   109.01  DIVISION OF CITY INTO FOUR WARDS.
   There are hereby established four wards pursuant to
Article III, Section 1, of the City Charter. Such wards shall be as hereinafter
described, subject to clarification as follows:
   (a)   In the case of a line formed by rear lot lines, such line shall be the
line formed by most of the lots having a coextensive line; and
   (b)   In the case of a property, lot or parcel bisected by such line, such
property, lot or parcel shall be in the ward in which the greatest part of it
lies.
      (Ord. 73-42. Passed 6-4-73.)
 
   109.02  WARD ONE.
   Ward One is bounded and described as follows: Beginning at the most
northwest corporation corner of the City, northwesterly of the westerly end of
Delevan Drive; thence easterly along the common boundary with the City of
Richmond Heights to its intersection with the westerly line of the Village of
Highland Heights; thence southerly along such mutual corporation line with the
Village of Highland Heights to Ridgebury Boulevard and the extension of such
line south of Ridgebury Boulevard along a line as is formed by the rear lot
lines of properties fronting on the west side of Irene Road; thence southerly
to the intersection with the centerline of Mayfield Road; thence westerly along
the centerline of Mayfield Road to its intersection with the centerline of
Richmond Road; thence northerly along the centerline of Richmond Road to its
intersection with a line which is the extension of the rear lot lines of the
properties fronting on the north side of Fairlawn Road; thence westerly along
such line formed by such rear lot lines of properties on the north side of
Fairlawn Road to the corporation line; thence northerly along the corporation
line to the northwest corporation corner which is the place of beginning.
(Ord. 73-42. Passed 6-4-73.)
 
   109.03  WARD TWO.
   Ward Two is bounded and described as follows: Beginning at the intersection
of the centerline of Ridgebury Boulevard and the westerly line of the Village
of Highland Heights or the extension of the rear lot line of the properties
fronting on the west side of Irene Road; thence easterly along the centerline
of Ridgebury Boulevard to the corporation line; thence southerly, easterly
(along Mayfield Road) and southerly along the common boundary with the City of
Mayfield Heights, to a line formed by the rear lot lines of properties abutting
Wellington and Cherokee Roads; thence westerly along the line of such rear lot
lines to the centerline of Brainard Road; thence northerly along the centerline
of Brainard Road to an extension of a line of the rear lot lines of the
properties fronting on the north side of Huron Road; thence westerly along such
rear lot lines of the properties fronting upon the north side of Huron Road to
the intersection of a line formed by the rear lot lines of the properties
fronting on the west side of Winchester Road; thence northerly along such rear
lot lines of properties fronting on the west side of Winchester Road to its
intersection with the centerline of Mayfield Road; thence easterly or westerly
along Mayfield Road to the intersection with an extension of a line which is
the rear lot lines of the properties fronting on the west side of Irene Road;
thence northerly along such rear lot lines of properties on the west side of
Irene Road to the intersection with the centerline of Ridgebury Boulevard,
which is the place of beginning.
(Ord. 73-42. Passed 6-4-73.)
 
   109.04  WARD THREE.
   Ward Three is bounded and described as follows: Beginning at the
intersection of the rear lot lines of the properties fronting on the west side
of Winchester Road and an extension of the rear lot lines of the properties
fronting on the north side of Huron Road; thence easterly to the intersection
of the line foregoing with the centerline of Brainard Road; thence northerly or
southerly to an extension of the rear lot lines of the properties fronting on
Wellington Road and the properties fronting on Cherokee Road; thence easterly
to the corporation lines; thence southerly, easterly, southerly, westerly and
southerly along the corporation line to the intersection with the centerline of
Cedar Road; thence westerly from the southeasterly-most intersection of the
corporation lines on Cedar Road to the intersection with a line which is the
southerly extension of the rear lot lines of the properties fronting on the
west side of Winchester Road; thence northerly along such line formed by the
rear lot lines of properties fronting on the west side of Winchester Road to
the intersection with an extension of the rear lot lines of the properties
fronting on the north side of Huron Road, which is the place of beginning.
(Ord. 73-42. Passed 6-4-73.)
 
   109.05  WARD FOUR.
   Ward Four is bounded and described as follows: Beginning at the intersection
of the corporation boundary and a line which is the westerly extension of the
rear lot lines of the properties fronting on the north side of Fairlawn Road;
thence easterly along such lines of such Fairlawn properties referred to above
to the intersection with the centerline of Richmond Road; thence southerly
along the centerline of Richmond Road to the intersection with the centerline
of Mayfield Road; thence easterly along the centerline of Mayfield Road to the
intersection with a line which is an extension of the rear lot lines of the
properties fronting on the west side of Winchester Road; thence southerly along
such westerly lines of the properties on the west side of Winchester Road to
its intersection with the centerline of Cedar Road; thence westerly along the
centerline of Cedar Road to the western-most corporation line; thence
northerly, easterly, northerly, easterly and northerly along the corporation
line to the intersection with a line which is an extension of the rear lot
lines of the properties fronting on the north side of Fairlawn Road, which is
the place of beginning.
(Ord. 73-42. Passed 6-4-73.)
 
   109.06  DESIGNATION OF BISECTED PROPERTIES.
   The Building Commissioner is hereby directed to designate properties which
are bisected by the ward lines set forth in this chapter and designate the ward
each of such properties is in, in accordance with Section
109.01(b). Such designation shall be made forthwith and certified to the Clerk
of Council.
(Ord. 73-42. Passed 6-4-73.)

   121.01  MEETINGS.
   Regular meetings of Council shall be held at the Council Chamber in the City
Hall on the first and third Monday of each month at 7:30 p.m. except that only
one regular meeting for June, July, August and December shall be required,
which shall be on the first Monday of June, July, August and December. When
City Hall is closed in observance of a legal holiday on the regular meeting
date, such regular meeting shall be held on the following day.
   A special meeting may be called by the Mayor or by any three Councilmen. At
least twenty-four hours notice of a special meeting shall be given to each
Councilman and the Mayor, which notice may either be in writing, delivered to
the person notified or left at his or her residence, or verbal notice delivered
directly or by telephone to the person notified. A regular or special meeting
may be adjourned to any time not later than that of the next regular meeting.
All meetings of Council shall be public and any resident shall have access to
the meetings and records thereof at all reasonable times, except as stated in
Ohio R.C. 121.22(G).
   At the initial regular meeting of the new term of the elected officials
elected at the election prior thereto, such officials may be sworn in and
assume their duties. Their compensation shall commence from the first day of
the year. Nothing herein, however, prevents an official from being sworn in
prior to such date should he or she so elect. It shall not be necessary for
Council to meet on New Year's Day as provided for in Ohio R.C. 705.74. (Ord.
75-120. Passed 12-15-75; Ord. 88-16. Passed 3-21-88.)
 
   (b)   Any official described in subsection (a) hereof who calls a special
meeting, and any Chairperson of a committee of Council who calls a meeting of
such committee, shall notify the Clerk of Council verbally or in writing as
such Clerk may require, at least seventy-two hours in advance of such meeting,
of the date, time and agenda of such meeting to permit such Clerk to comply
with the requirements of Ohio R.C. 121.22. In the event of any emergency
requiring a meeting on less notice than provided in Ohio R.C. 121.22(F), the
person calling such special meeting of Council or committee meeting shall give
immediate notice to the Clerk or his or her office so that immediate notice may
be given to the news media which have requested such notice. Ohio R.C. 121.22
(G) shall be observed.
   Each committee of Council shall be responsible for the recording of the
minutes reflecting the action taken at all committee meetings. Such minutes
shall be properly authenticated and submitted to the Clerk of Council and
retained by him or her until the end of the year following each Municipal
election. Thereafter the Clerk may destroy such minutes.
 
   (c)   Persons desiring notice and agendas of meetings of Council, its
committees and boards and commissions, as provided in Ohio R.C. 121.22, shall
deposit money with the Clerk of Council for one year, or if only one meeting
notice is desired, as follows:
      (1)   One dollar ($1.00) for a notice and agenda of any one meeting of
any body, agency or committee hereinafter referred to;
      (2)   Twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for notices and agendas of all
meetings of Council and its committees for one year or any part thereof ending
December 31, 1976, and for succeeding calendar years thereafter; or
      (3)   Five dollars ($5.00) for notices and agendas of meetings of each
separate committee of Council or a board or commission of the City during the
periods set forth in paragraph (c)(2) hereof.
         (Ord. 2015-58.  Passed 8-3-15.)
 
   121.02  QUORUM.
   A majority of the members of Council shall constitute a quorum for the
transaction of business at any meeting of Council, but a lesser number may
adjourn the meeting from time to time and compel the attendance of absent
members as provided in Section
 121.04.
(Ord. 4354. Passed 1-7-52.)
 
   121.03  OFFICERS OF COUNCIL.
   The Vice Mayor shall preside at all Council meetings.  During any period
when the Vice Mayor shall be absent or inaccessible or unable for any cause to
perform his or her duties, the Chairperson of the legislative committee shall
assume all of the duties and responsibilities of the Vice Mayor during such
period, including, but not limited to, presiding at Council meetings.  During
any period when the Chairperson of the legislative committee shall be absent or
inaccessible or unable for any cause to perform his or her duties as Vice
Mayor, the Chairperson of the Finance Committee shall assume all of the duties
and responsibilities of the Vice Mayor during such period, including, but not
limited to, presiding at Council meetings.  The Mayor may introduce ordinances
and resolutions and take part in the discussion of all matters coming before
Council.
   The Director of Finance shall act as Clerk of Council and the Mayor shall
appoint an employee of the City to be Assistant Clerk of Council.  Said
appointment shall be approved by a majority of Council.  The Clerk of Council
and the Assistant Clerk of Council shall be present at all Council meetings and
shall make such records of the proceedings as Council shall direct.  In case of
their absence from the meeting, Council shall designate one of its members or
some other person to perform the Clerk’s duties for the time.
   The person presiding at any Council meeting may designate one or more police
officers, firemen or other suitable persons to preserve order at the meeting.
(Ord. 2005-84.  Passed 1-3-06.)
 
   121.04  ENFORCEMENT OF ATTENDANCE.
   The Councilmen present at any regular meeting or at any special meeting for
which proper call has been made and notice given or at any adjourned meeting
properly held, may summarily inquire into the reasons for the absence of any
absent Councilman in such manner as they deem practicable and if, by unanimous
vote of those Councilmen present, they find such absence to be intentional and
without reasonable cause, they may designate one or more police officers,
firefighters or other suitable persons to require such Councilman forthwith to
attend the meeting if he or she is found within the Municipality and not
physically unable to attend.
   No Councilman shall be absent from any of the meetings above-mentioned.
(Ord. 4354. Passed 1-7-52.)
 
   121.05  DISTURBANCES.
   No person, whether a Councilman or not, shall disturb, hinder or prevent a
Council meeting by disorderly conduct or profane, indecent, abusive or
threatening language.
(Ord. 4354. Passed 1-7-52.)
 
   121.06  PROCEEDINGS NOT DEEMED ORDINANCES OR RESOLUTIONS.
   No proceeding of Council or any of its members or officers taken pursuant to
Sections
 121.04,
121.05 and
121.99 shall be deemed a resolution or ordinance or subject to the terms of
this chapter or the Charter covering resolutions or ordinances.
(Ord. 4354. Passed 1-7-52.)
 
   121.07  COMMITTEES.
   The Vice Mayor shall appoint a Finance Committee, a Legislative Committee, a
Safety Committee, a Roads and Utilities Committee, a Service and Sewer
Committee, a Public Lands and Buildings Committee and such other standing or
temporary committees as he or she may deem proper, and shall designate the
Chairperson of each such Committee. The Presiding Officer of Council may, when
circumstances require, appoint a temporary special administrative committee
which may include members of Council.
(Ord. 81-72. Passed 12-21-81.)
 
   121.08  INVESTIGATORY POWERS.
   Council is hereby authorized to issue subpoenas or some compulsory process
to compel the attendance of persons and the production of books and papers
before Council for the purpose of investigating charges against the head or
officer of any department.
(Ord. 3462. Passed 11-17-41.)
 
   121.09  ORAL BID TAKING PERMITTED.
   (a)   The Councilmanic authorization for the making of expenditures in
excess of the statutory amount authorized by Ohio R.C. 735.05 and 737.03, which
sections also direct the advertising for bids, may be had by oral motion of
Council. When bids are received pursuant to such advertising by Council in its
capacity as a Board of Control, pursuant to
 Article III, Section 3, of the Charter and Ohio R.C. 733.22, it shall approve
or disapprove the award of a contract by a particular department of the City.
In the event that it approves the award of a contract, it shall authorize the
Mayor to enter into such contract. This provision is provided in accordance
with and in furtherance of the requirement of
 Article III, Section 5(f), of the Charter. (Ord. 75-110. Passed 12-1-75.)
 
   (b)   The Clerk of Council shall cause notice to be given in accordance with
Section
123.02(a) of the Councilmanic authorization for such advertising for bids.
 
   121.10  MONTHLY STATEMENT BY DIRECTOR OF FINANCE.
   (a)   The Director of Finance shall prepare and submit to the Board of
Control each month a summary statement of revenues and expenses for the
preceding month, detailed as to appropriations and funds in such manner as to
show the  financial condition of the City and of each department and office
thereof as of the last day of the previous month.  Said summary statement shall
show, at a minimum, the following information:
      (1)   All receipts had during the preceding month.
      (2)   All disbursements made during the preceding month.
      (3)   A cumulative statement for each appropriation showing:
         A.   Amount of appropriations;
         B.   Amount expended against the appropriation at the end of the
preceding month;
         C.   Balance remaining.
   The foregoing summary statement shall be in such further detail as may be
required by Council to show the financial condition of the City as of the date
of the statement.
   (b)   At the next Board of Control meeting following the submission of the
summary statement the Board of Control shall by voice vote approve the summary
statement as to content and form. 
(Ord. 2005-85.  Passed 12-5-05.)
 
   121.11 PUBLIC RECORDS POLICY.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Council hereby adopts the City of Lyndhurst Public Records
Policy, a copy of which is attached to Resolution 2009-68 as Exhibit A and made
a part hereof.)
 
   121.99  PENALTY.
   (a)   Any Councilman violating Section
 121.04 may, upon the concurrence of all the Councilmen present at the next
regular meeting, if they find such absence to be intentional and without
reasonable cause, be considered guilty of a minor misdemeanor and fined not
more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for such absence, which penalty shall
be deducted from the compensation of such Councilman.
 
   (b)   Whoever violates Section
121.05 is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree. In addition, any person
may be summarily removed from the Council Chamber by any police officer,
firefighter or other person designated for that duty by the person presiding at
the Council meeting and may be detained in such manner as to prevent him or
her, from further disturbing the meeting and for one hour after its
adjournment.   
 
 
 
CHAPTER 123
Ordinances and Resolutions
 
123.01   Adoption.
123.02   Publication.
123.03   Sale of documents.
123.04   Veto; reconsideration.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      General Ordinances - see CHTR.
Art. III, §5
      Effective date - see CHTR.
Art. III, §6
      Mayor's legislative powers - see CHTR.
Art. IV, §3
      Mayor's veto - see CHTR.
Art. IV, §4
      Adoption and style - see Ohio R.C. 715.03, 731.17 et seq.
      Posting - see Ohio R.C. 731.25
 
   123.01  ADOPTION.
       (a)   All actions of Council shall be by written ordinance or
resolution, except actions authorized in this chapter, Chapter
121 or the City Charter or when it is acting in its capacity as a Board of
Control, reviewing agency of the Board of Zoning Appeals and City Planning
Commission or when otherwise authorized in these Codified Ordinances. In such
latter instances, its action may be by oral resolution recorded in its Journal.
Written ordinances and resolutions shall require, for their adoption, the
affirmative votes of at least four members of Council unless a larger number is
required by the provisions of the Charter or by the laws of Ohio, taken by a
yea or nay vote of each Councilman, entered upon the Journal of the Proceedings
of Council.
   (b)   Each ordinance or resolution of a general or permanent nature shall be
introduced in written or printed form, shall contain not more than one subject
or group of related subjects, except as otherwise provided by the Charter, and
shall, before its passage, be read in full on three separate days unless the
requirement for such reading be dispensed with by the concurrence of at least
five Councilmen. However, any emergency measure or any measure of a series
necessary to provide for making or paying for a public improvement, except the
first of such series, may be passed after one reading. An ordinance when
sponsored by a member of Council shall indicate such sponsorship in the
heading; otherwise it shall be considered a measure sponsored by the
administration.
   (c)   Measures not of a general or permanent nature may be adopted, except
as otherwise provided in this chapter or by the Charter, on the motion of any
Councilman, by the affirmative votes of at least four Councilmen and each such
measure shall be deemed a resolution unless expressly designated as an
ordinance. Each such measure shall be entered in full upon the Journal and the
subsequent approval by Council of the minutes containing such entry shall be
conclusive proof of the correctness of such entry.
   (d)   An ordinance may be amended by reference to and providing the
identifying number, alphabetical number or other designator of the section,
subsection or part thereof being amended. It shall not be necessary to set
forth the entire ordinance or section being amended.
   (e)   Any legislation not adopted by the end of a term of Council shall fall
off the agenda without further action by Council, and must be reintroduced at
the next term of Council to be considered.  (Ord. 2014-4.  Passed 2-17-14.)
 
   123.02  PUBLICATION.
   (a)   All ordinances, resolutions, statements, orders, proclamations,
notices and reports required by law to be published and notices to bidders for
the construction of public improvements and notices of the sale of bonds shall
be published for a day in each of two consecutive weeks, as hereinafter
provided, in a newspaper of general circulation in the Municipality.
   Such ordinances, resolutions, statements, orders, proclamations, notices and
reports required by law to be published shall be published by the title thereof
except that such title shall fairly apprise a reader of the subject matter of
such ordinances, resolutions, statements, orders, proclamations, notices and
reports. The title for publication shall be prepared or approved by the
Director of Law.
   Council, in special cases, may designate a longer publication period.
 
   (b)   The Director of Finance is hereby authorized and directed to solicit
bids for the cost of such publications from newspapers of general circulation
in the City for a period of one year. If the cost of such publication is less
than ten thousand dollars ($10,000), he or she shall report the same to the
Board of Control for an award of a contract for such publications for a period
of one year. If the cost exceeds ten thousand dollars ($10,000), then bids
shall be taken for such publication and bids shall be taken in accordance with
Chapter
107. Thereafter, the Mayor shall enter into a contract in accordance with
Article IV, Section 5, of the City Charter.
(Ord. 80-19. Passed 2-19-80.)
 
   123.03  SALE OF DOCUMENTS.
   The following charges are hereby established for City records, ordinances
and other documents:
 
(a)   Copies of ordinances, including the Codified Ordinances, per page side
                                                                                $ .50
(b)   Copies of police reports and all other miscellaneous  documents, per p
side                                                                            2.00
(c)   The Zoning Code in a binder                                         25.00
(d)   Zoning Maps:   small                                                  1.00
                              large                              25.00
(e)   Street address maps                                                    25.00
(f)   A paperbound copy of the Codified Ordinances                           100.00
(g)   Photographs:
   black and white, per copy                                                 5.00
   color, per copy                                                           10.00
(h)   Tabulation of special assessments, each parcel (except where more than
one of adjoining parcels is required, which parcels have identical assessment
charges, in which case the charge for each additional parcel shall be twenty-
five cents (25¢) per item)
                                                                                1.00
(i)   Copies of public records, pursuant to written public records request, p
page copy                                                                         .10
(j)   Master Zoning Plan                                                     25.00
      (Ord. 2006-77.  Passed 11-6-06.)
 
   123.04  VETO; RECONSIDERATION.
   When any legislation is disapproved or vetoed by the Mayor, the Clerk of
Council shall cause to be delivered to each member of Council within three days
a copy of the disapproved legislation and the written statement of objections
and shall also cause such legislation to be placed upon the agenda of the next
regular Council meeting for consideration. 
(Ord. 85-14. Passed 2-4-85.)

   131.01  MAYOR AS SAFETY DIRECTOR.
   Until otherwise provided by Council, the Mayor shall be the Director of
Safety of the City.
 
   131.02  MAYOR AS CUSTODIAN OF CITY PROPERTY.
   The Mayor is hereby declared to be the custodian of any and all property,
real, personal and mixed, to which the City has any right, title or interest or
over which the City has any power of appointment.
 
 
 
CHAPTER 133
Law Department
 
133.01   Composition.
133.02   Duties of Director; compensation.
133.03   Duties of City Prosecutor; compensation.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
   Created - see CHTR.
Art. V, §1
   Director - see CHTR.
 Art. V, §2
   Solicitor (City), powers and duties - see Ohio R.C.  733.51 et seq.
   Equitable remedies under Zoning Code - see P. & Z.
 1152.14
 
   133.01  COMPOSITION.
   The Law Department shall consist of the Director of Law and the City
Prosecutor, and such additional counsel as may hereafter be authorized by
Council.  The Director of Law shall have all the powers and perform all the
duties provided by the laws of the State of Ohio for directors of law and City
solicitors.  The City Prosecutor shall have all the powers and perform all the
duties provided by the State of Ohio for City prosecutors.
(Ord. 2014-6.  Passed 3-3-14.)
 
   133.02  DUTIES OF DIRECTOR; COMPENSATION.
   (a)   The services to be performed by the Director of Law, as a part-time
employee of the City (effective March 1, 1999), subject to all benefits of
part-time employees of the City and further subject to all normal deductions,
including PERS, and included in the annual compensation shall be: 
      (1)   Attendance and advice at all regular and special Council meetings
not to exceed twenty-four meetings per year;
      (2)   Attendance and advice at all regular and special Planning
Commission meetings not to exceed twelve meetings per year;
      (3)   Attendance and advice at all regular and special Board of Zoning
Appeals meetings not to exceed twelve meetings per year;
      (4)   All regular legislation necessary for the above meetings;
      (5)   All meetings of the Civil Service Commission and regular business;
and
      (6)   Up to twelve (12) hours of legal service per month.
   (b)   All other matters requiring attention by the Law Director not included
in subsection (a) hereof shall, in addition to the base salary, be compensated
for at an hourly rate to be determined annually by council.  Such other matters
include, but are not limited to, special preparation and services required
beyond the scope of subsection (a) hereof, and litigation, court appearances,
negotiations, preparations of covenants, zoning legislation and research,
certificates, notes, bonds, assessments and other matters incidental to the
foregoing special services.
   (c)   Should any special representation be required beyond the normal scope
of the regular or special duties outlined above, upon recommendation of the
Mayor, approval of such representation and compensation for such services shall
be subject to formal approval by Council in advance.
   (d)   Upon the request of the Director of Finance, the Director of Law shall
submit in writing a memo setting a value on the services performed in
connection with any public project financed by special assessments.  Such
amount shall then be included in the cost of such project with a memo entry of
credit to the General Fund in the same amount. 
(Ord. 2014-6.  Passed 3-3-14.)
   133.03  DUTIES OF CITY PROSECUTOR; COMPENSATION.
   (a)   The services to be performed by the City Prosecutor as a part-time
employee of the City, subject to all benefits of part-time employees of the
City, and further subject to all normal deductions, including pers, shall be
the following:
      (1)   Preparation of all cases in the Lyndhurst Municipal Court;
      (2)   Meetings with persons having complaints with the city, residents,
or others as are customarily handled by the Prosecutor;
      (3)   Meetings with police officers of the City as the same are necessary
to aid the prosecutor in the preparation of a case; and
      (4)   In-house consultation with the Chief of Police and his designees.
   (b)   The annual compensation shall be set by Council.
   (c)   All other matters requiring attention by the City Prosecutor not
included in subsection (a) hereof shall, in addition to the base salary, be
compensated for at an hourly rate to be determined annually by Council.  Such
other matters include, but are not limited to, special preparation and services
required beyond the scope of subsection (a) hereof, and other matters
incidental to the foregoing special services, including appearances in the Ohio
Court of Appeals and the Ohio Supreme Court. Such additional services shall be
performed only upon recommendation by the Mayor and approval by Council.
(Ord. 2014-6.  Passed 3-3-14.)
 
 
 
CHAPTER 135
Finance Department
 
135.01   Composition.
135.02   Assistant Finance Director as Acting Director.
135.03   Director's duties.

135.11   Indigent Driver's Alcohol Treatment Fund.
135.12   Enforcement and Education Fund.

135.14   Finance Department Petty  Cash Fund.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Created - see CHTR.
Art. V, §1
      Director; appointment, term and duties - see CHTR.
Art. V, §3
      Contracts and fiscal matters - see CHTR.

   135.01  COMPOSITION.
   The Finance Department shall consist of the Director of Finance, the
Assistant Finance Director and such other persons as required to carry out the
duties of the Department. The Director of Finance shall be the executive head
of the Finance Department, under the direction of the Mayor, and shall have and
exercise all powers and duties provided by the Charter of the City. The
Assistant Finance Director shall assist in the performance of such duties in
such manner as the Director of Finance may require. 
(Ord. 85-31. Passed 4-1-85.)
 
   135.02  ASSISTANT FINANCE DIRECTOR AS ACTING DIRECTOR.
   The Assistant Finance Director shall serve as Acting Director of Finance in
the absence and/or disability of the Director of Finance.
(Ord. 85-31. Passed 4-1-85.)
 
   135.03  DIRECTOR'S DUTIES.
   The Director of Finance shall be responsible for the purchase of all
supplies and material required for the use of any department or officer of the
City, except in the case of contracts for the construction of public
improvements, and excepting purchases specifically authorized by Council. The
head of any department for which supplies or materials are required shall
notify the Director of Finance of such requirements and the Director of Finance
shall promptly make the necessary purchase if funds are available therefor.
Purchases in the amount of fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000) or more shall be
made only from the lowest and best bidder after advertising for two consecutive
weeks in a newspaper of general circulation in the City. A recommendation as to
the lowest and best bidder shall be forwarded by the Director of Finance, the
Mayor and the head of the department concerned to the Board of Control. 
(Ord. 89-55. Passed 5-1-89; Ord. 2001-1.  Passed 1-16-01.)
 
   135.04  SALE OF PERSONAL PROPERTY.
   (a)   The Director of Finance shall also have the power to sell personal
property belonging to the City, on the instructions from the head of the
department concerned and with the consent and approval of the Mayor, such sale
being made in the manner provided by the laws of the State of Ohio.
   (b)   Personal property may be sold by Internet auction in the manner
outlined in Section 721.15 of the Ohio Revised Code, provided that the number
of days of bidding shall be not less than three (3) consecutive calendar days. 
The minimum number of days of bidding shall be stated in the ordinance
authorizing the sale of the personal property, and the minimum bid shall
likewise be stated in the ordinance.  The Mayor may be authorized in the
ordinance to sell any item of personal property to the highest bidder if the
minimum bid price is reached, without further action by Council.
   (c)   Personal property of the value of less than one thousand dollars
($1,000) may be transferred as part payment for the purchase of other personal
property on such terms as may be acceptable to the Director of Finance, the
Mayor and the head of the department concerned.
(Ord. 2006-56.  Passed 8-7-06.)
 
   135.05  SECRETARY TO DIRECTOR.
   The position of Secretary to the Director of Finance in the Finance
Department is hereby established. The Secretary to the Director of Finance
shall assist in the performance of the duties of the Director of Finance in
such manner as the Director of Finance may require. (Ord. 4584. Passed 2-15-
54.)
 
   135.06  AUTHORIZED SIGNATURES.
   (a)   The resources of the City in depository accounts, which have been duly
authorized and are maintained by the City, may be withdrawn from such accounts
by checks and/or other instruments issued in the name of the Municipality upon
any two of the signatures of the Mayor, the Director of Finance and a
designated secretary in the Finance Department.
 
   (b)   Checks and/or other instruments issued in the name of the City over
the mechanical signatures of any two persons including the Mayor, the Director
of Finance and a designated secretary in the Finance Department are authorized,
and any depository shall recognize as the signature of such authorized signer,
the facsimile of such authorized signer in every instance where the same may
appear purporting to be drawn or issued on behalf of the City and whenever the
mechanical signature on any check or draft shall correspond to or resemble the
facsimile specimen certified to any depository by the City, and to pay, honor
or certify any checks or drafts bearing such facsimile signatures.
 
   (c)   Any depository of the funds of the City, as a transfer agent for the
City and in reliance on the accuracy and sufficiency of written and/or verbal
instructions of the Mayor or the Director of Finance, may act to implement
transmission of City funds by bank wire to any other financial institution for
the account of the City or to the account of any other person, firm or
corporation without inquiry as to the circumstances of the transfer and to
charge the City's account therefor.
(Ord. 85-7. Passed 1-7-85.)
 
   135.07  CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT FUNDS.
   (a)   Lyndhurst Commercial Improvement Fund.  (EDITOR'S NOTE:  Subsection
(a) was repealed by Ordinance 96-63, passed December 16, 1996.)
 
   (b)   Street Improvement Fund.
      (1)   The Director of Finance is hereby authorized and directed to
establish a capital improvement fund, to be identified as the Street
Improvement Fund, to be used solely and exclusively for the purpose of
receiving and disbursing all monies related to making capital improvements to
various streets throughout the City.
      (2)   Expenditures from said Fund shall be made by the Director of
Finance upon receipt of the proper certificates and vouchers approved by the
City Engineer and such other officers authorized by law or by Council.
         (Ord. 88-17.  Passed 3-21-88.)
 
   135.08  SEWER CONSTRUCTION FUND.
   (a)   The Director of Finance is authorized and directed to establish a
special assessment fund, to be identified as the Sewer Construction Fund, to be
used solely and exclusively for the purpose of receiving and disbursing all
monies related to making sewer capital improvements, including debt retirement,
for the City.
 
   (b)   Expenditures from said Fund shall be made by the Director of Finance
upon receipt of the proper appropriations approved by the Mayor, the Finance
Director and Council. 
(Ord. 89-35. Passed 3-20-89.)
 
   135.09  LAW ENFORCEMENT TRUST FUND.
   (a)   A Special Revenue Fund, known as the Law Enforcement Trust Fund, is
hereby established for the purpose of receiving and expending money pursuant
to, and in the manner prescribed by, Ohio R.C. 2933.43.
 
   (b)   Any property, other than contraband, that is subject to the provisions
of Ohio R.C. 2933.43, and other than property that has been lawfully seized in
relation to a violation of Ohio R.C. 2933.42, or forfeited pursuant to Federal
law and required to be used for law enforcement purposes, that has been lost,
abandoned, stolen or lawfully seized or forfeited, and that is in the custody
of the Police Department of the City, shall be safely kept pending the time it
is no longer needed as evidence and disposed of pursuant to Section
606.24 of the General Offenses Code.
 
   (c)   The revenues in the Law Enforcement Trust Fund shall be allocated only
to the Police Department of the City.  The funds shall be expended only to pay
the costs of protracted or complex investigations or prosecutions, to provide
reasonable technical training or expertise, to provide matching funds to obtain
Federal grants to aid law enforcement, or for such other law enforcement
purposes that Council determines to be appropriate.  The Fund shall not be used
to meet operating costs of the City that are unrelated to law enforcement.
(Ord. 91-4.  Passed 1-7-91.)
 
   135.10  LAW ENFORCEMENT MANDATORY DRUG FINE FUND.
   (a)   In accordance with Ohio R.C. 2925.03, there is hereby established a
Law Enforcement Mandatory Drug Fine Fund.  All money forfeited to the City
pursuant to Ohio R.C. 2925.03 or Section
624.02 of the General Offenses Code shall be credited to this Fund.
 
   (b)   The Director of Safety is hereby authorized to accept all mandatory
drug fines and forfeited bail imposed for violations of Ohio R.C. 2925.03 or
Section
624.02 of the General Offenses Code.
(Ord. 91-5.  Passed 1-7-91.)
 
   (c)   The revenues of the Law Enforcement Mandatory Drug Fine Fund shall
only be used to subsidize the law enforcement efforts of the City that pertain
to drug offenses. 
(Ord. 92-57.  Passed 8-3-92.)
 
   135.11  INDIGENT DRIVER'S ALCOHOL TREATMENT FUND.
   (a)   The Director of Finance is hereby authorized and directed to establish
an Indigent Driver's Alcohol Treatment Fund pursuant to Ohio R.C. 4511.191(M)
and said Fund shall be used solely and exclusively for the purpose of receiving
all revenue that the General Assembly appropriates to the Indigent Driver's
Alcohol Treatment Fund and all portions of the fees that are paid under Ohio
R.C. 4511.191(J).
 
   (b)   Expenditures from said Fund shall be made in accordance with Ohio R.C.
4511.191(M) and shall be made only upon order of a County or Municipal Court
Judge and only for payment of the costs of attendance at an Alcohol and Drug
Addiction Treatment Program of a person who is convicted of a violation of Ohio
R.C. 4511.19 or Section
434.01 of the Traffic Code, who is ordered by the Court to attend the Alcohol
and Drug Addiction Treatment Program, and who is determined by the Court to be
unable to pay the cost of his or her attendance at the Treatment Program.
(Ord. 92-8.  Passed 1-21-92.)
 
   135.12  ENFORCEMENT AND EDUCATION FUND.
   (a)   The Director of Finance is hereby authorized and directed to establish
an Enforcement and Education Fund and said Fund shall be used solely and
exclusively for the purposes set forth in Ohio R.C. 4511.191.
 
   (b)   Expenditures from said Fund shall be made by the Director of Finance
to pay only those costs it incurs in enforcing Ohio R.C. 4511.191 or Section
434.01 of the Traffic Code and in educating the public as to laws governing
operation of a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol, the dangers
of operation of a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol, and other
information relating to the operation of a motor vehicle and the consumption of
alcoholic beverages.
(Ord. 92-9.  Passed 1-21-92.)
 
   135.13  INVESTMENT AND DEPOSITORY POLICY.
   (a)   Scope.  Council hereby directs that the investing authority of the
City shall reside with the Finance Director (the "Treasurer") or acting Finance
Director in accordance with this investment policy.  This policy is designed to
cover all monies under the control of the Finance Director and those that
comprise the core investment portfolio of the City.  Notwithstanding the
policies detailed below, Ohio R.C. Chapter 135 will be adhered to at all times.
 
   (b)   Objectives and Guidelines.  The following investment objectives will
be applied in the management of the City's funds:
      (1)   The primary objective shall be the preservation of capital and
protection of principal while earning investment interest.
      (2)   In investing public funds, the Finance Director will strive to
achieve a fair and safe average rate of return on the investment portfolio over
the course of budgetary and economic cycles, taking into account State law,
safety considerations and cash flow requirements.
      (3)   The investment portfolio shall remain sufficiently liquid to enable
the Finance Director to meet reasonably anticipated operating requirements.
      (4)   The investment portfolio should be diversified in order to avoid
incurring potential losses regarding individual securities which may not be
held to maturity, whether by erosion of market value or change in market
conditions.
      (5)   Investments shall be made with the exercise of that degree of
judgment and care, under circumstances then prevailing, which persons of
prudence, discretion and intelligence exercise in the management of their own
affairs, not for speculation but for investment, considering the probable
safety of their capital as well as the probable income to be derived.
      (6)   The Finance Director, acting in accordance with written procedures
and this investment policy, and exercising due diligence, shall be relieved of
personal responsibility for an individual security is credit risk or market
price changes, provided that the deviations from expectations are reported in a
timely fashion and appropriate action is taken to control adverse developments.
      (7)   To maintain the portfolio's current characteristics and/or to
enhance its yield, swapping (i.e. the simultaneous sale of one security and the
purchase of another) will be permitted, provided that the loss, if any, on the
sale is recovered in one-half the time or less remaining to maturity of the
security being sold.
      (8)   Bank account relationships will be managed in order to secure
adequate services while minimizing costs.  Deposits should be concentrated in
single accounts except where audit control considerations dictate otherwise.
 
   (c)   Authorized Financial Institutions and Dealers.  U.S. Treasury and
Agency Securities purchased outright shall be purchased only through financial
institutions located within the State of Ohio or through primary securities
dealers as designated by the Federal Reserve Board.
   Repurchase Agreements shall be transacted only through banks located within
the State of Ohio with which the Finance Director has signed a Master
Repurchase Agreement as required in Ohio R.C. Chapter 135.
   The market value of the securities subject to the repurchase agreement must
exceed the principal value of the repurchase agreement by at least two
percent.  Securities subject to repurchase agreements must be marked to market
daily.
   Certificates of Deposit shall be transacted through commercial banks or
savings and loans with FDIC or FSLIC coverage which are located within the
State of Ohio and qualify as eligible financial institutions under Ohio R.C.
Chapter 135.
   A list of authorized institutions and dealers shall be maintained with the
investing authority.  Additions and deletions to this list shall be made when
deemed in the best interest of the investing authority.
 
   (d)   Maturity.  To the extent possible, the Finance Director will attempt
to match investments with anticipated cash flow requirements.  Unless matched
to a specific cash flow requirement, the Finance Director will not directly
invest in securities maturing more than five years from the date of purchase.
 
   (e)   Derivatives.  Investments in derivatives and in stripped principal or
interest obligations of eligible obligations are strictly prohibited.  A
derivative means a financial instrument, contract or obligation whose value or
return is based upon or linked to another asset or index, or both, separate
from the financial instrument, contract or obligation itself.  Additionally,
any security, obligation, trust account or instrument that is created from an
obligation of a Federal agency or instrumentality, or from both, is considered
a derivative instrument.
 
   (f)   Allowable Investments.  The Finance Director may invest in any
instrument or security authorized in Ohio R.C. Chapter 135, as amended.  A copy
of the appropriate Ohio R.C. section will be kept with this policy.
 
   (g)   Collateral.  All deposits shall be collateralized pursuant to Ohio
R.C. Chapter 135.
 
   (h)   Reporting.  The investing authority shall establish and maintain an
inventory of all obligations and securities acquired by the investing
authority.  The inventory shall include the description of the security, its
type, the cost, its par value, the maturity date, the settlement date and the
coupon rate.  The investing authority shall produce a monthly portfolio report
detailing the current inventory of all obligations and securities, all
transactions during the month, income received and investment expenses paid,
and the names of any persons effecting transactions on behalf of the investment
authority.
   Any agreements for the deposit, investment or management of public money,
including investment advisory agreements entered into pursuant to this policy,
may, but need not, include a nonbinding arbitration clause and may not include
a binding arbitration clause.
   Pursuant to Ohio R.C. Chapter 135, all brokers, dealers and financial
institutions initiating transactions with the investment authority by giving
advice or making investment policy, or executing transactions initiated by the
investment authority, must acknowledge their agreement to abide by the rules
and regulations of Ohio R.C. Chapter 135, any future addendums thereto and this
investment policy.
(Ord. 96-41.  Passed 9-3-96.)
 
   135.14 FINANCE DEPARTMENT PETTY CASH FUND.
   A Petty Cash Fund not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00) at any time
for use by the Finance Department in the pursuance of the duties of the
Department is hereby established.  The amount of each expenditure and
supporting evidence shall be subject to the approval of the Director of
Finance, who shall charge such expenditures to an appropriate item of the
budget.
(Ord. 2009-54.  Passed 7-6-09.)

CHAPTER 139
Safety Department
 
139.01   Emergency calls outside City limits.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Mayor designated as Director - see ADM.
131.01
      Overtime for safety forces - see ADM.

   139.01  EMERGENCY CALLS OUTSIDE CITY LIMITS.
   (a)   Pursuant to Ohio R.C. 9.60 and 737.041, as amended, Council hereby
authorizes the Director of Safety, the Chiefs of the Police and Fire
Departments, and the officers on duty in charge of the Police and Fire
Departments, to render the services of those Departments to other
municipalities, townships, counties or the State in times of emergency, whether
or not the City has entered into mutual aid contracts for police or fire
services with any of those political subdivisions or the State. The
determination of "times of emergency" shall be made only by the Director of
Safety, the Chiefs of the Police and Fire Departments, or the officers on duty
in charge of the Police and Fire Departments, upon a call for emergency police
or fire protection services by the State or another political subdivision of
the State. In addition, even though a request for assistance has not been made,
a City of Lyndhurst police officer who sees a police officer in another
jurisdiction in distress or receives an urgent call for aid to any other
officer in distress nearby, may, in the exercise of sound discretion and
reasonable judgement, enter into the other jurisdiction to render assistance to
the officer in distress.
 
   (b)   The personnel of the Police and Fire Departments rendering emergency
services to other political subdivisions, or rendering service to an officer in
distress,  shall, as provided by State law, be entitled to all of their usual
wages and benefits, shall be covered by Workers' Compensation, and shall be
immune from any liability arising from the reasonable, good faith rendering of
emergency police and fire protection services or the rendering of services to
an officer in distress as provided herein.
(Ord. 89-45. Passed 4-3-89; Ord. 2001-16. Passed 3-5-01.)

   141.01  COMPOSITION; ACTING CHIEF.
   The composition of the Police Department of the City shall not exceed the
following: 
   (a)   One Chief of Police; six Lieutenants (one of whom will be designated
by the Chief of Police to serve as Executive Lieutenant); four Sergeants; up to
twenty-two Patrol Officers; twenty-five Auxiliary Police Officers, and seven
Special Police Officers.
   (b)   In the event of the prolonged absence, unavailability or disability of
the Police Chief, the Executive Lieutenant (designated by the Police Chief)
will serve as Acting Police Chief and, subject to prior approval of the Mayor,
will be compensated accordingly during that period.
      (Ord. 2011-51.  Passed 9-6-11.)
 
   141.02  POWERS AND DUTIES OF CHIEF.
   The Chief of the Police Department shall be the head of the Police
Department. He or she shall preside at all meetings of the Police Department,
shall have charge of and be responsible for proper maintenance of the apparatus
of the Department, and shall, with the consent and approval of the Mayor,
establish rules for the operation of the Police Department and the duties and
conduct of the members thereof. He or she shall have power to suspend any
member of the Police Department for violation of rules, disobedience to orders
of a superior officer or disorderly conduct while on duty, but such suspension
shall be reported immediately to the Mayor, who shall take such action thereon
as he or she may see fit.
   All members of the Police Department shall have all the powers provided by
ordinance and the laws of the State of Ohio for police officers of cities, and
shall exercise the same in such manner as may be provided by the rules of the
Department and the orders of the Mayor, the Chief of Police, the Captain,
Lieutenants and Sergeants. 
(Ord. 4356. Passed 1-7-52.)
 
   141.03  DETECTIVE BUREAU.
   Four members of the Police Department, other than the Chief of Police, who
shall have served in the Department at least two years, may be assigned to
perform detective duties by the Chief of Police and Mayor. The members acting
as Detectives of the Department shall perform detective duties in the accepted
sense of such designation, except in those circumstances when they may be
reassigned to regular police duties, at the discretion of the Mayor and the
Chief of Police, and shall be known as the Detective Bureau.
   The Mayor and Chief of Police, in the event of an emergency, shall have the
authority to temporarily assign assistants to the Detectives from members of
the Police Department who have served more than two years, but while so
assigned such assistants shall not be entitled to additional compensation.
(Ord. 73-27. Passed 4-2-73.)
 
   141.04  WORK WEEK.
   The work week of the Police Department shall be as provided in Section
159.14.
 
   141.05  AUXILIARY POLICE UNIT.
   (a)   In the Police Department, there is hereby created a body to be known
as the "Auxiliary Police Unit" which shall be under the management control of
the Chief of Police. The Director of Safety shall, subject to the approval of
Council, promulgate rules and regulations for the organization, training,
administration, control, duties and conduct of the Auxiliary Police Unit. Duty
performance shall include civil defense duties as may be required by such
Director or Council. 
(Ord. 81-5. Passed 1-19-81.)
 
   (b)   Members of the Auxiliary Police Unit are not eligible for membership
in the Police and Firemen's Disability and Pension Fund under Ohio R.C. Chapter
742, nor shall they be in the classified service of the Municipality.
 
   (c)   Members of the Auxiliary Police Unit shall be eligible for
compensation under Ohio R.C. Chapter 4123, or under any ordinance, or to
receive any benefits or compensations under any Act of Congress or under any
law of the State.
(Ord. 70-47. Passed 9-8-70.)
 
   141.06  SCHOOL GUARDS.
   The Mayor is hereby authorized to appoint ten school guards who shall have
such authority and duties with respect to pedestrian and automobile traffic as
the Mayor shall direct.
(Ord. 60-76. Passed 10-3-60.)
 
   141.07  DETECTIVE BUREAU PETTY CASH FUND.
   A Petty Cash Fund not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00) at any time
for use by the Detective Bureau in the pursuance of the duties of the Bureau,
is hereby established. The Fund shall be expended by the officer or officers
serving as detective or detectives who shall supply evidence of each item of
expense. The amount of such expenditure and supporting evidence shall be
subject to the approval of the Mayor who may delegate such function to the
Chief of the Police Department. The Director of Finance shall charge such
expenditures to an appropriate item of the Police Department budget.
(Ord. 61-62. Passed 7-17-61; Ord. 87-61. Passed 7-6-87; Ord. 99-51.  Passed 10-
4-99.)
 
   141.08  UNIFORM ALLOWANCES.
   (a)   Subject to Section
159.21, each full-time regular member of the Police Department of the City
shall receive, in addition to all other compensation, an allowance for uniforms
and cleaning. The amount of such allowance shall be in accordance with the
provisions of the compensation ordinance of the City.
 
   (b)   The Director of Finance is hereby authorized and directed to pay to
each officer of the Department performing the duties of Detective, annually, to
reimburse him or her for clothing expenditures, an allowance corresponding to
moneys paid to uniformed police officers.
 
   (c)   The official or employee performing the duties of the School Guard-Dog
Warden, at least forty hours a week, shall receive a uniform allowance, in
addition to his or her regular remuneration, as provided for in the City's
compensation ordinance.
(Adopting Ordinance)
 
   (d)   Special Police Officers shall be paid, upon presentation of paid
invoices and/or invoices supported by purchase orders and upon the approval of
the Mayor, up to one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) per annum as a uniform
allowance.
(Ord. 94-63.  Passed 9-6-94.)
 
   141.09  USE OF PISTOL AND RIFLE RANGE.
   (a)   The Director of Safety and the Chief of Police are hereby authorized
and directed to extend the use of the Pistol and Rifle Range in the police
facilities to members of police departments from municipalities with which the
City has mutual aid agreements or which are members of S.P.A.N. The cost of the
use of such Range by such other municipalities shall be eight dollars ($8.00)
per man per month, and billings therefor shall be made by the Department of
Finance at regular intervals determined appropriate by the Director of Finance.
The contracting municipalities shall be obligated to pay the monthly fee for
all men or personnel, or eight dollars ($8.00) times the number of men in their
respective police departments. If there is any question as to whether a
reservation has been made, the records of the Chief of Police or his or her
designated firing range officer shall control.
 
   (b)   The contracting municipality is responsible for its men and equipment
on City of Lyndhurst premises. It will indemnify and save Lyndhurst harmless
from any and all liabilities or damage of any nature whatever, directly or
indirectly incurred by such employees and representatives in their use of the
City of Lyndhurst premises. Such liabilities and damages shall also include
Lyndhurst's cost and attorney's fees or the reasonable value thereof if the
exact expense is not known. Such municipalities shall further agree that its
personnel take the premises as they are, that the premises are satisfactory to
them and that they are not business invitees, but mere licensees. The personnel
using such Lyndhurst facilities will be instructed as to the meaning of such
terms under Ohio law by the legal officer of the City of Lyndhurst. The
contracting municipality shall arrange that its personnel will be in the course
of their employment of such municipality's business while its personnel are
using the aforesaid facilities, much the same as is provided for under typical
mutual aid contracts between municipalities, including those between Lyndhurst
and communities in its near vicinity.
 
   (c)   Municipalities desiring to have their police members use the Pistol
and Rifle Range shall cause a copy of this section to be signed, in lieu of
preparation of other documents, by the appropriate contract making official or
officials of such municipality, and file such signed copy hereof with the Clerk
of Council of the City of Lyndhurst.
(Ord. 75-27. Passed 4-7-75; Ord. 80-23. Passed 3-3-80.)
 
   141.10  SPECIAL POLICE OFFICERS.
   A Special Police Unit, manned by Special Police Officers, is hereby created.
The eligibility qualifications of the members shall be as established by the
Civil Service Commission. Such Special Police Officers are hereby authorized to
preserve the peace, protect life, property and rights and enforce the laws of
the State and the City. Such authority contemplates that such Officers shall
bear arms and have authority to make arrests for the commission of
misdemeanors. The Director of Safety shall provide, by rules and regulations,
for duties and the type of uniform to be worn by Special Police Officers. 
(Ord. 78-30. Passed 5-15-78.)
 
   141.11  DISPOSING OF UNCLAIMED BICYCLES.
   The Chief of Police is hereby authorized and directed to contribute the
unclaimed bicycles listed in Exhibit A, which is attached to original Ordinance
2010-9 and fully incorporated herein, to Cops & Kids, Inc.  (Ord. 2010-9. 
Passed 2-15-10.)

   143.01  COMPOSITION.
   The composition of the Fire Department of the City shall not exceed:
   (a)   Chief; four Captains; a minimum of three Lieutenants, but not to
exceed three Lieutenants; and eighteen firefighters.
   (b)   A Captain will serve as Fire Prevention Officer and shall direct all
activities of the Fire Prevention Bureau in accordance with Section
1501.03 of these Codified Ordinances.
   (c)   In the event of the prolonged absence, unavailability or disability of
the Fire Chief, a Captain (designated by the Fire Chief) will serve as Acting
Fire Chief and, subject to prior approval of the Mayor, will be compensated
accordingly during that period.
      (Ord. 98-71. Passed 7-6-98; Ord. 2000-9.  Passed 2-7-00; Ord. 2002-68. 
Passed 8-5-02.)
 
   143.02  POWERS AND DUTIES OF CHIEF.
   The Chief of the Fire Department shall be the head of the Fire Department.
He or she shall preside at all meetings of the Fire Department, shall have
charge of and be responsible for proper maintenance of the apparatus of the
Fire Department and shall, with the consent and approval of the Mayor,
establish rules for the operation of the Department and the duties and conduct
of the members thereof. He or she shall have power to suspend any member of the
Fire Department for violation of rules, disobedience to orders of a superior
officer or disorderly conduct while on duty, but such suspension shall be
reported immediately to the Mayor, who shall take such action thereon as he or
she may see fit. All members of the Fire Department shall have all the powers
provided by the laws of the State for the protection of lives and property in
case of fire, and shall exercise the same in such manner as may be provided by
the rules of the Department and the orders of the Mayor, the Chief of the Fire
Department, the Captain and Lieutenants.
(Ord. 4356. Passed 1-7-52.)
 
   143.03  UNIFORM ALLOWANCE.
   Each full-time regular member of the Fire Department of the City shall
receive, in addition to all other compensation, an allowance for uniforms and
cleaning. The amount of such allowance shall be in accordance with the
provisions of the compensation ordinance of the City.
 
   143.04  EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICE.
   (a)   There is hereby established within the Fire Department of the City an
Emergency Medical Services (EMS) composed of emergency medical technician-
paramedic service and emergency ambulance service, as authorized, set forth and
described in Ohio R.C. Chapter 4765.
 
   (b)   The Mayor is hereby authorized and directed to provide for the
necessary training, qualification and appointment of adequate personnel so as
to ensure that not less than one paramedic is available for duty on each Fire
Department shift.
 
   (c)   All Department personnel, other than the Chief, who are certified as
paramedics shall receive additional compensation in an amount to be determined
annually by Council in the ordinance providing for compensation of Department
personnel.
 
   (d)   EMS shall be furnished in all cases of illness, injury and other
bodily harm.  Such EMS will be provided at the advanced life support level and
each ambulance shall be staffed with a minimum of one (1) basic EMT-A, and one
(1) paramedic.
 
   (e)   Every person receiving EMS from the City including but not limited to
basic life support service (BLS) and advanced life support service (ALS) shall
be charged a fee for each response at the most current rate that would be the
usual and customary fee as is determined by the Health Care Financing
Administration (HCFA) and the third party insurers including but not limited to
Medicare, Medicaid and other private, public and commercial insurance carriers.
 
   (f)   Billing and collection of said fees shall be conducted by a
professional billing agency selected by the City.  Said professional billing
agency shall have the power to accept insurance assignments.
 
   (g)   Council shall determine a procedure to identify uncollected accounts,
and such accounts shall be reviewed by the Finance Director and pursued in
accordance with the procedure. 
(Ord. 2005-30.  Passed 5-16-05.)
 
   143.05  AGE LIMIT FOR APPOINTMENT.
   (a)   In accordance with Ohio R.C. 124.42, the Mayor may appoint any
competent person who  is not over thirty-one (31) years of age to a full-time
position  in the Fire Department.
   (b)   The Mayor may appoint any competent person not over forty (40) years
of age to a full-time position in the  Fire Department provided he has prior
service as a firefighter  and qualifies as being a member of the Ohio Police
and Firemen's Disability and Pension Fund.  (Ord. 2015-48.  Passed 7-6-15.)

CROSS REFERENCES
      Administration of Zoning Code - see P. & Z.

   145.01  ESTABLISHMENT; COMPOSITION; HOUSING DIVISION.
   (a)   There is hereby established a Building Department, which shall consist
of a Building Commissioner (who may also be referred to as Chief Building
Official) and an Assistant Building Commissioner. The Building Commissioner
shall be the executive head of the Building Department, under the direction of
the Mayor, and may be either a full-time employee or a part-time employee of
the City or, at the option of the Mayor, be retained under contract with the
City.  He or she shall have such powers and perform such duties as are provided
by the City for the Building Inspector, the Plumbing Inspector, the Electrical
Inspector and the Sewer Inspector. The Assistant Building Commissioner shall
have the same powers and perform the same duties as the Building Commissioner,
subject, however, to the direction and control of the Building Commissioner.
   (b)   There is hereby established a Housing Division within the Building
Department. The Building Commissioner shall have direct control and supervision
of said Division under the direction and authority of the Mayor. The Housing
Division shall have employees as are necessary to carry out the duties
associated with the Housing Division, as those duties may be defined and set
forth by the Mayor and/or Council according to the laws of the City and the
State. The duties shall include the administration and enforcement of the
zoning and building laws of the City and the State as they relate to the
housing in the City. 
(Ord. 2013-59.  Passed 9-16-13.)
 
   145.02  COMMISSIONER AND ASSISTANT; CONFLICT OF INTEREST.
   Neither the Building Commissioner, while employed full time by the City, nor
the Assistant Building Commissioner shall, during the term of their offices, be
employed or engage, directly or indirectly, in any building business or enter
into any contract for building for others or for furnishing materials, plans or
specifications for others.
(Ord. 2013-59.  Passed 9-16-13.)
 
   145.03  COMPENSATION; BOND.
   The Building Commissioner and the Assistant Building Commissioner shall
receive such compensation for their services as Council may from time to time
determine and each shall, before entering upon the duties of his or her office,
give bond for the faithful performance of his or her duties in such sum and
with such surety as may from time to time be required by Council. The obligee
of the bond shall be the City and the bond shall be for the benefit of all
parties aggrieved by the acts or neglect of the principal.
(Ord. 3260.  Passed 6-19-39.)
 
   145.04  DUTIES; RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Building Commissioner shall examine all buildings in the course of
erection, alteration, repair or removal, throughout the City as often as
required to insure efficient supervision and shall be charged with the survey
and inspection of buildings and with the enforcement of this chapter and all
other laws and ordinances relating to the erection, construction, alteration,
repair, removal and safety of buildings, structures, elevators, heating
apparatus, gas fittings, house drainage and plumbing, steam boilers, electric
wiring, prevention of smoke, fire escapes and other fire protection devices. He
or she shall pass upon all questions relating to the strength and durability of
buildings and structures and the quality of materials and workmanship so far as
they affect safety, shall examine and approve all plans and specifications
therefor before a permit shall be issued and shall sign and issue all permits,
certificates and notices required to be issued. He or she shall promptly
acknowledge receipt of all official communications, notices and reports
pertaining to his or her Department.
   The Assistant Building Commissioner shall assist the Commissioner in the
performance of the above described duties, in such manner and to such extent as
the Commissioner may require.
   The Building Commissioner shall promulgate rules and regulations for the
efficient and proper administration of the programs desired by the Mayor and/or
Council or otherwise instituted under the Division of Housing according to the
laws of the City and the State.
(Ord. 3260.  Passed 6-19-39; Ord. 90-29.  Passed 5-7-90.)
 
   145.05  SECRETARY TO THE BUILDING COMMISSIONER.
   There is hereby created the position of Secretary to the Building
Commissioner, and such additional full or part-time secretaries as may be
designated by the Mayor.
 
   145.06  PETTY CASH FUND.
   The Director of Finance is hereby authorized and directed to disburse to the
Building Commissioner the sum of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) to be used by him
or her as a petty cash fund for the purpose of making change. The Building
Commissioner or an assistant thereof may be required to give an accounting of
such funds at all reasonable times as the Director of Finance may require.
(Ord. 4385. Passed 3-3-52.)
 
   145.07  REIMBURSEMENT FOR DRY CLEANING EXPENSES.
   The Building Commissioner and full-time Inspectors shall be reimbursed for
dry cleaning upon presentation of invoices for such dry cleaning in the amount
of ten dollars ($10.00) with a maximum amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00)
per person per year. 
(Ord. 97-37.  Passed 4-7-97.)

City Engineer
 
147.01   Position created; powers and duties.

   147.01  POSITION CREATED; POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (a)   There is hereby created the position of City Engineer. The duties for
said position are as set forth in this section.
 
   (b)   Compensation for this position shall be as set from time to time by
City Council resolution.
 
   (c)   The position of City Engineer established in division (a) of this
section shall be filled by appointment of the Mayor as provided for in the City
Charter.
 
   (d)   The duties of the City Engineer shall be as follows:
      (1)   Act as a technical consultant and advisor on engineering matters
referred to him or her by the Mayor, Council, and administrative departments
upon direction of the department heads;
      (2)   Advise the Service and Building Departments relating to residents'
problems pertaining to engineering as they may relate to public sewers, public
water supplies, drainage patterns, and building grades;
      (3)   Assist the Building Department on engineering matters, including 
attendance at Planning Commission meetings, as requested, and act as aide in
the administration of the National Flood Insurance Program;
      (4)   Attend all meetings as requested by the Mayor or Council;
      (5)   Prepare formative or preliminary sketches, layouts, estimates or
reports, concerning the advisability of proceeding with public improvements
such as wastewater collection and treatment, water mains, pavement improvements
or other infrastructure improvements contemplated by the Mayor and/or Council;
      (6)   Prepare applications for grant or funding programs pertaining to
public improvements requiring the services of the Municipal Engineer such as
Issue Two funding requests;
      (7)   Provide services necessary for the City's compliance with the EPA
NPDES Phase II Stormwater Permitting Program. This includes permit preparation,
updating the City's plan, monitoring, and annual report preparation;
      (8)   Perform such other duties as is normally required of Municipal
engineers not requiring the use of additional staff members such as field
crews, etc.
         (Ord. 2002-88.  Passed 12-2-02.)

(Res. 72-44. Passed 7-3-72.)
