RULES OF THE CIVIL SERVICE COMMISSION
 
   EDITOR'S NOTE:  The Rules of the Civil Service Commission were adopted by
the Commission by resolution on June 29, 1979.  Dates appearing in parentheses
following a section indicate that the section was enacted or amended on the
date given.
 
 
RULE I
ORGANIZATION AND ADMINISTRATION
 
 
   Section 1.  The officers of the Lyndhurst Civil Service Commission shall
consist of a Chairperson and a Vice-Chairperson, to be elected by a majority
vote of the Commission, each of whom shall hold office for a period of one
year, or until the election of a successor. Officers shall be elected at the
first regular meeting of the Commission in January of each year.
   The Chairperson shall preside at all meetings of the Commission and shall
sign all documents, papers, minutes, reports and records pertaining to the
affairs and business of the Commission. The Secretary shall attest to all
documents, papers, minutes, reports and records required herein to be signed by
the Chairperson. In the absence of the Chairperson, the Vice- Chairperson shall
perform the duties of the Chairperson.
 
   Section 2.  The Secretary of the Commission shall keep an official record in
the form of minutes of all the proceedings of the Commission and shall have
charge of the certification of eligibles, the checking and approval of payrolls
and the filing and preservation of all records, papers and other data belonging
to the Commission or its officers, and in addition shall do and perform all
such other duties as may from time to time be required by the Commission.
 
   Section 3.  The Director of Law shall be the counsel of the Commission and
as such shall be the legal adviser and attorney for the Commission and attend
to such other correlated matters as may from time to time be delegated to him
or her by the Commission.
 
   Section 4.  The regular meetings of the Commission shall be held at the City
Hall on the second Thursday of each month at 8:30 a.m., except that when such
day falls on a holiday, the meeting shall be held on the next day.
   Special meetings shall be held upon the call of the Chairperson or upon the
call of the other two members of the Commission, but unless all members are
present, all business transactions at a special meeting shall be confined to
the purpose specified in a written notice thereof to be given to the members at
least forty-eight hours, exclusive of weekends and holidays, prior to the
meeting, except in the event of an emergency requiring immediate official
action, in which case written notice thereof shall be given to the members
immediately upon the determination to hold such a meeting.
   A majority of the Commission shall constitute a quorum for the transaction
of business at any regular or special meeting of the Commission. Except as
otherwise provided, Robert's Rules of Order shall be followed in the conduct of
the meetings of the Commission.
(Amended by Res. 94-2.  Passed 11-10-94.)
 
   Section 5.  Notices of the date, time and agenda of special meetings and
committee meetings shall be communicated to the Secretary, in writing, at least
forty-eight hours, exclusive of weekends and holidays, in advance of such
meeting, to permit such Clerk to comply with the requirements of Ohio R.C.
122.22. In the event of an emergency requiring a meeting on less notice than is
provided in Ohio R.C. 121.22(F), notice shall be immediately given to the Clerk
or the Clerk's office so that immediate notice may be given to the news media
which have requested such notice.
   Persons desiring notices and agendas of meetings of the Civil Service
Commission or of a committee thereof, as provided in Ohio R.C. 121.22, shall
deposit self-addressed, stamped envelopes with the Clerk of Council for one
year or, if notice of only one meeting is desired, as follows:
   (1)   One dollar ($1.00) for the notice and agenda of any one meeting of
such body or committee hereinafter referred to;
   (2)   Five dollars ($5.00) for notices and agendas of meetings of each
committee of the Civil Service Commission and of the Commission itself for each
calendar year.
   If a regular meeting is not required because of the lack of public business,
a notice shall be posted to such effect at least five days prior to such
meeting on or in the vicinity of the bulletin board in the main lobby at the
Municipal Center. Notice of such lack of meeting shall be given by the Clerk of
Council to all news media that have requested notices or to the persons who
have made the deposits referred to above.
(Amended by Res. 91-7.  Passed 7-11-91.)
 
   Section 6.  At any meeting, the Commission may assign defined duties to any
member of the Commission. Any action thereunder, however, shall at all times be
reported to the full Commission and be subject to its approval, modification or
revocation. The acts of any Commissioner when in charge during the absence of
the others, or of the Secretary during the absence of the Commissioners, shall
be reported to the full Commission and shall be subject to its approval,
modification or revocation.
 
RULE II
CLASSIFICATION
 
   Section 1.  All offices and positions in the service of the City, whether
permanent, temporary or provisional, except those specifically exempted by Ohio
R.C. 124.11 and by
Article V, Section 5 , of the City Charter, or those which are exempted by the
rules of the Civil Service Commission made pursuant to law, shall be in the
classified service and subject to the rules of the Commission. Employees of the
Service Department and those designated "Volunteer Firefighters" are in the
unclassified service of the City.
 
   Section 2.  The classes of positions named and described in specifications
adopted by the Commission and with such amendments as may be made thereto under
these rules from time to time and as interpreted therein shall constitute the
"Classification Plan" for the classification of positions in the service of the
City.
 
   Section 3.  Every position in the service existing when these rules take
effect, or hereafter created, shall be classified under the Classification Plan
by allocation to its appropriate class, which allocation shall be made by the
Civil Service Commission. Whenever a position has been allocated to its
appropriate class in the manner aforesaid, the title of such class shall
forthwith become the title of such position and shall be used in the payroll
records, in requests to the Commission for the certification of eligibles and
in all similar administrative and employment processes and documents.
 
   Section 4.  Whenever a new position is established, or the duties of a
position are so changed that in effect the old position, as described by the
specifications of the class to which it was originally allocated, no longer
exists, but in its place there is created a position of a different class, the
appointing authority shall report such fact to the Commission and transmit a
full statement of the circumstances and description of the duties to the
Commission, which shall thereupon, after investigation of the actual proposed
duties, responsibilities and qualification requirements, classify or reclassify
the position, allocating it to its appropriate class in accordance with the
Classification Plan in effect.
   The Commission shall likewise, from time to time, on its own motion, make
investigation of all positions in the service and propose changes in
classification whenever the facts are considered to warrant such action.
Classification or reclassification in all such cases shall take effect
immediately upon approval by the Commission.
 
   Section 5.  When a position has been reclassified by the Commission by
reason of additional duties or responsibilities, or to correct original errors
in classification, the incumbent of the former position may be promoted or
appointed to the new position without examination upon request of the
appointing authority. It must be shown to the satisfaction of the Commission
that the person for whom such promotion or appointment is requested has fully
and capably performed the additional duties and assumed the responsibilities on
account of which the reclassification was allowed, and is fully qualified to
fill the position.
 
   Section 6.    The Commission may, whenever in its sole discretion
circumstances warrant, amend the specifications or characteristics for any
class and abolish, merge or divide existing classes or create new classes under
the Classification Plan.
 
   Section 7.   Specifications or characteristics of classes or positions in
the Classification Plan are hereby declared to have the following force, effect
and intendment:
   (a)   They are descriptive only and not restrictive. They are intended to
indicate the kinds of positions that should be classified under the respective
classes, as determined by their duties, responsibilities and qualification
requirements. Every factor essential to the proper performance of the duties of
the position shall be considered and weighed in assigning such position to its
proper class.
   (b)   In determining the class to which any position should be allocated,
the specifications or characteristics of each class shall be considered as a
whole. Consideration shall be given to the general duties, typical tasks,
responsibilities, desirable entrance qualifications and relationships to other
classes in determining the class into which a position shall be assigned.
   (c)   As to the particular parts of the determining factors of
specifications of classes, the following principles of interpretation shall
apply:
      (1)   The "duties statement" shall be construed as a general description
of the kind of work involved in a position that properly falls within the class
and not in any sense as designating what the duties of any position shall be,
nor as affecting or limiting the conceded power which the appointing authority
now has or may hereafter be vested with respecting the right to prescribe or
alter the duties of any position, provided, however, that where a substantial
change of duties is made, except for a temporary period or by the addition of
duties that are incidental to the main employment, such change shall be
reported to the Commission with a view to a possible reclassification of the
position.
      (2)   The "typical tasks" shall be construed as examples only,
illustrative of the duties as outlined by the duties statement. These examples
are not intended to be complete or exclusive and the fact that the actual tasks
performed in a position do not apply therein shall not be taken to mean that
the position is necessarily excluded from the class, provided that the tasks
constituting the main work or employment are covered by the general statement
of duties. On the other hand, any one example of a typical task, taken without
relation to the general statement of duties and all other parts of the
specifications, shall not be construed as determining that a position shall be
included within the class.
      (3)   The statement of "minimum entrance qualifications" constitutes a
part of the description or definition of the kind of employment by expressing
the minimum qualifications desirable in the case of any new appointee if he or
she is to perform the work properly, and it is to be so construed, and not as
imposing, in itself, any new or additional requirements for the filling of
positions. Although they may not be mentioned in the statement, such
qualifications as should be properly applied in common to all or many
positions, such as citizenship, sex, suitable age, honesty, sobriety and
industry, are taken for granted, subject to equal opportunity laws.
 
   Section 8.   For the purpose of assisting in its work in connection with the
classification or reclassification of positions, the Commission may require the
appearance before it of the appointing authority and the submission of
information and data to support the testimony of such appointing authority in
connection with the classification or reclassification issue then before the
Commission.
 
RULE III
APPLICATIONS
 
   Section 1.   Every applicant for admission to an examination for a position
in the classified service of the City must be a citizen of the United States,
and if he or she is an applicant for appointment to the safety forces of the
City, the applicant, upon appointment, must reside within the State of Ohio. It
shall be a requirement for appointment to, and continued employment on the
safety forces that said employee reside within the State of Ohio.  A
naturalized citizen must present his or her naturalization certification and
proof of residence location for inspection at the time of filing his or her
application, and a proper endorsement of such inspection shall be made upon the
application by the Secretary of the Commission.
   In addition to the aforesaid, an applicant for appointment to the Fire
Department of the City must possess a current State of Ohio certification as a
paramedic, and current FF1 and FF2 State of Ohio Fire Training Certificate as a
"State Certified Professional Firefighter", and provide evidence of such
certification prior to certification from the eligible list by the Commission. 
(Amended by Res. 2016-1.  Passed 6-24-16.)
 
   Section 2.   (EDITOR'S NOTE:  Section 2 was repealed by Res. 93-1, passed
February 24, 1993.)
 
   Section 3.   The application for an examination must be in writing upon
forms prescribed by the Civil Service Commission, signed by the applicant,
sworn to or affirmed before an officer authorized to administer oaths, and
accompanied with a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) in cash or money order
payable to the City of Lyndhurst.  The application must be filed by the
applicant in person at the office of the Secretary of the Commission during
office hours at least two days before the date of the examination.
(Amended by Res. 2018-3.  Passed 10-11-18.)
 
   Section 4.  An applicant for an examination for an original appointment as a
police officer must have reached his or her twenty-first birthday and as a
firefighter must have reached his or her eighteenth birthday on or before the
final date for filing of the application set by the Commission for the taking
of such examination. No applicant for the position of firefighter shall be
eligible for appointment to a position by the Mayor subsequent to the
applicant’s thirty-first birthday, except as provided in Section
143.05(b) of the Codified Ordinances of the City.  Appointments of police
officers and firefighters shall be in accordance with other requirements as set
forth in Ohio R.C. 124.41 and 124.42, respectively.
(Amended by Res. 2011-2.  Passed 7-14-11.)
 
   Section 5.  All other applicants for positions in the classified service
shall be of legal age unless otherwise specified by the Commission in its
notices of examination.
 
   Section 6.  No applicant shall be examined or certified as eligible, nor
appointed to any office in the public service, who is found to lack any of the
established preliminary requirements for the examination as fixed by the
Commission, or who is found to be physically or psychologically unfit for the
performance of the duties of the position he or she seeks, or who is addicted
to the use of intoxicating liquors, drugs or other illegal substances, or who
has been found guilty of any felony or crime involving crimen falsi or moral
turpitude, or of infamous or notoriously disgraceful conduct, or who has been
dismissed from any branch of public service for delinquency or misconduct, or
who has made false statements of any material fact, or who has practiced or
attempted to practice any deception or fraud in his or her application or in
his or her examination, or in establishing his or her eligibility, or in
securing his or her appointment.  (Amended by Res. 91-10.  Passed 7-11-91.)
 
   Section 7.  Every person applying for examination for eligibility to any
position, the duties of which require examination by and the certificate of any
Board of Examiners authorized by the laws of the State, shall present for
inspection by the Secretary of the Commission, at the time when he or she files
his or her application for examination, his or her certificate from such Board
of Examiners, or a duly certified copy thereof. Proper endorsement of such
inspection shall be made on the application by the Secretary.
 
   Section 8.  The Commission may, in its discretion, require an applicant to
furnish a sworn written statement of his or her experience qualifying him or
her for the position which he or she seeks.
 
   Section 9.  At the time of any examination, the Commission shall have the
power to require such other basic qualifications in the applicant for any
position under the classified service as the Commission deems necessary for the
efficient performance of the duties of the position for which the examination
is held and for the best interests of the civil service of the City and the
merit system generally.  To this end, all preliminary documents required of an
applicant, including but not limited to the physical agility certificate
evidencing successful completion of the physical agility test, shall be
submitted to the secretary prior to taking the written examination.
(Amended by Res. 2012-3.  Passed 12-13-12.)
 
 
RULE IV
EXAMINATIONS
 
   Section 1.  Examinations shall be of such a character and relate to such
matters as will fairly test the relative fitness of the persons examined to
discharge the duties of the positions to which they seek appointment.  The
passing grade for all civil service examinations in the City shall be seventy
percent (70%).  (Amended by Res. 2010-7.  Passed 10-14-10.)
 
   Section 2.  Whenever the Civil Service Commission decides that the good of
the service will be promoted thereby, it may hold an examination for any office
or position or combination of offices or positions in the classified service.
Adequate public notice of the time and place of every examination shall be
given. Such notice shall be posted in a conspicuous place in the Lyndhurst
Municipal Center for at least two weeks before any examination. Additional
notice of the examination shall be published in newspapers as required by
affirmative action programs. The notices shall contain such other information
relating to the scope and character of the examination, to the weights to be
given to the respective subjects, and to the qualifications of applicants, as
the Commission may deem proper.
 
   Section 3.  There shall be no fee or charge for filing an application form
for any promotional appointment position with the City.
(Amended by Res. 89-1.  Passed 4-27-89.)
 
   Section 4. Examinations shall be conducted under the supervision of the
Commission and, when necessary and advisable to do so, the Commission may
designate special examiners to assist in the conduct of an examination.
   Oral interviews by the Commission and/or the appointing authority may be
required of applicants for positions where personal qualifications are to be
determined.  The oral interviews may be conducted by the Civil Service
Commission as a whole or by members of the Civil Service Commission as
designated by the Chairperson of the Commission.  Additional interviews may be
conducted by the appointing authority and/or designees of the appointing
authority.
   After a job offer, the appointment of any candidate to a position in the
civil service of the City shall be subject to such candidate successfully
passing a complete physical and medical examination by a medical examiner
selected by the Commission establishing the fact that the appointee is
physically and medically capable of performing the essential functions of the
position he or she has been appointed to as provided by law.  The cost of such
medical examination shall be paid for by the Commission.  The results of the
examination shall be certified to the appointing authority and/or the
Commission on forms prescribed for that purpose.  The appointment of any
appointee who fails to pass such physical and medical examination as set forth
above shall be rescinded and shall therefore be null and void, and his or her
name shall be removed from the eligibility list.
   All candidates appointed to a position in the civil service of the City by
the appointing authority shall be required to undergo a complete psychological
examination by a qualified examiner selected by the Commission.  The cost of
such psychological examination shall be paid for by the Commission. The results
of the psychological examination shall be certified to the appointing authority
and/or the Commission upon forms prescribed for that purpose and acceptable to
the Commission.  If, as a result of such examination, it is recommended to the
appointing authority and/or the Commission that the applicant not be certified
for appointment, or if the results of the examination show that the candidate
failed to pass such examination because of the fact that the results of such
examination show that the appointee is unable to perform the essential
functions of the position, the appointment of such appointee shall be rescinded
and shall be null and void and his or her name shall be removed from the
eligibility list.  The appointee will be required to sign a voluntary release
to the Commission and its members and employees, and/or to the appointing
authority and its designees, whenever it is required that the applicant take a
physical ability/agility test, a medical examination and/or a psychological
examination.  Failure to sign such a release disqualifies the applicant from
further consideration. 
(Amended by Res. 93-2. Passed 2-24-93.)
 
   Section 5.  At the time of registering for a written examination, each
applicant shall be required to fill out and sign an identification and
declaration sheet containing his or her examination number (as shown on the
official envelope furnished him or her), his or her address and age, and such
other information as the Commission may require, and to seal the same in the
official envelope. All envelopes shall be placed in a sealed package and
deposited by the Secretary in a safe place. The package shall be opened for
identification of papers only after the grading has been completed on all
examination papers.
   All written examination papers submitted by applicants shall contain their
identification number, and, if required by the Commission, their thumbprint
only, and any examination papers bearing the name of an applicant or any
identification data or mark other than their identification number and, if
required, their thumbprint, shall be rejected. Specific announcement of this
rule shall be made at the commencement of each examination. 
(Amended by Res. 91-9. Passed 7-11-91.)
 
   Section 6.  Maintaining one's certification as a paramedic is a condition of
employment in the City for such period of time required to be necessary in the
best interests of the City and the safety of its residents by the Fire Chief.
 
   In an original appointment examination for the Fire Department, and upon
submission by an applicant to the Commission of written documentary evidence
acceptable to the Commission, five (5) additional points will be added to the
final points score of the applicant who has earned an Associates Degree in Fire
Science, Paramedicine or Emergency Management; or a Bachelors Degree in any
discipline. Two (2) additional points will be added to the final points score
of the applicant who has earned an Associates Degree in any discipline. No more
than five (5) additional points will be added to the final points score for all
educational achievement under this paragraph. Such credit or credits will only
be given to an applicant who has first received the established passing grade.
   In an original appointment examination for the Police Department, and upon
submission by an applicant to the Commission of documentary proof acceptable to
the Commission, ten (10) additional points will be added to the final points
score of the applicant qualifying for such an examination who has successfully
completed an Ohio Peace Officers Training Commission authorized basic police
school and has maintained his or her certification since graduation. Such
credit or credits will only be given to an applicant who has received the
established passing grade.
   In an original appointment examination for the Police Department, and upon
submission by an applicant to the Commission of documentary proof acceptable to
the Commission, five (5) additional points will be added to the final point
score of the applicant who has earned an Associates Degree or higher. Written
documentary evidence of the Degree acceptable to the Commission must be
submitted to the Commission by the Applicant, and the Degree must be conferred
by an institution accredited by the United States Department of Education or
accreditation agencies recognized by the United States Department of Education.
Such credit will only be given to an applicant who has first received the
established passing grade.
   In an original appointment examination for the Police Department, and upon
submission by an applicant to the Commission of documentary proof acceptable to
the Commission, five (5) additional points will be added to the final point
score of the applicant: (a) who has at least one continuous year of full-time
duty, and is (i) currently employed full-time as a Police Officer in Ohio, or
(ii) who is currently laid off as a Police Officer in Ohio for not more than a
year from the date of receipt of the application by the Commission; (b) who is
not currently under any disciplinary action; and, (c) who has first received
the established passing grade.
   In an original appointment examination for the Fire Department, and upon
submission by an applicant to the Commission of documentary proof acceptable to
the Commission, five (5) additional points will be added to the final point
score of the applicant: (a) who is (i) currently employed full-time as a
Firefighter in Ohio and has at least one continuous year of full-time duty, or
(ii) who is currently laid off as a Firefighter in Ohio for not more than a
year from the date of receipt of the application by the Commission; (b) who is
not currently under any disciplinary action; and, (c) who has first received
the established passing grade.
   In an original appointment examination for either the Fire Department or the
Police Department, any person who has served in the military service, as
described in Ohio R.C. 124.23, and who files with the Civil Service Commission
a Form DD-214 or evidence of an honorable discharge, shall receive five (5)
additional points which will be added to the final point score of the
applicant. Such credit will only be given to an applicant who has first
received the established passing grade. No military credit shall be given for
any promotional examination.
   In an original appointment examination for the Police Department, and upon
submission to the Commission by the Chief of Police of the City a written
certification that such applicant is a special police officer in the City, and
has satisfactorily been such for at least one (1) year immediately previous,
five additional points will be added to the final point score of the applicant
qualifying for such examination. Such points will only be given to an applicant
who has first received the established passing grade.
(Res. 2018-1.  Passed 2-8-18.)
 
   Section 7.  When it is determined by the Commission that the total final
grade in the examination for any position shall be comprised of more than one
test, the Commission may require an applicant to attain a specified percentage
rating or raw grade in each test as a condition to being permitted to
participate in succeeding tests.
   Physical ability and agility shall be determined by physical tests approved
by the Commission prior to such tests and shall be standardized in such manner
that the same may be credited and recorded in writing. Appropriate comment
shall be added to such athletic and physical ability grading as may aid the
Commission or its reviewing authority. 
(Amended by Res. 2005-7.  Passed 7-21-05.)
 
   Section 8.  (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section 8 was repealed by Resolution 2005-8,
passed July 21, 2005.)
 
   Section 9.  If an applicant changes his or her address (from the address
shown on his or her application) he or she shall immediately notify the
Commission in writing of such change.  Notices pursuant to this section will be
sent to the address on the application unless change of address notification is
received by the Commission.
(Amended by Res. 93-2.  Passed 2-24-93.)
 
   Section 10.  All examination papers, with the grades marked thereon by the
examiners, shall be carefully preserved in the office of the Commission for at
least the life of the eligible list thereby established or augmented. The
Commission may, at any time within thirty days after the completion of the
examination and notification to an applicant of his or her average, correct any
obvious error in the grading of an examination paper or computation of the
grade.
 
   Section 11.  Any examination may be postponed or canceled by order of the
Commission for good and sufficient reason, and such postponement and
cancellation shall be minuted in the records of the Commission, together with
the reason therefor.
 
   Section 12.  When an applicant in any test is found to be using, without
permission of the Commission, any extraneous means of information, such as
memorandum, pamphlets or books of any kind, to assist him or her in answering
questions, the Commissioner or his or her representative present at the test
shall take from the applicant any such memoranda or information, shall take up
the test paper and dismiss the applicant from the examination. The Commission
in such instance shall give the test paper a grade of zero and place thereon a
notation explaining such marking. Such applicant shall be barred thereafter
from any examination held by the City for any position.
 
   Section 13.  Noncompetitive examinations may be held for such positions as
in the sole discretion of the Commission require peculiar and exceptional
qualifications of a scientific, managerial, professional or educational
character. Competitive examinations may be ordered for any position previously
filled by noncompetitive examinations. Noncompetitive examinations shall be of
such character as will determine whether or not the applicant possesses the
requisite knowledge, ability and physical qualifications to enable him or her
to perform the duties of the position. An applicant for such an examination
shall be required to achieve a qualifying rating to be fixed by the Commission
prior to the examination in order to become eligible for the position which he
or she seeks.
 
   Section 14.  Special police personnel are hereby designated members of the
classified service who shall not require a competitive examination for
appointment but whose appointment shall be made as set forth below:
   (a)   For personnel to be considered for this position, the Safety Director
(appointing authority) must submit a letter of recommendation to the
Commission, accompanied by a completed application for the position and a
letter of recommendation from the Chief of Police.
   (b)   Upon receipt of the above mentioned letters and application, the
Commission shall implement the following procedures, qualifications and
requirements:
      (1)   Candidate must be at least twenty-one years of age at time of
application and must be a certified Ohio law enforcement officer.
      (2)   A background check and polygraph exam or any other type of truth
verification exam, as approved by the Commission will be administered by an
agency approved by the Commission.  After a review of these reports, the
Commission will certify to the Safety Director that said candidate qualifies
for a conditional offer of employment or does not.
      (3)   If he/she qualifies, the candidate will be interviewed by the
Safety Director and Chief of Police, and a conditional offer of employment will
be made subject to the following:
         A.   Candidate must pass a physical examination including a drug
screen test by a physician or facility selected by the Commission;
         B.   Candidate must pass a psychological examination by a psychologist
selected by the Commission;
         C.   Candidate must be found to be in compliance with all of the
requirements found in Rule III entitled Applications prior to final
certification.
   (c)   Upon satisfactory completion by the candidate of all of the
requirements stated above, the Commission will give a final certification to
the Safety Director for probationary appointment.  Special police officers
shall serve at the pleasure of the Chief of Police or the Safety Director.
   (d)   Candidates must cooperate with the Commission in submitting the
required exhibits and with the testing agencies so that there are no
unnecessary delays in the application process.  The personal history form shall
be returned to the Commission Secretary within seven days of receipt, or the
application will be withdrawn by the Commission.  Consideration will be given
for special circumstances.  In the event that a candidate does not cooperate
with the application process in an expeditious manner, the Commission may, in
its discretion, remove the candidate’s application from consideration for the
position of special police officer with a letter so indicating to the candidate
with a copy to the Safety Director and to the Chief of Police.
   (e)   The City will bear the cost of application process, including all
testing and examinations.  (Amended by Res. 2008-1.  Passed 1-10-08.)
 
   Section 15. Credit for experience gained during an emergency or temporary
appointment shall not be given to an applicant in any examination.
 
   Section 16.
   (a)   The position of Animal Warden is hereby designated as part of the
classified service of the City.  This Commission, pursuant to the authority
vested in the Commission by the Charter of the City, hereby determines that it
is impracticable to conduct competitive examinations for such position for the
reason that the position does not require particular skills, training, or
education, therefore making it impracticable to establish a competitive test
for such position.
 
   (b)   When a vacancy occurs, or is about to occur, in such position, the
appointing authority shall notify the Civil Service Commission of such
vacancy.  Applications shall then be accepted for such position.  If no
applications are received as a result of such posting, the Civil Service
Commission may authorize advertisement for such position outside of the current
City workforce.  Upon receipt of any such applications, such applicant shall be
certified to the appointing authority to conduct interviews as determined to be
necessary by the appointing authority.  The appointing authority may then make
a conditional offer of employment to one of such applicants.
 
   (c)   After receiving a conditional offer of employment, such applicant will
then be required to undergo a physical and psychological examination and final
appointment will be subject to the results thereof.
 
   (d)   Upon completion of the requirements stated above, such candidate may
receive probationary appointment by the appointing authority and such
appointment shall be certified as having been made to the Civil Service
Commission by the appointing authority.
 
   (e)   At a minimum, all applicants must either be currently holding the
position of Special Police Officer or be an individual that holds a current
certification as a law enforcement officer.
(Amended by Res. 2001-1.  Passed 3-26-01.)
 
RULE V
ELIGIBLE LISTS
 
   Section 1.  The Civil Service Commission, as soon as an eligible list is
established, shall post such list for public inspection. The list shall
designate all applicants who have passed the examination and who are thus
eligible for appointment to the position or class of positions for which the
examination was held.
   All applicants who receive a passing grade in each test, as established by
the Commission prior to the examination, shall be placed on the eligible list
in the order of their standing, as determined in
Section 8 of Rule IV, including their military and education credits, if any,
together with the date they are entered on the list and the date of their
examinations.
   Whenever two or more applicants competing for the same position or positions
have like averages, their respective priorities on the eligible list shall be
the same as the order in which their applications were filed, and a notation
shall be made upon the list of such fact.
 
   Section 2.   The Commission, at any time when in its sole discretion the
interest of the service so requires, may hold an examination for eligibles in
any class or grade of the classified service and may consolidate two or more
eligible lists of the same kind by rearranging all eligibles named therein
according to their standings.
 
   Section 3.   When, for any reason, the Commission holds an examination for
eligibles in any particular class or grade and there is an existing list of
eligibles for such class or grade, any eligible on such existing list may take
the new examination, but by so doing he or she shall thereby become removed
from such existing list and shall be bound by the results of the new
examination.
 
   Section 4.   An applicant taking more than one examination for a position in
the classified service may stand upon all eligible lists for which he or she
has qualified under the rules of the Commission. Upon appointment of such
eligible to any position in the classified service and his or her acceptance
thereof, he or she shall be removed from all eligible lists except those lists
of a superior class or grade.
 
   Section 5.   An eligible list shall remain in effect for a period of one
year from the date of the creation of such list unless, in the judgment of the
Commission, it is considered advisable, there having been no subsequent
examination, that the names of all those whose eligibility is about to expire
shall be continued on the list for a further period of one year or less. In
such event, the action of the Commission shall be recorded in its minutes
together with the reasons therefor.
   An eligible list may be further extended for a second one-year period or
less, if deemed necessary by the Commission. Such extension shall be shown in,
or by the Commission minutes.  (Amended by Res. 2010-8.  Passed 10-14-10.)
 
   Section 6.   If, at any time, the Commission has reason to believe that any
eligible upon any list has become disqualified in any manner for the position
for which he or she is listed, it shall give notice thereof to such eligible
and an opportunity to be heard in his or her own behalf. If he or she fails to
appear, or if, on any such hearing, he or she fails to satisfy the Commission
that he or she is still duly qualified, he or she shall be removed from such
eligible list forthwith.
 
   Section 7.   Each eligible shall file with the Commission a written notice
of any change of his or her address, which notation shall state his or her
name, the eligible list on which it appears, his or her new address and his or
her last address as registered with the Commission. 
(Amended by Res. 91-8. Passed 7-11-91.)
 
 
RULE VI
REQUISITION, CERTIFICATION AND APPOINTMENT
 
   Section 1.   When any position in the classified service is to be filled,
the appointing authority shall notify the Civil Service Commission of such fact
in writing.  The Commission shall then, prior to certification of any names,
order a background check and polygraph exam or any other type of truth
verification exam, as approved by the Commission, to be administered by an
agency approved by the Commission, for the six to ten persons standing highest
on the appropriate eligible list.  Upon receipt and review of the results of
the background checks and polygraph exams, the Commission shall determine which
applicants, up to this point in the selection process, meet the qualifications
for the position.  Should any applicant fail to meet said qualifications, the
Commission shall then notify the applicant accordingly and offer the
opportunity of a hearing with the Commission, after which the Commission shall
notify the applicant of its final decision to certify his or her name to the
appointing authority or to remove his or her name from the eligible list.  This
process shall continue until the Commission has at least six but not more than
ten qualified applicants standing highest on the appropriate eligible list, at
which time it shall certify the names, addresses and grades of said qualified
applicants to the appointing authority.  The appointing authority shall
thereupon conditionally appoint to such position one of the eligibles who are
so certified.  The appointing authority may conduct oral interviews as provided
for in Rule IV, Section 4, of these Rules and may review the results of any
background check performed, or polygraph examination, psychological or medical
test given to such eligibles.  Should the appointing authority desire to
conduct oral interviews prior to appointment, the appointing authority, or
designee, shall contact the eligibles at the address or telephone number on the
application to arrange such interview, unless a change of address or telephone
number has been provided to the Commission in writing.  If such eligible does
not respond to such contact within seven days, he or she shall be removed from
such certified list.
   When there is no eligible list for a position, or when such list has become
exhausted, eligibles from the list most nearly appropriate to the position may
be certified.  An eligible certified more than three times for the same or a
similar position may be omitted from future certifications and removed from
such eligible list, except that certification for a temporary appointment shall
not be counted as one of such certifications.
(Amended by Res. 2008-2.  Passed 1-10-08.)
   Section 2.   If there is more than one vacancy to be filled, the maximum
number of names to be certified shall be determined in the following manner: 
for two vacancies, the Commission shall certify not less than ten names nor
more than twelve names.  For each vacancy thereafter, the Commission shall
certify not less than two nor more than four additional names to the appointing
authority.
(Amended by Res. 2006-2.  Passed 2-9-06.)
 
   Section 3.   If an appropriate eligible list contains fewer than six names,
the names remaining on such list may be certified to the appointing authority
by the Commission, and the appointing authority may appoint from this
certification if he or she so desires. He or she may, however, demand a
complete list of six names.
(Amended by Res. 91-2. Passed 7-11-91; Res. 98-1.  Passed 2-19-98; Res. 2002-
2.  Passed 8-8-02; Res. 2002-2A.  Passed 9-11-02.)
 
   Section 4.   Notification by the appointing authority of vacancies shall be
made in the manner required by the Commission, and as a minimum shall state the
title, character and duties of the position, whether the position is temporary
or permanent and the compensation to be paid.
   Unless specified in the notice, or otherwise required, sex shall be
disregarded in the certification.
 
   Section 5.  The person selected for appointment shall be duly notified by
the appointing authority, and if such person fails to report to the appointing
authority within three days from the date of such notice, such person may be
considered as declining the appointment, and his or her name may be stricken
from the eligible list. Another eligible may be appointed then and notified to
report. The name of the declining eligible may be restored to the list upon
good cause being shown to the satisfaction of the Commission.
 
   Section 6.  The appointing authority shall, immediately upon acceptance of
an appointment by an eligible, report to the Commission the name of the person
so appointed and accepting. The names of those certified and not appointed
shall thereupon be restored to their positions on the eligible list.
 
   Section 7.  The person selected for the position shall be appointed for a
probationary period of one year and if the conduct, capacity and fitness of the
probationer are satisfactory to the appointing authority, the retention of such
person in the service after the end of such term shall be equivalent to a
permanent appointment, or, if the conduct, capacity or fitness is
unsatisfactory, he or she may be discharged by the appointing authority at any
time during such term, and notice of either such action shall be given to the
Commission forthwith.
 
   Section 8.  No name shall be certified more than four times to the same
appointing authority for the same or a similar position, except upon the
written request of such authority. (See
Section 1 of this Rule, above.)
 
   Section 9.  Eligibles on any list may waive certification before, but not
after, being certified, upon giving reasons in writing satisfactory to the
Commission. If the reasons assigned are not approved by the Commission, an
eligible may be removed from the list. Within thirty days thereafter, an
eligible so removed may be restored to the list, provided that satisfactory
reasons for such action are presented to and approved by the Commission.
   An eligible so filing a waiver shall not be entitled to certification as
long as his or her waiver remains on file and is not withdrawn, but no waiver
shall be permitted for a longer period than one year, after which time, if the
waiver is not withdrawn, the eligible shall be removed from the list. A second
waiver to the same list shall not be allowed.
 
RULE VII
TEMPORARY AND EMERGENCY APPOINTMENTS
 
   Section 1.  Upon receipt of a request for certification for a position for
which no appropriate eligible list is available, the Commission shall notify
the appointing authority that nomination for a temporary appointment may be
made to fill such position until an eligible list can be created, or for a
period not to exceed ninety days.
 
   Section 2.  Emergency appointments may be made by the appointing authority
when the good of the service, the welfare of the public and the necessities of
the City's operation make it necessary to do so in the judgment of the
appointing authority.  Written notice, however, must be given forthwith to the
Commission, together with the reasons for making such emergency appointments,
and such reasons must be sufficient and satisfactory to the Commission.  The
emergency appointment shall not be effective for a period longer than ninety
days or until an eligible list can be certified.  In any event, however,
interim or temporary appointments, made necessary by reason of the exhaustion
of one's appeal rights relative to disciplinary action, or by reason of
sickness, disability or other approved leave of absence, may be made, but shall
continue only during such period of the exhaustion of one's appeal rights
relative to disciplinary action, or during such sickness, disability or other
approved leave of absence, subject to approval of the same by the Commission. 
Any eligibility list for promotional appointment which is in existence at the
beginning of any such period shall be extended until the termination of said
period, unless, in the judgment of the Commission, it is impractical to do so,
or the good of the Service, the welfare of the public or the necessities of the
City will not be served thereby.
(Amended by Res. 96-2.  Passed 10-17-96.)
 
RULE VIII
PROMOTIONS
 
   Section 1.  Vacancies shall be filled by promotion whenever practical. An
advancement in rank or an increase in salary beyond the limit prescribed for
the grade shall constitute a promotion.
 
   Section 2.  Whenever there is a vacancy in a position in any department
above the lowest grade, the Civil Service Commission shall ascertain whether or
not there are at least two employees who have served one year or more in the
next lower grade or grades and at least three years in the department of which
they are members as of the final date of filing of the application, who are
eligible and willing to compete to fill such vacancy. If it is found that there
are at least two employees, the vacancy shall be filled from an eligible list
established by a competitive examination for promotion of such employees. 
(Amended by Res. 80-1.  Passed 5-22-80.)
 
   Section 3.  Whenever there are fewer than two persons holding a position in
the grade or rank next lower than the position to be filled, which person is
eligible and willing to compete, the Commission shall allow the persons holding
positions in the then next lower grade or rank, i.e. two grades or ranks lower
than the grade or rank in which the vacancy exists, and who are eligible and
willing, to compete with the person holding a position in the grade or rank
lower than the position to be filled, or if there is no person holding a
position in such grade or rank, then to compete with each other for the
vacancy.
 
   Section 4.  Notice of all promotional examinations shall be posted by the
Secretary in a conspicuous place in the Lyndhurst Municipal Center not less
than two weeks before the date fixed for the examination. Such notice shall
give the date and the character of the examination and shall indicate the grade
or rank of persons eligible to compete. Applicants for promotion shall file
their application as the Commission has prescribed in its notice at least four
days before the date fixed for the examination.
 
   Section 5.  (EDITOR'S NOTE:  Section 5 was repealed by Resolution 69-12,
passed July 20, 1989.)
 
   Section 6.  Applicants for promotion shall be examined on such practical and
theoretical questions as, in the judgment of the Commission, pertain to the
office or rank to which promotion is sought. They may also be examined on State
laws and City ordinances, rules and regulations pertaining to the duties of the
office or rank to which promotion is sought, and on such other subjects or
tests which the Commission may prescribe. An application may not be accepted
while charges are pending against an applicant, at the discretion of the
Commission, and any conviction on charges will be considered by the Commission
according to the gravity of the offense.  (Amended by Res. 2017-1.  Passed 12-
14-17.)
 
   Section 7.  In promotional examinations for all positions including Chief,
seniority in the service shall form a part of the maximum grade obtainable in
the examination.
   Credit given for seniority shall be for completion of full years only with a
full year being not less than 365 days from the date of original appointment to
the date of filing an application for promotion.  Credit for seniority shall be
given as follows:  one point shall be added for each of the first four years of
service and six-tenths of a point shall be added for each year for the next ten
years of service.
   No credit for seniority or education shall be added to an examination grade
unless the applicant achieves at least the minimum passing score established
for the examination without counting such extra credit.
(Amended by Res. 94-1.  Passed 4-14-94; Res. 95-1.  Passed 12-14-95.)
   In a promotional examination for the Fire Department, and upon submission by
an applicant to the Commission of written documentary evidence acceptable to
the Commission, additional points will be added to the final point score of any
applicant who has passed such examination, and who has successfully completed
the listed curricula from institutions accredited by the United States
Department of Education or accrediation agencies recognized by the United
States Department of Education as follows:
Firefighter/Paramedic to Lieutenant:
- certification as a fire safety inspector, one point will be added to the
final point score.
- certification as a fire service instructor, one point will be added to the
final point score.
- associate degree or higher in fire science, three points will be added to the
final point score.
Lieutenant to Captain: 
- certification as an executive fire officer from either the Ohio Fire Chiefs
Association or the National Fire Academy, three points will be added to the
final point score.
- bachelor's degree or higher, two points will be added to the final point
score.
Captain to Chief: 
- certification as an executive fire officer from either the Ohio Fire Chiefs
Association or the National Fire Academy, three points will be added to the
final point score.
- bachelor's degree or higher in a major related to public sector
administration or public safety, two points will be added to the final point
score.
(Amended by Res. 2010-3.  Passed 7-15-10; Res. 2010-6.  Passed 9-6-10; Res
2011-01.  Passed 10-13-11.)
 
   Section 8.  After the examination scores have been certified, following
grading, any appeal thereon (which appeal must be filed within ten (10)
consecutive calendar days after such certification) and the adding of seniority
credit thereto, the Civil Service Commission shall certify the eligibility list
for promotion and shall certify to the appointing authority the name of the
applicant listed at the top of the eligibility list for promotion.
   Such eligible applicant shall be appointed by the appointing authority
within the time prescribed by law.  If there is no time for appointment
prescribed by law, then such appointment shall be made within thirty days after
certification of the name to the appointing authority. 
(Amended by Res. 2018-2.  Passed 4-12-18.)
 
   Section 9.  Examinations of applicants for promotion shall be generally
conducted in accordance with the rules of the Commission governing examinations
for original appointments, provided, however, that no extra credit shall be
given for military service or education, as provided in
 Section 6 of Rule IV.
 
RULE IX
TRANSFERS, LAYOFFS AND REINSTATEMENTS
 
   Section 1.  The transfer of a police officer to the position of firefighter
heretofore made and approved by the Director of Safety, the Chiefs of the
Departments of Police and Fire, and the Civil Service Commission, and ratified
by rule and regulation under Rule VII, Section 3, of the Rules of the Civil
Service Commission of the City (repealed by Resolution 66-3, passed November
18, 1966), permitting transfers of personnel of the permanent rank of police
officer or firefighter between the Police Department and Fire Department upon
application of a permanent police officer or firefighter, is hereby adopted,
approved, confirmed and ratified. Salaries received by the former police
officer who is now a member of the Fire Department, as a member of such Fire
Department, pursuant to the rule of ratification of such appointment by the
Civil Service Commission, are hereby determined to be legal payments, but in
the event that any question exists regarding the legality of such payments,
such member is deemed morally entitled to the compensation received by him or
her for valuable services received by the City during such period. Similar
future transfers are not permitted.
 
   Section 2.  A transfer of an employee from a position in one class to a
position in another class, with a higher rate of compensation, or with
different or more responsible duties, shall be regarded as a promotion, and
shall be subject to the rules of this Commission governing promotions.
 
   Section 3.  Whenever it becomes necessary to lay off employees in the
classified service for any reason, those persons who have been appointed last
shall be first to be laid off from the service. The names of such persons so
laid off shall be returned to their proper positions on the appropriate
eligible list for recertification and reappointment when the conditions
necessitating the layoff have been removed.
 
   Section 4.  A layoff list shall be established by the Commission and kept by
the Secretary and the employees whose names appear on such list shall be the
first to be selected to refill the position which were the subject of the
layoff and which were held by the persons so laid off.
 
   Section 5.  Any person holding an office or position in the classified
service who resigns therefrom without delinquency or misconduct on his or her
part may be reinstated, upon the request of the appointing authority, with the
consent of the Commission, to a vacancy in the same or similar office or
position in the same department, provided a written application for
reinstatement is filed within one year from the date of resignation. However,
any member of the Fire Department or Police Department who resigns may be
reinstated to the rank of firefighter or police officer, as the case may be,
upon passing a physical examination showing physical fitness to perform the
duties of the office of firefighter or police officer, and upon reinstatement
such firefighter or police officer shall not receive credit for seniority
earned prior to resignation and reinstatement and shall not be entitled to
reinstatement to a position above the rank of firefighter or police officer, as
the case may be, regardless of the position held at the time of resignation.
 
RULE X
LEAVES OF ABSENCE
 
   Section 1.  Leaves of Absence without pay may be granted by the appointing
authority for a period not exceeding thirty days without the consent of the
Civil Service Commission.  Leaves of Absence without pay for a period longer
than thirty days, but not exceeding six months, may be granted by the
appointing authority with the consent and approve of the Commission.  Written
notice of all leaves of absence granted, stating the commencement and period
thereof, and the reason for such leave, shall be given forthwith to the
Commission.  No request for a leave of absence shall be considered by the Civil
Service Commission until all vacation time and personal time has first been
exhausted. 
   Section 2.  Absence from duty without leave for any time will be considered
good cause for dismissal. Absence from duty without leave for ten consecutive
days shall be deemed a resignation from the service by the absentee upon report
of such absence by the appointing authority. In such case, the resignation
shall be entered upon the records of the Commission. However, if at any time
within thirty days the person so absenting himself or herself makes
satisfactory explanation to the Commission of the cause of his or her absence,
he or she may be reinstated to his or her position. Failure to report after the
leave has expired or has been disapproved, revoked or cancelled by the
Commission, shall be cause for discharge, provided, however, that if an officer
or employee so discharged shows to the satisfaction of the Commission that such
failure to report was excusable, the Commission may then order his or her
reinstatement.
(Amended by Res. 2015-01.  Passed 7-9-15.)
 
RULE XI
REDUCTIONS, SUSPENSIONS AND REMOVALS
 
   Section 1.  The tenure of every employee in the classified service shall be
during good behavior and efficient service, and no such employee shall be
reduced in pay or position, laid off, suspended, discharged or otherwise
disciplined by the appointing authority except as hereinafter provided.
 
   Section 2.  When an employee becomes physically incapacitated for the
performance of the duties of any position, the appointing authority may, at the
request of such employee and with the consent of the Commission, transfer him
or her to a vacant position in a lower grade which he or she has the ability to
fill.
 
   Section 3.  No employee shall be reduced in pay or position, laid off,
suspended, discharged or otherwise discriminated against by an appointing
authority for religious or political reasons or affiliations. For the purpose
of discipline, the appointing authority may suspend, without pay, an employee
for a reasonable period, not to exceed thirty days, provided, however, that
successive suspensions shall not be allowed. Written report of any such
suspension, the period thereof and the reasons therefor, shall be filed with
the Commission forthwith by the appointing authority.
   No reduction, layoff or suspension for a period longer than thirty days, nor
any discharge of an employee by the appointing authority, shall become
effective unless and until the appointing authority has:
   (a)    Served upon the employee a written order for the particular action
taken, which order shall specify one or more grounds or reasons set forth in
 Section 4 of this Rule and shall contain a sufficient statement of facts to
enable the employee to understand the charge and to make an explanation or to
prepare his or her defense;
   (b)    Given the employee at least one week in which to make and file a
written explanation with the appointing authority; and
   (c)    Filed a copy of such order together with the explanation, if any, of
the employee, with the Commission.
   The Commission shall thereupon conduct a hearing following the filing of the
order and the explanation to determine the sufficiency or the cause of the
order. The provisions of this section, however, shall not apply to temporary or
emergency appointments made by the appointing authority as provided in these
Rules.
 
   Section 4.  An employee may be reduced in pay or position, laid off,
suspended, discharged or otherwise disciplined by the appointing authority for
incompetency, inefficiency, dishonesty, drunkenness, drug abuse or abuse of
illegal substances, immoral conduct, insubordination, discourteous treatment of
the public, neglect of duty, violation of the applicable provisions of the
Civil Service law of the State, violation of the rules and regulations of the
Commission, violation of departmental or divisional rules and regulations, for
any other failure of good behavior or for any other act of misfeasance,
malfeasance or nonfeasance in office.
(Amended by Res. 91-4. Passed 7-11-91.)
 
   Section 5.  Any employee in the classified service who is so reduced, laid
off, suspended for a period longer than thirty days, discharged or otherwise
disciplined by the appointing authority, may appeal to the Commission within
ten days from and after the receipt of notice of such reduction, layoff,
suspension for a period longer than thirty days, discharge or other discipline
by the appointing authority. The appeal shall be made by filing with the
Commission a written statement or notice that the employee appeals from such
order, and the notice shall describe or identify clearly the order. In such
event, the Commission shall forthwith notify the appointing authority and shall
hear the appeal within thirty days from and after its filing with the
Commission, giving to the appellant and to the appointing authority not less
than five days written notice of the time and place thereof.
 
   Section 6.  On the hearing of an appeal, the Commission shall consider the
charges and specifications set forth in the order of the appointing authority
as filed with the Commission, and in reaching its decision shall also take into
consideration the record and history of the appellant as set forth in the
records and files of the Commission. No substantial amendment of, or addition
to, such charges and specifications will be permitted or considered by the
Commission, and the order of the procedure shall be as follows:
   (a)    The appointing authority shall briefly state the grounds and facts
alleged to sustain the order.
   (b)    The appellant shall briefly state his or her explanation or defense.
   (c)    The appointing authority shall present the evidence in support of the
order.
   (d)    The appellant shall present the evidence in support of his or her
explanation.
   (e)    The appointing authority shall present any rebuttal evidence.
   (f)    Argument will be permitted only when desired by the Commission.
   The admission and exclusion of evidence and the determination of the appeal
shall be governed in general by the rules of evidence and burden of proof
applied by the courts in civil cases. Either party may personally represent
himself or herself or be represented by counsel.
   The Commission shall, after due consideration, render its judgment,
affirming, disaffirming or modifying the order which was the subject of the
appeal. If the judgment is one of disaffirmance or modification, the appellant
shall be reinstated under such conditions as the Commission may make in
connection therewith.
 
   Section 7.  If the appellant fails to appear at the time and place fixed by
the Commission to prosecute the appeal, the appeal shall be dismissed by the
Commission. If the appointing authority fails to appear at such time and place
and to offer evidence in support of his or her charges and specifications, the
Commission may hear evidence offered by the appellant and render its decision
on the merits.
 
   Section 8.  The acceptance by the appointing authority of the resignation of
any such appellant before final action on the appeal by the Commission will be
considered as a withdrawal of the charges, and thereupon the appeal shall be
dismissed without decision, except that the facts pertaining to such
resignation and the disposition of such appeal shall be set forth and entered
upon the records of the Commission.
 
RULE XII
WAIVER OF RULES
 
   Section 1.  In specific cases where, in the sole discretion of the Civil
Service Commission, it is in the interest of the public service, any of the
rules hereby adopted may be waived by a majority vote of the Commission,
provided, however, that such waiver shall not be inconsistent with the
provisions of the Civil Service law of the State. Such action, together with
the reasons therefor, may be waived by the unanimous vote of the Commission.
Such action, together with the reasons therefor, shall be entered in the
minutes of the Commission. In the interest of justice to all concerned and to
promote the welfare of the civil service in the City, a wide degree of
liberality of construction and interpretation of these rules and regulations in
any and all circumstances and situations shall be the policy to be adopted and
followed by the Commission in its administration of the merit system.
 
RULE XIII
EFFICIENCY RECORDS (REPEALED)
 
   Section 1.  EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Rule XIII was deleted from the Codified
Ordinances by Resolution 2010-1, passed April 8, 2010.
 
RULE XIV
PRESENT EMPLOYEES
 
   Section 1.  Each and every person now occupying a position or office in the
classified service of the City for at least one year prior to the date of the
adoption of the original Rules of the Civil Service Commission in 1951, is
hereby, in accordance with the spirit and intent of
 Article V, Section 5 , of the City Charter, automatically inducted into the
civil service system of the City without the necessity of an examination, but
such positions and offices are hereby declared to be hereafter under the
control and supervision of the Civil Service Commission under these Rules.
 
RULE XV
AMENDMENTS
 
   Section 1.     The Civil Service Commission, in its discretion, may change,
amend, revoke or modify these Rules or any Rule herein, or any part thereof, by
a majority vote of the Commission.  One week of notice of such proposed change,
together with the text of the proposal, shall be posted on the bulletin board
in the City Hall.
 
RULE XVI
SAVING CLAUSE
 
   Section 1.  If any Rule, part of a Rule, section or part of a section of
these Rules is held to be invalid or unconstitutional by any court for any
reason, the same shall not invalidate or impair the validity, force or effect
of any other Rule, part of a Rule, section or part of a section of these Rules
unless it clearly appears that such other Rule, part of a Rule, section or part
of a section is wholly or necessarily dependent for its operation on the Rule,
part of a Rule, section or part of a section so held invalid or
unconstitutional.
 
RULE XVII
MANDATORY RETIREMENT
 
   Section 1.  Pursuant to Section
159.16 of the Codified Ordinances, the mandatory retirement age of all
personnel in the safety forces, except the Chiefs thereof, and in the
competitive classified service, subject to civil service regulations, shall be
sixty-five years of age.  Each and every member shall terminate his or her
service at the end of the month during which he or she attains such age. In the
case of the Police Chief and the Fire Chief, they shall terminate their service
not later than December 31 of the year during which he or she attains such
age.

CHAPTER 175
Architectural Board of Review
 
175.01   Establishment; membership.
175.02   Officers; conflict of interest.
175.03   Fee Schedule.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Architects - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4703
      Exterior building design - see B. & H. Ch.
1327
 
   175.01  ESTABLISHMENT; MEMBERSHIP.
   There is hereby established an Architectural Board of Review, consisting of
the Mayor, the Councilmanic representative to the Planning Commission and three
architects, one or more of whom may be a member of the Board of Zoning Appeals.
If there is an insufficient number of architects on such Board of Zoning
Appeals, the Mayor shall designate sufficient architects to provide the
required membership of such Architectural Board of Review.
   The Mayor may designate three alternative architects as alternate members of
the Architectural Board of Review in the event the regular architect members of
the Board would be unable to serve for any length of time, thereby impeding the
business of such Board. Such alternate architect members shall serve as
substitute members only during such periods designated by the Mayor. The term
of the members of the Architectural Board of Review shall be the term of
service of the Mayor or the termination of their appointment to the Board of
Zoning Appeals. (Ord. 71-25. Passed 4-5-71.)
 
   175.02  OFFICERS; CONFLICT OF INTEREST.
   The Architectural Board of Review shall organize at its first meeting by
electing a Chairperson and a Secretary. The Secretary shall keep a record of
the proceedings of the Board which shall be available in the office of the
Building Commissioner at reasonable times. A Chairperson and Secretary shall be
elected every January.
   An architect member of the Board may not review any plan or design in which
he or she may have any interest, either direct or indirect, for example, his or
her own work, that of members of his or her firm or work for a client of his or
hers. The examples are descriptive rather than limiting.  (Ord. 64-49. Passed
7-6-64.)
 
   175.03  FEE SCHEDULE.
   (a)   The Fee Schedule for each application for review by the Architectural
Board of Review shall be as follows:
      One, Two and Three Family Dwellings
 
New Construction       $50
Additions, Alterations $35
      All other Buildings or Structures
         Based on square feet of Aggregate Floor Area
 
Under 2,500     $50
2,500 to 7,500  $60
7,500 to 15,000 $80
Over 15,000     $120
Alterations     $50
Signs           $50
   (b)   Fees for the Architectural Board of Review are for two appearances. 
There is a $25.00 fee for the third and each subsequent appearance.
(Ord. 2016-37.  Passed 5-16-16.)

CHAPTER 179
Records Commission
 
179.01   Establishment; membership; Secretary; compensation.
179.02   Duties.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      City Records Commission - see Ohio R.C. 149.39
      Keeping of records - see Ohio R.C. 149.40
      Availability of public records - see Ohio R.C. 149.43, 149.44
      Tampering with records - see GEN. OFF.
642.18
 
   179.01  ESTABLISHMENT; MEMBERSHIP; SECRETARY; COMPENSATION.
   There is hereby established, in accordance with Ohio R.C. 149.39, the
Records Commission of the City, which shall consist of the Mayor, who shall be
the Chairperson, the Director of Finance, the Director of Law and one
additional member appointed by the Mayor who shall be a citizen of the City.  A
Secretary, who may or may not be a member of the Records Commission, shall be
appointed by the Commission, and shall serve at its pleasure.  The Commission
members and Secretary shall serve without compensation.
(Ord. 86-74.  Passed 10-20-86.)
 
   179.02  DUTIES.
   The Records Commission shall perform the duties set forth in Ohio R.C.
149.39, and in addition thereto shall, when it is deemed advisable by the
membership, initiate and promulgate plans for the reproduction of City records,
by lawful means, for the purposes of more economical storage and improved
safety thereof, and may conduct investigations of the necessity for and the
practicability of said plans.
(Ord. 86-74. Passed 10-20-86.)
 
 
 
CHAPTER 181
Commission on Aging
 
181.01   Establishment; membership.
181.02   Purpose.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
   Low interest housing loans - see Ohio Const., Art. VIII, §14
   Community service programs - see Ohio R.C. 121.40
   Ohio Department of Aging - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 173
   Food services - see Ohio R.C. 3313.81
   Alzheimer's disease - see Ohio R.C. 3701.18, 3701.181
   Complaints of nursing home violations - see Ohio R.C. 3721.17
 
   181.01  ESTABLISHMENT; MEMBERSHIP.
   There is hereby established in and for the City a Commission on Aging,
consisting of nine members. Permanent nonvoting members shall be the Mayor and
the Vice-Mayor. The remaining seven and voting members of the Commission shall
be residents of the City who are sixty years of age or older. All such members
shall be appointed by the Mayor, four of whom shall serve for a term of two
years each, and three of whom shall serve for a term of one year each. All
subsequent appointments to such Commission shall be for a two-year period.
(Ord. 77-84. Passed 11-7-77.)
 
   181.02  PURPOSE.
   The purpose of the Commission on Aging shall be to serve in an advisory
capacity to Council on the concerns of the aging and to recommend programs for
the aging and means of implementing such programs. Among those areas of concern
in the problems of aging, which the Commission may review and as to which the
Commission may make recommendations, are the following:
   (a)   Referral Services or Senior Information and Service Center on:
      (1)   Job placement
      (2)   Skills bank
      (3)   Medicare - Social Security information
      (4)   Emergency services
      (5)   Telephone assurance.
   (b)   Health:
      (1)   Health survey
      (2)   Health needs defined
      (3)   Increase or change of existing services
      (4)   Voluntary service programs with medical school, etc.
      (5)   Preventive health program.
   (c)   Leisure Time Activities:
      (1)   Trips
      (2)   Classes
      (3)   Exercise programs
      (4)   Social involvement to provide services
      (5)   Programs (dances, plays, movies, lectures)
      (6)   Recreation.
   (d)   Transportation:
      (1)   Minibus proposal
      (2)   Coordinating of other minibus services.
   (e)   Nutrition:
      (1)   Coordinating food programs
      (2)   Food stamp program
      (3)   Hot food (lunches, meals on wheels)
      (4)   Nutrition education.
         (Ord. 77-84.  Passed 11-7-77.)

TITLE NINE - Judiciary
      Chap.
197.   Municipal Court.
 
 
 
CHAPTER 197
Municipal Court
 
197.01   Officers.
197.02   Traffic Bureau.
197.03   Special Projects Fund.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Judicial powers of Mayor - see CHTR.
Art. IV, §2
      Municipal Court - see Ohio R.C. 1901.01 et seq.
      Traffic Code penalties - see TRAF. Ch.
408
      General Offenses Code penalties and sentencing - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
698
 
   197.01  OFFICERS.
   The officers of the Lyndhurst Municipal Court, as provided for in Ohio R.C.
1901.31(H) and 1901.32, shall be the Clerk and the Bailiff. Additional Deputy
Clerks and Deputy Bailiffs may be appointed by the Clerk and the Court, as
provided for in the annual appropriation for such Court by the City.
(Ord. 65-31. Passed 4-5-65.)
 
   197.02  TRAFFIC BUREAU.
   (a)   Establishment.    Subject to the Rules of Practice and Procedure in
Traffic Cases for All Courts Inferior to Common Pleas, as promulgated by the
Supreme Court of Ohio, there is hereby established a Traffic Bureau to assist
the Municipal Judge with the clerical work of traffic cases. The Bureau shall
be in the charge of the Clerk of the Municipal Court and shall be open at such
hours as the Judge may designate.
 
   (b)   Waiver Schedules.  The judge shall designate the specified offenses
under the traffic ordinances of the City and the State traffic laws in respect
to which payments of fines may be accepted by the Traffic Bureau in
satisfaction thereof, and shall specify by suitable schedules the amount of
such fines for first, second and subsequent offenses, provided such fines are
within to limits declared by law or ordinance, and shall further specify what
number of such offenses shall require appearance before the Court.
 
   (c)   Options; Effect of Waiver.
      (1)   Any person charged with an offense for which payment of a fine may
be made the Traffic Bureau may either pay such fine within the time specified
in the notice of arrest at the Traffic Bureau upon entering a plea of guilty
and upon waiving appearance in court, or may deposit required lawful bail,
enter a plea of not guilty and be tried as authorized by law.
      (2)   The payment of a fine to the Bureau shall be deemed an
acknowledgment of conviction of the alleged offense, and the Bureau, upon
accepting the prescribed fine, shall issue a receipt to the violator
acknowledging payment thereof.
 
   (d)   Duties.  The following duties are hereby imposed upon the Traffic
Bureau in reference to traffic offenses:
      (1)   It shall accept designated fines, issue receipts and represent in
court such violators as are permitted and desire to plead guilty, waive court
appearance or give power of attorney.
      (2)   It shall receive and issue receipts for cash bail from the persons
who must or wish to be heard in court, enter the time of their appearance on
the court docket, and notify the arresting officer and witnesses, if any, to be
present.
      (3)   It shall keep an easily accessible record of all violations of
which each person has been guilty during the preceding twelve months, whether
such guilt was established in court or in the Traffic Bureau.
      (4)   It shall keep records and submit summarized monthly reports to the
Court and Mayor of all notices issued and arrests made for violations of the
traffic laws and ordinances in the City, and of all the fines collected by the
Traffic Bureau or the court, and of the final disposition or present status of
every case of violations of the provisions of such laws and ordinances. Such
records shall be so maintained as to show all types of violations and the
totals of each. Such records shall be a public record. (Ord. 64-100. Passed 12-
7-64.)
 
   197.03  SPECIAL PROJECTS FUND.
   (a)   The Director of Finance is hereby authorized and directed to establish
a special revenue fund to be identified as “Municipal Court - Special Projects
Fund.”  Said Fund shall be used solely and exclusively for the purpose of
receiving and disbursing all monies related to special projects of the
Lyndhurst Municipal Court, as allowed in Ohio R.C. 1901.26(B)(1).
 
   (b)   Expenditures from said Fund shall be made by the Director of Finance
upon receipt of the proper certificates and vouchers approved by the Judge of
the Lyndhurst Municipal Court or such other officers authorized by law.
(Ord. 2000-26.  Passed 4-17-00.)
