subdivisions, and combinations of individuals of any form.
   (d)   "Transient guests" means persons occupying a room or rooms for
sleeping accommodations for less than thirty consecutive days.
      (Ord. 89-19. Passed 3-20-89.)
   795.02  LEVY AND RATE.
   There is hereby levied and imposed upon every person who is a transient
guest in a hotel and pays a charge for such lodging a tax of three percent on
the amount paid for the lodging in such hotel, irrespective of whether such
lodging is paid by cash or credit card. The tax shall apply to every hotel
within the City for which a charge is made, notwithstanding that the
reservation of the lodging is made outside the City.
(Ord. 89-19. Passed 3-20-89.)
   795.03  COLLECTION.
   Every person receiving any payment upon which a tax is levied under this
chapter shall collect the amount of the tax imposed from the person making the
lodging payment. The tax required to be collected under this chapter shall be
deemed to be held in trust by the person required to collect the same until
paid to the Director of Finance as herein provided. Any person required to
collect the tax imposed under this chapter who fails to collect the same, or
having collected same, fails to remit the same to the Director of Finance in
the manner prescribed by this chapter, whether such failure is the result of
his or her own act or the result of acts or conditions beyond his or her
control, shall nevertheless be personally liable to the City for the amount of
such tax, and shall, unless the remittance is made as herein required, be
guilty of a violation of this chapter. The tax imposed hereunder shall be
collected at the time the lodging charge is paid by the transient guest seeking
lodging in a hotel and shall be reported and remitted by the person receiving
the tax to the Director of Finance in monthly installments and remittances
therefor on or before the thirtieth day of the month next succeeding the end of
the monthly period in which the tax is collected or received. Payment or
remittance of the tax collected may be made by check, unless payment or
remittance is otherwise required by the Director of Finance, but payment by
check shall not relieve the person collecting the tax from liability for
payment and remittance of the tax to the Director of Finance unless the check
is honored and is in the full and correct amount. The person receiving any
payment for lodgings from a transient guest shall make out a return upon such
forms and setting forth such information as the Director of Finance may
require, showing the amount of the tax upon lodging for which he or she is
liable for the preceding monthly period, and shall sign and transmit the same
to the Director of Finance with a remittance for such amount.  However, the
Director Finance may, in his or her discretion, require verified annual returns
from any person receiving lodging payments, setting forth such additional
information as he or she may deem necessary to determine correctly the amount
of tax collected and payable, and failure to comply with any requirement of the
Director as to the report and remittance of the tax as required shall be a
violation of this chapter.
   The books, records and accounts of any person collecting a tax herein levied
shall, as to lodging and tax collections, be at all reasonable times subject to
examination and audit by the Director of Finance. If the tax imposed by this
chapter is not paid when due there shall be added, as part of the tax, interest
at the rate of one percent per month from the time when the tax became due
until paid.
(Ord. 89-19. Passed 3-20-89.)
   795.04  CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION.
   Any person conducting or operating any place for lodging for transient
guests shall, on a form prescribed by the Director of Finance, make application
to and procure from the Director of Finance a certificate of registration, the
fee for which shall be five dollars ($5.00), which certificate shall continue
valid until December 31 of the year in which the same is issued. Such
certificate of registration, or duplicate original copies thereof to be issued
by the Director of Finance without additional charge, shall be posted in a
conspicuous place in each guest registration lobby.
(Ord. 89-19. Passed 3-20-89.)
   795.05  RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   (a)   The Director of Finance shall have the power to adopt rules and
regulations not inconsistent with the terms of this chapter for carrying out
and enforcing the payment, collection and remittance of the tax herein levied.
A copy of such rules and regulations shall be published in the City record at
least once before they shall become effective and copies shall be printed and
made available in the office of the Director of Finance. Failure or refusal to
comply with any such rules or regulations shall be deemed a violation of this
chapter.
   (b)   Until such time as rules and regulations are promulgated under this
section, the rules and regulations of the Department of Taxation, State of
Ohio, relating to excise taxes in effect on March 20, 1989, except as the same
may conflict with the provisions of this chapter, shall be deemed to be the
rules and regulations hereunder.
(Ord. 89-19. Passed 3-20-89.)
   795.06  APPEALS.
   Appeals from any ruling hereunder of the Director of Finance shall be made
to Council in the same manner as other appeals to Council. Council shall have
the authority to annul, modify or affirm any such ruling appealed from, in
conformity with the intent and purpose of this chapter.
(Ord. 89-19. Passed 3-20-89.)
   795.07  CONFIDENTIALITY OF INFORMATION.
   All returns and information relating to the business of any person required
to collect the tax imposed by this chapter and coming into the possession of
the Director of Finance, or his or her agents and employees, shall be held
confidential.  No person shall make any disclosures thereof unless ordered by a
court of competent jurisdiction, except, however, that the Director of Finance
may furnish the Bureau of Internal Revenue, Treasury Department of the United
States, with copies of returns filed.
(Ord. 89-19.  Passed 3-20-89.)
   795.08  VIOLATIONS.
   No person charged by this chapter with the duty of collecting or paying the
tax imposed by this chapter shall willfully fail or refuse to:
   (a)   Charge and collect or pay such tax;
   (b)   Make a return to the Director of Finance as required by this chapter;
   (c)   Permit the Director or his or her duly authorized agent to examine
books and other records in or upon any premises where the same are kept, to the
extent necessary to verify any return made or to ascertain and assess the tax
imposed by this chapter if no return was made; or
   (d)   Maintain and keep books and other records for three years or such
lesser or greater time as may be permitted or required by the Director.
      (Ord. 89-19.  Passed 3-20-89.)
   795.99  PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter, for which no penalty is otherwise provided, is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor for a first offense and shall be fined not more than one hundred
dollars ($100.00), if an individual, and shall be fined not more than one
thousand dollars ($1,000), if an organization, subject to the provisions of
Sections
606.08 and
606.09 of the General Offenses Code.  For a second or subsequent offense, such
person is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree and shall be fined not
more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned not more than sixty
days, or both, if an individual, and shall be fined not more than three
thousand dollars ($3,000), if an organization, subject to the provisions of
Sections
 606.08 and
606.09 of the General Offenses Code, for each offense.  A separate offense
shall be deemed committed each day during or on which a violation or
noncompliance occurs or continues.
   (b)   Whoever violates Section
795.07 is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree and shall be fined not
more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned not more than sixty
days, or both, for each offense, and, in addition, shall thereafter be
disqualified from acting in any official capacity in connection with the
assessment or collection of taxes under this chapter.
                                                                               
                     
CHAPTER 797
Motor Vehicle License Tax
797.01   Intent.
797.02   Levy; purposes.
797.03   Rate.
797.04   Effective period; payment.
797.05   Certification.
CROSS REFERENCES
   Motor vehicle license tax - see Ohio R.C. 4504.06,  4504.172
   Display of license plates - see TRAF. 436.09
   Use of illegal license plates - see TRAF. 436.10
   797.01  INTENT.
   Council hereby finds that it is desirable to levy an annual license tax upon
the operation of motor vehicles on the public roads and highways of the City of
Lyndhurst, Ohio, to provide additional revenue for the purposes hereinafter set
forth.
(Ord. 87-69.  Passed 8-17-87.)
   797.02  LEVY; PURPOSES.
   There is hereby levied an annual license tax upon the operation of motor
vehicles on the public roads or highways, pursuant to Ohio R.C. 4504.172, for
the purposes of paying the costs and expenses of enforcing and administering
the tax provided for in this section, to provide additional revenue for the
purposes set forth in Ohio R.C. 4504.06, and to supplement revenue already
available for such purposes.
(Ord. 87-69.  Passed 8-17-87.)
   797.03  RATE.
   The tax provided for in Section
797.02 shall be at the rate of five dollars ($5.00) per motor vehicle on each
and every motor vehicle the district of registration of which, as defined in
Ohio R.C. 4503.10, is in the City of Lyndhurst, Ohio.  As used in this chapter,
"motor vehicle" means any and all vehicles included within the definition of
motor vehicle in Ohio R.C. 4501.01 and 4505.01.
(Ord. 87-69.  Passed 8-17-87.)
   797.04  EFFECTIVE PERIOD; PAYMENT.
   The tax imposed by this chapter shall apply to and be in effect for the
registration year commencing January 1, 1988, shall continue in effect and
application during each registration year thereafter and shall be paid to the
Registrar of Motor Vehicles of the State of Ohio or to a Deputy Registrar at
the time application for registration of a motor vehicle is made, as provided
in Ohio R.C. 4503.10.
(Ord. 87-69.  Passed 8-17-87.)
   797.05  CERTIFICATION.
   The Clerk of Council is hereby directed to certify this chapter to the
Bureau of Motor Vehicles no later than September 30, 1987, and no later than
July 1 of each successive year thereafter, for collection in the following
year.
(Ord. 87-69.  Passed 8-17-87.)

CODIFIED ORDINANCES OF LYNDHURST
PART NINE - STREETS AND PUBLIC SERVICES CODE
TITLE ONE - Street and Sidewalk Areas
      Chap.
901.   Excavations and Repairs.
      Chap.

      Chap.
905.    Sidewalks.

907.    Street Lighting.
CHAPTER 901
Excavations and Repairs
901.01   Openings in public rights of way; deposit.
901.02   Openings in tree lawns or park strips or under sidewalks; deposit.
901.03   Barricades and warning lights.
901.04   Backfilling.
901.05   Excavations and repairs involving sewer work.
901.06   Use of off-duty police officers.
901.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
   Openings by the Municipality - see Ohio R.C. 723.02
   Excavation liability - see Ohio R.C. 723.49 et seq.
   Digging, excavating and piling earth on streets - see Ohio R.C. 5589.10
   Injurious material or obstruction in street - see TRAF
. 412.01
   Public utilities generally - see S.U. & P.S. Ch.
921
   Street opening permit - see S.U. & P.S.
921.03
   Excavations on private premises - see B. & H.
1351.14(c)
   901.01  OPENINGS IN PUBLIC RIGHTS OF WAY; DEPOSIT.
   Whenever any excavation is to be made within a public right of way, the
applicant shall deposit with the Building Commissioner and/or the Service
Director an amount determined by the Building Commissioner or the Service
Director to ensure that the property involved is repaired and restored to its
original condition.  All of such deposit, except for the sum of fifty dollars
($50.00) per inspection, to ensure compliance with this section, shall be
returned to the applicant when the work has been completed to the satisfaction
of the Building Commissioner and/or the Service Director.
   901.02  OPENINGS IN TREE LAWNS OR PARK STRIPS  OR UNDER SIDEWALKS; DEPOSIT.
   (a)   Estimate. Openings in tree lawns or under sidewalks, which include
only private sewer or water connections, may be done by any plumber or sewer
builder who is properly bonded and licensed in the City and only to the extent
covered by his or her bond. Work on main sewers, catch basins or other public
sewer facilities is done by the City; work on water mains or meter vaults shall
be done by the Cleveland Water Division. Generally, work in park strips is
classified as City work. Application for a cost estimate of work to be done by
the City must be made at least two days in advance of the contemplated starting
date. Arrangements for the division of the work to be done will be made at this
time and the estimate given on this basis.
   (b)   Deposit. If determined by the Building Commisisoner and/or the Service
Director to be necessary, a deposit shall be required as per Section
901.01.
   901.03  BARRICADES AND WARNING LIGHTS.
   No person, firm, voluntary association of persons, contractor or mechanic
performing work of any nature in public streets and areas, shall fail to
protect members of the public and their property from any injury or danger
thereof by providing barricades, lights and other facilities around open
excavations and other disturbances in public streets and areas in the City.
(Ord. 61-74. Passed 8-7-61.)
   901.04  BACKFILLING.
   (a)   All tree lawn openings shall be backfilled with sand when the work
must be done in freezing weather. At other times they may be backfilled with
earth, but the work must be done under the Building Commissioner's supervision.
If the trench is backfilled with earth during freezing weather or at any time
without supervision, then the deposit will not be refunded upon completion of
the work but may be held for a period of six months or until the Building
Commissioner is satisfied that settlement is complete.
   (b)   All openings under sidewalks except in new construction shall be
backfilled with sand. This work shall also be carried out under the Building
Commissioner's supervision, and failure to observe these regulations will also
necessitate withholding the deposit until the Building Commissioner is
satisfied with the work.
(Ord. 3260. Passed 6-19-39.)
   901.05  EXCAVATIONS AND REPAIRS INVOLVING SEWER WORK.
   If the excavation or repair includes sewer work, the usual sewer permit must
be obtained; and if work is on a water line, arrangements for inspection must
be made with the Cleveland Water Division.
(Ord. 61-102.  Passed 11-20-61.)
   901.06  USE OF OFF-DUTY POLICE OFFICERS.
   The Director of Service is hereby authorized to retain off-duty members of
the Police Department for the purpose of regulating traffic during excavation
and repair of streets, tree lawns, park strips or sidewalks.
   Where deposits from contractors are required for payment for such service,
Section
921.05 shall be complied with.
(Ord. 73-95. Passed 12-17-73.)
   901.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of the second degree and shall be fined not
more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) or imprisoned not more than
ninety days, or both, if an individual, and shall be fined not more than four
thousand dollars ($4,000), if an organization, subject to the provisions of
Sections
606.08 and
 606.09 of the General Offenses Code, for each offense. A separate offense
shall be deemed committed each day during or on which a violation or
noncompliance occurs or continues.
                                                                               
                     
CHAPTER 903
Trees and Shrubs

903.09   Stone or concrete on ground adjacent to tree trunk.
903.10   Moving of trees.
903.11   Duties of private owners.
903.12   Authority of City Arborist to enter private premises.
903.13   Interference with City Arborist.
903.14   Permit for landscape work.
903.15   Injury by animals.
903.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Dutch elm disease - see Ohio R.C. 927.39 to 927.42
      Obstruction of view of streets by vegetation - see TRAF. 
412.07
      Injuring vegetation - see GEN. OFF.
642.06
      Weeds - see GEN. OFF.
660.16
   903.01  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and
their derivations shall have the meanings given herein. When not inconsistent
with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words
used in the plural number include the singular number and words in the singular
number include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not
merely directory.
   (a)   "City" means the City of Lyndhurst, Ohio.
   (b)   "City Arborist" means the Director of Service of the City or a
specially assigned member of his or her staff.
   (c)   "Person" means any individual, firm, partnership, association,
corporation, company or organization of any kind.
   (d)   "Street tree" or "tree" means a tree in a public place except where
otherwise indicated.
   (e)   "Public place" means any public street, public highway, public park or
any property owned or held by the City within the boundaries of the City.
   (f)   "Arboriculture" or "tree preservation" means and includes the
treating, spraying, pruning, maintaining and any other care or work intended
for the strengthening of trees, and the removal and prevention of tree pests,
blights and diseases of any and all kinds.
      (Ord. 63-35. Passed 6-3-63.)
   903.02  AUTHORITY OF DIRECTOR OF SERVICE.
   The Director of Service shall, by virtue of his or her office, be the City
Arborist.
   (a)   Scope of Authority. The Director of Service is hereby given full
jurisdiction, authority, control, supervision and direction of all trees which
now or which may hereafter exist upon any public place in the City and over all
trees which exist upon any private property in the City when such trees
constitute a menace to the City.
      (1)   Issuance of permits.  The Director of Service is also given full
jurisdiction, authority and control in connection with the issuance of permits
hereinafter provided for.
      (2)   Delegation of duties and authority. In the exercise of any or all
of the powers herein granted, the Director of Service shall have the authority
to delegate all or such part of his or her power and duties with respect to
supervision and control of trees to his or her subordinates and assistants in
the employ of the City as he or she may from time to time determine.
   (b)   Order to Preserve or Remove. The Director of Service shall have the
authority and it shall be his or her duty to order the trimming, preservation
or removal of trees or plants upon private property when he or she finds such
action necessary to public safety or to prevent the spread of disease or
insects to public trees and places.
      (Ord. 63-35. Passed 6-3-63.)
   903.03  MASTER STREET TREE PLAN ADOPTED.
   There is hereby adopted for the City a Master Street Tree Plan Public
Document showing varieties of species of all trees to be planted in the public
right of way of all streets within the City. Such Plan is contained under
separate cover and incorporated in this chapter by reference as if fully set
forth herein. No person shall hereafter plant, transplant or move any public
tree on or to any street of the City except to a location where it will be in
conformity with the Master Street Tree Plan and the species or variety therein
designated.
(Ord. 63-35. Passed 6-3-63.)
   903.04  PLANTING, REMOVAL, ETC.; PERMIT REQUIRED.
   (a)   In General.  No person shall plant, remove, destroy, cut, prune,
treat, break, climb, injure or spray any tree existing on any public place in
the City, or authorize or procure any person to do so, or remove or tamper with
any device placed for the protection of any such tree, or attach any rope,
wire, chain, sign or other device placed for the protection of such tree, or
authorize or cause the same to be done, except having first obtained written
permission from the Director of Service to do so.
   (b)   Contents of Permit: Support Posts. Such permit, when granted for the
planting of any tree to be located on any public place in the City, shall
designate the species of tree to be planted, the required spacing and required
minimum planting size, as specified in the Master Street Tree Plan for the
City, as such plan now exists or as it may be amended from time to time. All
newly planted trees, whether installed by the abutting property owner or
contractor, shall be supported by a ninety-six inch support post placed on the
street side of the tree. No person shall guy any tree less than four inches in
caliper with wires or rope. For trees over four inches in caliper special
permission must be obtained and the permittee must assume liability for
accidents occurring therefrom.
   (c)   Application Data. The application for the permit herein required shall
state the number and kind of trees to be trimmed, sprayed, preserved, removed
or planted, the kind of treatment to be administered and such other information
as the Director of Service shall find reasonably necessary to a fair
determination of whether a permit should be issued hereunder.
   (d)   Standards for Issuance. The Director of Service shall issue the permit
provided for herein when he or she finds that the desired action or treatment
is necessary and that the proposed method and workmanship are satisfactory.
   (e)   Supervision. The Director of Service shall have the authority and it
shall be his or her duty to supervise all work done under a permit issued in
accordance with the terms of this chapter.
   (f)   Conditional Permits. The Director of Service shall have the authority
to affix
reasonable conditions to the granting of a permit hereunder.
   (g)   Exemptions. No permit shall be required to cultivate, fertilize or
water public trees or shrubs. The Director of Service may authorize any person
to do any work or act described in   subsection (a) hereof without written
permit whenever he or she determines that such work or act will not be
detrimental to the public interest and will be in accordance with the spirit
and other requirements of this chapter.
(Ord. 63-35. Passed 6-3-63.)
   903.05  GENERAL REGULATIONS.
   (a)   Injury to Trees and Shrubs Prohibited. No person shall, without the
consent of the owner in the case of a private tree or shrub, or without a
written permit from the Director of Service in the case of a public tree or
shrub, do, or cause to be done by others, any of the following acts:
      (1)   Secure, fasten or run any rope, wire, sign or other device or
material to, around or through a tree or shrub.
      (2)   Break, injure, mutilate, deface, kill or destroy or permit any fire
to burn where it will injure any tree or shrub.
      (3)   Permit any toxic chemical, gas, smoke, salt, brine, oil or other
injurious substance to seep, drain or be emptied upon or about any tree or
shrub.
      (4)   Excavate any ditch, tunnel or trench or lay any drive within a
radius of not closer than three feet from any tree or shrub.
      (5)   Erect, alter, repair or raze any building or structure without
placing suitable guards around all nearby public trees or shrubs which may be
injured or defaced by such activity, or where such injury or defacement may
arise out of, in connection with or by reason of such an operation. The quality
of the guard shall be determined by the Director of Service.
      (6)   Knowingly permit any unprotected electric service wires to come in
prolonged contact with any public tree or shrub.
      (7)   Remove any guard, stake or other device or material intended for
the protection of a public tree or shrub or close or obstruct any open space
about the base of a public tree or shrub designed to permit access of air,
water and fertilizer. (See Section
 903.09.)                                       
   (b)   Trimming of Trees on Public Property. The Director of Service shall,
and he or she is hereby directed to, keep all trees standing upon any public
place in the City trimmed so that the branches of such trees projecting over
any public sidewalk, private driveway or into any public street beyond the curb
line shall not conflict with the public welfare.
   (c)   Trimming of Trees on Private Property. All trees standing upon private
property in the City having branches projecting into public highways or public
places shall, under the supervision of the Director of Service, be kept trimmed
by the owner or occupant of such private property to such an extent that the
lowest branches of such trees do not come within nine feet of the ground where
they overhang any public sidewalk or public place or thirteen feet over a
public highway.
   (d)   Obstruction of View at Intersections Prohibited. Notwithstanding any
other provision of this chapter, no person shall maintain, plant or permit to
remain on any private or public premises situated at the intersection of two or
more streets or alleys in the City any hedge, tree, shrub or other growth which
may obstruct the view of the operator of any motor vehicle approaching such
intersection to the extent that such operator is unable to observe other
vehicles or pedestrians approaching or crossing such intersection. Any such
hedge, tree, shrub or growth is hereby declared to be a public nuisance.
(Ord. 63-35. Passed 6-3-63.)
   (e)   Trimming of Trees by Public Utility Companies. When a public utility
company desires to trim trees it shall be done only under the supervision of a
City inspector. The cost of such inspector shall be borne by the public
utility.
(Ord. 3260. Passed 6-19-39.)
   903.06  CERTAIN TREES PROHIBITED.
   Any silver maple, honey locust, poplar, basswood, box elder, catalpa or
willow upon private property in the City in such close proximity to any public
place in the City as will permit the roots of such tree to penetrate through or
under the surface of any public place in the City is hereby declared to be a
public nuisance and may be abated by the Director of Service as provided in
Sections
903.02(b) and
 903.08.
(Ord. 63-35. Passed 6-3-63.)
   903.07  PRESERVATION AND REMOVAL OF TREES ON  PUBLIC PROPERTY.
   The Director of Service shall have the right and duty to trim any tree
existing on any public place in the City so as to insure the public safety or
to preserve the function or beauty of such public place; and he or she shall
further have the right to remove any such tree, or any part thereof, which is
in an unsafe condition or which, by reason of its location or nature, is
injurious or detrimental to other public improvements in the City, or is
infected with any injury, fungus, insect or other pest or disease which cannot
otherwise be controlled. Such infested or infected tree is a public nuisance.
(Ord. 63-35. Passed 6-3-63.)
   903.08  PROCEDURE UPON ORDER TO PRESERVE OR REMOVE.
   When the City Arborist finds it necessary to order the trimming,
preservation or removal of trees or plants upon private property as authorized
in Sections
903.02(b) and
903.05(c), he or she shall serve a written order upon the owner, operator,
occupant or other person responsible for its existence to correct the dangerous
condition.
   (a)   Method of Service. The order required herein shall be served in one of
the following ways:
      (1)   By making personal delivery of the order to the person responsible;
      (2)   By leaving the order with some person of suitable age and
discretion upon the premises;
      (3)   By affixing a copy of the order to the door at the entrance of the
premises in violation;
      (4)   By mailing a copy of the order to the last known address of the
owner of the premises by registered mail; or
      (5)   By publishing a copy of the order in a local newspaper once a week
for three successive weeks.
   (b)   Time for Compliance. The order required herein shall set forth a time
limit for compliance dependent upon the hazard and danger created by the
violation. In cases of extreme danger to persons or public property, the City
Arborist shall have the authority to require compliance immediately upon
service of the order.
   (c)   Appeal from Order. A person to whom an order hereunder is directed has
the right, within twenty-four hours of the service of such order, to appeal to
the Mayor, who shall review such order within three days and file his or her
decision thereon. Unless the order is revoked or modified it shall remain in
full force and be obeyed by the person to whom directed. No person to whom an
order is directed shall fail to comply with such order within ten days after an
appeal has been determined.
   (d)   Failure to Comply. When a person to whom an order is directed fails to
comply within the specified time, the City Arborist shall remedy the condition
or contract with others for such purpose and charge the cost thereof to the
person to whom the order is directed. The person remedying a condition under a
contract made hereunder shall be authorized to enter premises for that purpose.
   (e)   Special Assessment. If the cost of remedying a condition is not paid
within ten days after receipt of a statement therefor from the City Arborist,
such cost shall be levied against the property upon which such hazard exists,
as a special assessment. The levying of such assessment shall not affect the
liability of the person to whom the order is directed to fine and imprisonment
as provided in Section
903.99. Such special assessment shall be collected in the manner provided in
Ohio R.C. 727.30 to 727.38, inclusive, with a forfeiture of five percent and
interest for failure to pay at the time fixed by the assessing ordinance.
      (Ord. 63-35. Passed 6-3-63.)
   903.09  STONE OR CONCRETE ON GROUND ADJACENT TO TREE TRUNK.
   No person shall place or maintain upon the ground in any public place any
stone, concrete, brick or other impervious material or substance in such a
manner as may obstruct the free access of air and water to the roots of any
tree upon any public place in the City without first having obtained written
permission to do so. Unless otherwise provided for there shall be maintained
about the base of the trunk of each such tree at least nine square feet of open
ground for a three-inch diameter tree and for every two inches of increase of
such diameter there shall be an increase of at least one square foot of open
ground.
(Ord. 63-35. Passed 6-3-63.)
   903.10  MOVING OF TREES.
   All moving of trees upon any public place in the City made necessary by the
moving of a building or structure or any other private enterprise shall be done
under the supervision of, and with the written permission of, the City
Arborist, and at the expense of the applicant or person seeking the removal of
such tree. Such applicant, as one of the conditions to obtaining such
permission, shall deposit with the City such sum in cash as the City Arborist
may determine and specify to cover all of the cost of moving and replacing such
tree if the conditions of such permission require the replacement thereof,
provided, however, that in lieu of such cash deposit the City Arborist may, in
his or her discretion, accept a good and sufficient bond in like amount
conditioned upon the payment of all of the cost of such moving and replacing.
(Ord. 63-35. Passed 6-3-63.)
   903.11  DUTIES OF PRIVATE OWNERS.
   It shall be the duty of any person growing a tree within a public highway or
responsible for trees growing on property abutting on public places supporting
trees or plants to:
   (a)   Trim his or her trees so as not to cause a hazard to public places or
interfere with the proper lighting of public highways by the street lights, and
so that the minimum clearance of any overhanging portion thereof shall be nine
feet over footways and thirteen feet over vehicular ways.
   (b)   Treat or remove any tree or plant so diseased or insect-ridden as to
constitute a hazard to trees or plants in public places.                       
 
   (c)   Remove and refrain from planting any of the species set forth in
Section
903.06.
(Ord. 63-35. Passed 6-3-63.)
   903.12  AUTHORITY OF CITY ARBORIST TO ENTER PRIVATE PREMISES.
   The City Arborist has the authority to enter upon private premises at all
reasonable times for the purpose of examining any tree or shrub located upon or
over such premises and carrying out any of the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 63-35. Passed 6-3-63.)
   903.13  INTERFERENCE WITH CITY ARBORIST.   
   No person shall prevent, delay or interfere with the City Arborist or his or
her agents, employees or servants while they are engaged in carrying out any
work or activities authorized by this chapter.
(Ord. 63-35. Passed 6-3-63.)
   903.14  PERMIT FOR LANDSCAPE WORK.
   Any person desiring to plant, prune, fertilize, spray or otherwise treat any
tree on public property in the City shall first apply to the City Arborist for
a permit. All such work shall be done under the supervision of the Building
Commissioner.
(Ord. 3260. Passed 6-19-39.)
   903.15  INJURY BY ANIMALS.
   No person shall cause or knowingly or negligently permit any animal to
injure any tree, ornamental plant or shrub.
(Ord. 58-75. Passed 11-17-58.)
   903.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree and shall be fined not
more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or imprisoned not more than
thirty days, or both, if an individual, and shall be fined not more than two
thousand dollars ($2,000), if an organization, subject to the provisions of
Sections
 606.08 and
606.09 of the General Offenses Code, for each offense. A separate offense shall
be deemed committed each day during or on which a violation or noncompliance
occurs or continues.
                                                                               
                   
CHAPTER 905
Sidewalks
905.01   Construction and repair; permit required.
905.02   Construction and repair; specifications.
905.03   Construction and repair; procedure.
905.04   Maintenance of tree lawns;  salt strips.
905.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
   Walking on sidewalks - see TRAF.
416.05
   Right of way on sidewalks - see TRAF.
416.09
   Driving upon sidewalks - see TRAF.
432.22
   Bicycles upon sidewalks - see TRAF.
 474.07(d), (f)
   Maintenance and obstructions - see GEN. OFF.
660.05,
660.10
   Excavations in sidewalks - see S.U. & P.S.
901.02
   905.01  CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR; PERMIT REQUIRED.
   Any person desiring to lay or re-lay any sandstone flagging or concrete
sidewalk or to perform any other sidewalk work on public property in the City
shall first apply to the Building Commissioner for a permit, which shall be
issued without cost.
   All replacements of curb or sidewalk shall be as required in Sections
1136.12 and
1136.14 of these Codified Ordinances. The Building Commissioner may order any
replacements removed which do not comply with such requirements.
(Ord. 3260. Passed 6-19-39.)
   905.02  CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR; SPECIFICATIONS.               
   Sidewalk specifications for the City shall be as provided in Section
1136.14 of these Codified Ordinances. The Engineer shall provide specifications
for the base construction, aggregate and construction components and other
pertinent requirements. For a repair or reconstruction program of existing
sidewalks, plans will not be required and the grade of the sidewalk shall be
that which co-extends with adjoining sidewalks. Similarly, construction of new
sidewalks in the vicinity of existing sidewalks shall be so established. In any
case where Council deems it advisable, plans may be ordered to show grade and
other necessary data.
(Ord. 72-15. Passed 4-3-72.)     
   905.03  CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR; PROCEDURE.
     (a)     Findings and Purpose.  Council finds that the City has had a low
incidence of accidental injuries on public sidewalks by reason of defects
therein due to the continuous maintenance which has been provided by the City
in its annual sidewalk repairs programs. Council also finds that the City
prescribes the specifications for the construction of sidewalks in Sections
905.02  and
1136.14  of these Codified Ordinances and acquiesces in bicycle operation on
public sidewalks in Section
474.07 (d), (e) and (f) of these Codified Ordinances. Council also finds that
its routine maintenance program is conducive to the health, safety and welfare
of the public by minimizing the possibility of injury and enhancing the public
prosperity by limiting the expenses which are the natural result of claims
arising out of injury whether in payment for such injuries or the defense
thereof. Council declares that sidewalks determined to be public nuisances
shall be repaired to abate the nuisance pursuant to  Section
1385.24  of the Codified Ordinances.  (Ord. 2013-27.  Passed 5-20-13.)
   905.04  MAINTENANCE OF TREE LAWNS; SALT STRIPS.
   (a)   The owner and person in control of premises abutting the public
sidewalk and tree lawn area are required to maintain the tree lawn in a neat
and clean condition, planted in lawn or maintained as otherwise permitted by
the Service Director, except as otherwise authorized hereinafter, and free of
nuisance, as commonly known or as described or defined in these Codified
Ordinances. Tree removal or trimming shall be the responsibility of the City,
but the repair of tree root damage to sidewalks and driveway aprons shall be
performed by the owner and person in control. If the City performs such repair,
the cost thereof shall be paid by or assessed to the abutting owner in the
manner prescribed in Section
905.03 and similar ordinances adopted by Council in prior years.
   The Service Director may authorize a type of maintenance of tree lawns other
than the planting of lawns, provided the substitution is similar and secures
the objects of the maintenance requirements provided in the previous paragraph.
He or she shall maintain a log as a permanent record in his or her Department
of authorization under this paragraph of owners who have been allowed an
exception to the foregoing paragraph.
(Ord. 77-79. Passed 10-3-77.)
   (b)   A tree lawn, for the purposes of this section, is the area between the
street line, as defined in Section
1150.09(139), and the street curbing, edge of the pavement or ditch adjacent to
such pavement, excluding sidewalks where such are provided.
   (c)   In retail districts, salt strips, i.e. narrow sidewalks, twenty-four
inches wide and six inches of concrete thick may be placed along the curb.
Loose stones or other arrangements will not be permitted except as provided in
subsection (a) hereof.
(Ord. 74-108. Passed 12-16-74.)
   905.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a
misdemeanor of the fourth degree and shall be fined not more than two hundred
fifty dollars ($250.00) or imprisoned not more than thirty days, or both, if an
individual, and shall be fined not more than two thousand dollars ($2,000), if
an organization, subject to the provisions of Sections
606.08 and
606.09 of the General Offenses Code, for each offense. A separate offense shall
be deemed committed each day during or on which a violation or noncompliance
occurs or continues. The failure of the City to remove or trim trees shall not
constitute an offense.
(Ord. 78-90. Passed 12-18-78.)
                                                                               
                     
CHAPTER 907
Street Lighting
907.01   Necessity for assessments.
907.02   Determination of amount of assessments.
CROSS REFERENCES
   Electric companies - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4933
   Tampering with and theft of utilities - see GEN. OFF.
642.26
   Trimming of trees by public utility companies - see S.U. & P.S.
903.05(e)
   Public utilities - see S.U. & P.S. Ch.
921
   Street lighting assessments - see S.U. & P.S.
927.02
   907.01  NECESSITY FOR ASSESSMENTS.
   It is necessary that biannually the City determine the amount to be assessed
for the cost and expense of electric lights for certain streets, public roads
and parts thereof in the City.
(Ord. 80-39. Passed 5-19-80.)
   907.02  DETERMINATION OF AMOUNT OF ASSESSMENTS.
   The Director of Finance shall biannually determine the amount of assessments
to be certified to Council according to the following formula:
   (a)   Single-family residences, two-family residences, churches and
nonpublic and public school properties abutting upon public streets which are
lighted shall be assessed for the actual cost of residential street lighting.
   (b)   Underground fed street lighting for single-family residences, two-
family residences, churches and nonpublic and public school properties abutting
upon such streets, roads or portions thereof and served by such lights shall
likewise be assessed upon the actual cost and expense of such lighting except
for those properties abutting on Acacia Park Drive, which, for all lighting
assessments, shall be considered commercial property.
   (c)   Commercial properties shall be assessed seventy-five percent of the
actual cost and expense of commercial street lighting.
   (d)   All additional costs and expenses of such lighting, including park
lighting, shall be charged to the General Fund of the City.
      (Ord. 80-39. Passed 5-19-80; Ord. 80-46. Passed 6-2-80.)

Public Utilities Generally
921.01   Definitions.

   Prosecutions for theft of utilities - see GEN. OFF.

   Underground utilities - see P. & Z.
1136.22,
1160.07,
1162.05,
1164.14
   Utilities in flood hazard areas - see B. & H. 1331.15(c)
   921.01  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter certain words shall be defined as follows:
   (a)   "City" means the City of Lyndhurst, a municipal corporation, acting in
an administrative capacity by its Mayor and duly appointed officers, within the
scope of their authority, and in a legislative capacity by City Council.
   (b)   "Company" means any public utility corporation, person, firm, company,
political subdivision or corporation, whether municipal or otherwise, doing
construction or maintenance work on structures located in, under or over the
streets or public grounds of the City.
   (c)   "Cost" means the entire cost of work and materials and includes all
incidental expense, such as repaving, City inspection and supervision,
pertaining to the construction or maintenance of any structure.
   (d)   "Structure" means any pipe, conduit or duct line, sewer, water main,
service connection, pole, wire, track or other structure or appurtenance,
located in, under or over the streets or public grounds.
   (e)   "Work" means any and all labor and materials, delivery of materials,
supervision, fabrication or process of construction pertaining to the
construction or maintenance of any structure.
      (Ord. 3840. Passed 11-4-46.)
   921.02  PRIORITIES.
   (a)   The City, in the construction, reconstruction and maintenance of City
structures, shall have prior right in or over the streets or public grounds and
may require the removal, relocation, reconstruction or support of the
structures of any company. In such cases, the entire cost of such removal,
relocation, construction or support shall be borne by the company.       
   (b)   The City, if deemed necessary and in the public interest, may require
the removal, relocation, reconstruction or support of the structures of any
company for the purpose of permitting the construction, reconstruction or
maintenance of the structures of a second company and the cost thereof shall be
borne by the second company. However, if it is determined that the structures
of the prior company were constructed without authorization or permit of the
City, are not located substantially in accordance with the plans filed
therefor, occupy an unnecessary or unreasonable proportion of the space
available, or for other just and reasonable cause, the City may require that
the cost of such removal, relocation, reconstruction or support shall be borne
all or in part by such prior company.
(Ord. 3840. Passed 11-4-46.)                     
   921.03  WORK ON OR UNDER PUBLIC WAYS OR GROUNDS; PERMITS REQUIRED.
   No construction, reconstruction or maintenance work shall be done in, over
or under streets or public grounds by any company until satisfactory plans
therefor have been filed with and approved by the City and written permits for
such work are issued. Any material alterations or additions to the work must be
approved by the City and written permits secured. Where a street pavement or
sidewalk is to be opened for any work, a street opening permit shall be
included in those to be secured, and where a sidewalk or drive is to be
replaced in connection with the work, a sidewalk permit shall be secured. After
the completion of work, the company shall, if necessary, revise or file amended
plans so that the final record on file with the City shall show the correct
location, size and extent of all structures constructed, relocated or removed
or which otherwise are not in accord with the records prior to such work. The
foregoing provisions of this section shall not apply to emergency work made
necessary by accidents or other unforeseen conditions requiring immediate
action to prevent damage to persons or property, but the company shall promptly
report the nature and extent of any such work to the City, shall secure the
written approval of work which has been done and shall deposit the estimated
cost of inspection, supervision, refilling, repairing, repaving, etc., as
required by this chapter.
(Ord. 3840. Passed 11-4-46.)
   921.04  PLANNING REQUIREMENTS.
   The plans for the work or structures of any company in the streets or public
grounds shall show by scale of sufficient size to determine locations within
one foot or by dimensions, the accurate location, size and depth of structures
proposed to be built in relation to street lines and grade or monuments or to
semipermanent structures such as curbs, sidewalks or buildings. The City may
require that accurate surveys be made before or during construction. Pipe
conduits, duct lines and water mains shall, in general, follow lines parallel
to street and grade lines. Sewers shall, in general, follow lines parallel with
street lines and be on a grade satisfactory to the City. All such construction
shall be at a depth satisfactory to the City. Such construction shall not be so
laid as to obstruct or reduce the size of any culvert, storm sewer or similar
structure. Service connections shall, in general, be laid on lines which are
radial or at right angles to street lines. Special structures shall be detailed
to the satisfaction of the City.
(Ord. 3840. Passed 11-4-46.)
   921.05  SUPERVISION BY CITY; DEPOSITS.
   All work done and structures built in streets and public grounds shall be
under the inspection and supervision of the City to the extent that it may deem
necessary to protect the public interest. Before starting any work the company
shall deposit with the City a satisfactory amount to cover the estimated cost
of inspection, supervision, refilling, repaving, repairing and any other
expenses that may be incurred by the City in connection with the proposed work.
The City may, from time to time, require that additional deposits be made if it
is found that the expenses incurred will be in excess of the amount on deposit.
If deposits are not made promptly on demand of the City, all work may be
stopped by order of the City until such demands are satisfied and any expense
occasioned by such delay shall be borne by the company. Any balance remaining
after the completion of the work shall be refunded to the company.
(Ord. 3840. Passed 11-4-46.)
   921.06  WORK REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   The work of the company shall be first class in every respect. The
City shall have the right to insist that all work be performed by competent
foremen and workmen and may require that any company employees doing
unsatisfactory work be removed. All structures shall be constructed in a
workmanlike manner, true to line, grade and dimensions, and of ample strength
to withstand all anticipated loads and stresses. The City may require that
unsatisfactory structures be rebuilt. Materials shall be entirely suitable for
the structures contemplated; they shall be so delivered and stored as to give
least inconvenience to the public and shall be used within a reasonable time
after delivery.
   (b)   Excavation for structures shall be so conducted as to keep
interference with other uses of streets and public grounds to a minimum and
shall be subject to City control as to location and extent. Suitable bridges
over trenches at street intersections and at other locations where they are
deemed necessary shall be required by the City. Excavation in general shall be
open trench and tunnelling will be permitted only in specific locations
approved by the City. Structures of the City and other companies encountered
during work shall be called to the attention of the City promptly and all
necessary precautions taken to protect them. No such structures shall be
disturbed until the authorization of the owner is secured. The City may require
such bracing, sheeting, footing and other measures as are deemed necessary to
protect structures.
   (c)   Backfilling of excavations shall be done by the company under the
direction of the Director of Service and shall follow the completion of work as
closely as possible. The backfilling shall be made with sand well puddled and
tamped, and material taken from the trench shall be removed and not used for
backfilling.
   (d)   Temporary paving of brick shall be constructed by the company on
backfills within the paved portion of any street, and such temporary pavement
shall be maintained by the City, such construction and maintenance to be at the
contractor's expense. When, in the opinion of the Director of Service, the
backfill has fully settled, the temporary paving shall be removed and permanent
repairs made by the City at the company's expense. If the deposits above
mentioned are insufficient to cover the costs, the balance shall be collected
from the company. If more has been deposited than is needed, the balance shall
be refunded to the company.
   (e)   Curbing, walks, drives and other City structures removed or disturbed
during work shall be replaced by the City at the expense of the company unless
otherwise provided at the time the permit is granted. If the company is
permitted to do any part of such replacement work it must be done under City
inspection. Pavement base shall be of at least two inches greater thickness and
two inches wider than the base removed. Concrete shall have adequate steel
reinforcement to the satisfaction of the City. Pavement surface shall be of the
same type as the surface removed except by written permission of the City. In
general, replaced structures shall be of greater thickness, strength and
durability than the original structures to compensate for possible subsurface
settlements, or failures, for difficulty in bonding old and new work, and for
structural weakening due to loss of homogeneity.
   (f)   Wooden poles carrying wires or cables shall be of one piece and shall
not be extended in length or height by splicing, bolting or otherwise fastening
thereto any other piece of wood or metal.
   (g)   In an emergency the City may enter upon any work and execute such
measures as may be necessary to prevent loss of life or serious damage to
property or persons. Any costs arising out of such emergency work will in
general be borne by the company.
   
   921.07  LIABILITY OF PERSONS WORKING ON OR UNDER PUBLIC WAYS OR GROUNDS.
   (a)   The company shall construct and maintain its structures in accordance
with good standard practice and shall be liable for any damage to persons or
property occasioned by improper work, maintenance or negligence. Settlement of
pavement, walks, curb lawns or structures over or adjacent to recently
completed work will, unless satisfactory contrary evidence is presented, be
regarded as due to such work and the company responsible shall pay the cost of
any repairs or replacements that may be necessary. The City shall order such
maintenance as is deemed necessary in the interest of public safety and in
accordance with the terms under which such structures have been erected. Upon
the failure of the company to comply with such order the City may cause such
work to be done at the expense of the company.
   (b)   The company shall furnish and maintain all lights, barricades and all
other materials or appliances that may be required for the safety and
protection of the public or of the workmen who may be employed on or about the
work, and will save the City harmless and free and clear of all loss or damages
by reason of any negligence or failure on the part of the company to properly
protect and safeguard the public or its workmen.
(Ord. 3840. Passed 11-4-46.)
   921.08  CORRECTIONS.
   The City may require that the company promptly report any dangerous
condition or practice and remove, alter or otherwise make satisfactory any
structure which may cause damage to persons or property. The City may require
the relocation or rebuilding of structures in the interest of public
convenience, the facilitation of traffic, or similar needs. Any such work shall
be done at the expense of the company.
(Ord. 3840. Passed 11-4-46.)
   921.09  BONDS.
   The City may require such bonds or sureties as are necessary to protect the
public interest and to save the City harmless from any liability for damage to
persons or property which may be occasioned by the work or structures of the
company. The amount of such bonds or sureties shall be determined by the City.
(Ord. 3840. Passed 11-4-46.)
   921.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree and shall be fined not
more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or imprisoned not more than
thirty days, or both, if an individual, and shall be fined not more than two
thousand dollars ($2,000), if an organization, subject to the provisions of
Sections
606.08 and
606.09 of the General Offenses Code, for each offense. A separate offense shall
be deemed committed each day during or on which a violation or noncompliance
occurs or continues.

   925.01  RENTAL CHARGES.
   Council finds that the City has heretofore installed a system of sewerage
for public use in the City. Council further finds that it is necessary to
provide for the cost of the management, maintenance, operation and repair of
the sewerage system above-mentioned by the establishment and collection of a
rate or charge of rents for those purposes and an additional charge of rents
for meeting the obligations imposed by the Clean Water Act for improving the
sewerage system as required by the Northeast Ohio Regional Sewer District. 
Council further finds that a rate of one hundred seventeen dollars and fifty
cents ($117.50) per year for each lot or parcel of land on which is situated a
single-family residence having a connection to a sanitary sewer, except as
herein provided, is a just and equitable charge or rate to be paid to the City
for the use of the system of sewerage above- mentioned, and said rate and
charge are hereby established.  In the case of a two-family residence and
multiple dwellings, a charge of one hundred seventeen dollars and fifty cents
($117.50) per year for each living unit, as determined by the Commissioner of
Buildings in accordance with the definitions and standards provided in the
Zoning Code, shall be made.  In the case of retail, office building and
commercial property, a charge of sixty five dollars ($65.00) per year for each
commode or urinal shall be made, with a minimum charge of one hundred seventeen
dollars and fifty cents ($117.50). For churches and schools, the annual charge
shall be thirty eight dollars and seventy five cents ($38.75) per year for each
urinal or commode in said buildings.
(Ord.  2019-52.  Passed 8-5-19.)
   925.02  PAYMENT OF CHARGES, REMEDY FOR NONPAYMENT.
   (a)     The rates and charges shall be due and payable upon the taking
effect of this section, and if not so paid shall be certified to the Fiscal
Officer of the County and shall be collected in the same manner as other City
taxes upon the tax duplicate for the years 2020, 2021, and 2022.
   (b)     The rates and charges herein provided, whether paid directly or
collected with taxes, shall be paid to the Director of Finance of the City and
shall be placed by the Director of Finance in separate funds and expended for
the purposes authorized by law. A portion of the assessment shall be used for
the purpose of maintenance and repair of Sewers in the City, and the remaining
portion of the assessment shall be used for the purpose of meeting the Clean
Water Act requirements imposed by the Federal Government and enforced by the
Northeast Ohio Regional Sewer District. The portions of the assessment
allocated to each fund shall be determined annually by Council by Ordinance.
(Ord.  2019-52.  Passed 8-5-19.)
   925.03  SPECIFICATIONS.
   (a)   Specifications for Joints for Sanitary and Storm House Connections.
The materials used for jointing clay pipe used for sanitary and storm house
connections shall be composed of natural rubber, neoprene or plasticized resins
of polyvinyl chloride with characteristics similar to those of rubber, or
rubber used in conjunction with epoxy resins, polyvinyls or sulphur silica, or
other suitable combinations of such materials as approved by the Building
Commissioner.  The respective components of the jointing connections which are
designed to be affixed to the pipe shall be so bounded at the factory.  All
jointing materials included under this specification shall comply with the
specifications of the American Society for Testing and Materials (A.S.T.M.) for
vitrified clay pipe joints, using materials having resilient properties,
designation C 425-58T, and any amendments thereto.  The lubricant which may be
required shall be as furnished or recommended by the manufacturer of the
jointing material. 
(Ord. 61-102.  Passed 11-20-61.)
   (b)   Specifications for Stoppers for Sanitary and Storm Sewer Test Tees. 
Risers for test tees for all sanitary and storm sewer house connections shall
be closed at the top with a cast-iron stopper.  Cast-iron stoppers shall be
manufactured from gray cast-iron, conforming to American Society for Testing
and Materials (A.S.T.M.) Specification A-48-56, and any amendments thereto. 
Stoppers shall be three-eighths inch thick.  Edges shall be chipped and
ground.  Stoppers for six-inch risers shall have a diameter of seven and one-
half inches.  Stoppers for five-inch risers shall have a diameter of six and
one-half inches.  Risers for the test tees shall be at or within six inches of
the finished grade.
(Ord. 73-7.  Passed 1-15-73.)
   (c)   Lengths of Clay Pipe Used for Sanitary and Storm Sewer House
Connections.  All vitrified clay pipe used for sanitary and storm sewer house
connections shall be in lengths of not less than three feet.
(Ord. 61-102.  Passed 11-20-61.)
   925.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree and shall be fined not
more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or imprisoned not more than
thirty days, or both, if an individual, and shall be fined not more than two
thousand dollars ($2,000), if an organization, subject to the provisions of
Sections
606.08 and
606.09 of the General Offenses Code, for each offense.  A separate offense
shall be deemed committed each day during or on which a violation or
noncompliance occurs or continues.

   927.01  LIGHT SHIELD FEE.
   The Director of Finance is hereby authorized and directed to receive a fee
from a benefitting property owner or resident applicant for a light shield in
the vicinity of his or her property or residence. The amount of such fee shall
be the charge made by the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company to the City
for such shield and installation.
The shields will be installed on light fixtures for street lighting only when
authorized by Council upon oral motion made and passed, in each instance.
(Ord. 66-39. Passed 5-16-66.)
   927.02  STREET LIGHTING ASSESSMENTS.
   (a)   The Director of Finance shall cause the charges and assessments to be
made as hereinafter provided for all streets in the City which are lighted with
electric lights for the tax years 1993, 1994 and 1995 for collection in the
years 1994, 1995 and 1996.  The Director of Service shall certify to the
Director of Finance, as he or she may require, a list of streets in the City
which have no lights prior to the time that the assessments herein provided for
are certified to the County Auditor as provided in subsection (d) hereof.
   (b)   The cost and expense of such lighting shall be assessed upon the
property abutting upon such streets, public roads or parts thereof, served by
such lighting, excluding, however, 100 feet of side yards or side properties
measured from an intersecting street.
   (c)   Such assessments are fixed on the above named streets and roads and
portions thereof at the rate of thirty-two cents (32¢) per linear foot per year
for single-family residences, two-family residences and church and school
properties abutting upon such streets, roads or portions thereof and served by
such lights.
   (d)   Underground fed street lighting for single-family residences and two-
family residences abutting upon such streets, roads or portions thereof and
served by such lights shall be assessed at the rate of seventy-eight cents
(78¢) per linear foot, except for those properties abutting on Acacia Park
Drive, which shall be assessed at the same rate as commercial property. Such
rate shall be an annual charge.
   (e)   Such assessments are fixed at the rate of two dollars and seventy
cents ($2.70) per linear foot per year for commercial and all other types of
property abutting upon such streets, roads or portions thereof and served by
such lights, unless otherwise herein provided for.
   (f)   The assessment charge against each sublot or parcel of land shall be
certified by the Clerk of Council to the County Auditor as provided by law. The
County Auditor shall place such charge on the tax duplicate and collect the
same as other taxes.
(Ord. 93-74.  Passed 7-6-93.)

CHAPTER 951
Garbage and Rubbish Collection and Disposal
   EDITOR'S NOTE:  Ordinance 94-15, passed February 7, 1995, approved the fees
to be levied by the Solid Waste Management Policy Committee of the County Solid
Waste Management District on the generation of solid waste within the
District.  Copies of such ordinance may be obtained, at cost, from the Clerk of

Management Plan Update, 2001 - 2015, of the Cuyahoga County Solid Waste

951.01   Definitions.

   951.01  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and
their derivations shall have the meanings given herein. When not inconsistent
with the context, words used in the present tense shall include the future;
words used in the plural number include the singular number; and words in the
singular number include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory
and not merely directory.
   (a)   "City" means the City of Lyndhurst, Ohio.
   (b)   "Commercial establishment" means all properties upon which a profit-
making enterprise is conducted, including, but not necessarily limited to, uses
defined in Section
1168.03 of the Planning and Zoning Code. A commercial establishment which also
serves as the principal residence of the proprietor of such establishment
shall, for the purposes of this chapter, be considered a residence.
   (c)   "Director" means the Service Director of the City.
   (d)   "Garbage" means all the putrescible waste, except sewage and body
waste, including vegetable and animal offal and carcasses of small dead
animals, but excluding recognizable industrial by-products, and includes all
such substances from all public and private establishments and from all
residences.
   (e)   "Nonprofit organization" means eleemosynary organizations, including,
but not necessarily limited to, organizations exempt from taxation under
Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1954, as amended.
   (f)   "Premises" means land or buildings or both, or parts of either or
both, used either as a residence or by a nonprofit organization or commercial
establishment.
   (g)   "Residence" means all privately-owned residential properties, either
single or multi-family, including condominiums, but excluding commercially
operated apartment houses.
   (h)   "Rubbish" means ashes, bottles, broken glass, crockery, tin cans, cast
iron, printed matter, paper, boots, shoes, hats and other clothing. It does
not, however, include any material in the nature of earth, sand, brick, stone,
plaster or other substances that may accumulate as a result of building
operations.
   (i)   "School" means nonprofit public institutions and private institutions
providing the equivalent of nonprofit public education accredited by the State
Board of Education.  (Ord. 84-22. Passed 5-7-84.)
   951.02  RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Mayor shall, subject to the approval of Council, make rules and
regulations for the collection and disposal of garbage and rubbish within the
City. The following regulations are in codified form for which the penalty of
Section
951.99 is applicable.
   (a)       Garbage, rubbish, recyclables and yard waste shall not be placed
on the tree lawn or curb before 5:00 p.m. on the day prior to collection day,
and not later than 7:00 a.m. of collection day. When holidays change a regular
collection day, garbage and rubbish shall be placed for pickup on the next
working day. When equipment breakdown or weather conditions delay pickup,
garbage and rubbish may remain on the tree lawn for pickup on the following
working day.
   (b)   All empty containers must be removed from the tree lawn the day
rubbish is collected.
   (c)   Containers shall be City issued automated collection carts or approved
containers.
   (d)   All leaves, grass and other organic yard waste shall be placed in
approved paper (biodegradable) yard waste disposal bags. While the fall leaf
pickup program is in progress, leaves may be placed on the tree lawn. Placing
or burning of leaves in the street gutter at any time is prohibited.
   (e)   Large cardboard boxes must be collapsed and should be placed in
recycling containers.  If the recycling container is full, additional cardboard
must be collapsed and tied in bundles weighing not more than forty pounds and
not more than four feet in length and placed next to the recycling container.
   (f)   Newspapers and magazines must be placed in a recycling container.
   (g)   Lumber, tree and hedge trimmings must be cut and bundled so that
bundles are not longer than four feet or greater than eighteen inches in
diameter and not to exceed forty pounds. Larger branches (up to 6" inches truck
diameter) must be stacked neatly on the treelawn for collection on the normal
day of pick up.
   (h)   Private contractors performing any repair or construction work in the
City are required to dispose of any rubbish generated by their activities.
Residents are also required to make their own arrangements for disposal of any
toxic or hazardous waste materials.
   (i)   All grass clippings, hedges, shrubs, weeds and similar yard waste must
be disposed of by one of the following methods:
      (1)   Allow the clippings to remain on the lawn;
      (2)   Compost shall be within one's own property using proper composting 
methods;
      (3)   Bag all such yard waste in bags designated by the City for such
use, according to the rules and regulations of the City, as authorized by this
section, for curbside pick-up or delivery to the City service yard for disposal
according to City regulations;
   The bags referred to in paragraph (i)(3) hereof shall be biodegradable paper
bags.
(Ord. 2009-72.  Passed 10-5-09.)
   951.03  MANAGEMENT AND SUPERVISION OF SERVICE.
   It shall be the duty of the Director to manage and supervise the collection
of garbage and rubbish from residences, schools and nonprofit organizations
within the City. Collections shall be made at such periods as may be prescribed
by rules of the Department of Service under the supervision of the Director.
The Director shall also manage and supervise the hauling and disposal of such
garbage and rubbish to disposal plants or landfills, subject to the approval of
the Mayor and Council and shall, likewise, manage and supervise the operation
of such plants or landfills as the City may own for the disposal of garbage or
rubbish.
(Ord. 84-22. Passed 5-7-84.)
   951.04  COMMERCIAL ESTABLISHMENTS.
   All commercial establishments shall procure the services of a private hauler
to dispose of their garbage and rubbish. Pick-ups and disposal shall be made
with such frequency as to prevent an unreasonable accumulation of garbage and
rubbish endangering the public health and welfare, and any unreasonable
accumulations are hereby declared to be a nuisance.
(Ord. 84-22. Passed 5-7-84.)
   951.05  REMOVAL OF CONTENTS.
   (a)   Contents of any receptacles for garbage or rubbish shall not be
removed in any manner or at any time so as to be or constitute a nuisance.
   (b)   No person, except a recognized charitable or civic organization, upon
approval by the Mayor, shall engage in scavenging garbage or rubbish set out by
property owners or occupants for private or public collection, whether such
refuse is in containers or not. Refuse so deposited for collection is deemed to
be the property of the City or private hauler, as the case may be, for their
purposes when so placed.
(Ord. 84-22. Passed 5-7-84.)
   951.06  LOCATION OF RECEPTACLES.
   No person shall place or maintain any receptacle for garbage or rubbish so
that it will be or constitute a nuisance. Receptacles for one, two, and three
family dwellings shall be located within a garage or other enclosed non-
habitable space, such as a storage shed.  Garbage or rubbish within closed
receptacles or containers may be placed along the side or rear of the home
being served.  Receptacles and/or containers shall not be placed within the
front yard setback, which is the entire area from the sidewalk to the front of
the structure.
(Ord. 2009-72.  Passed 10-5-09.)
   951.07  PRIVATE COLLECTION PRACTICES.
   (a)   All commercial establishments subject to private collection shall
maintain, in a clean and sanitary condition, garbage and rubbish containers
which shall have tight-fitting covers and be watertight. The capacity of such
containers shall be as determined by the private hauler.
   (b)   All private haulers shall use a watertight vehicle provided with a
tight cover, and so operated as to prevent offensive odors from escaping
therefrom and refuse from being blown, dropped or spilled.
(Ord. 84-22. Passed 5-7-84.)
   951.08  RECORDS.
   The Department of Service shall keep a permanent record showing the cost of
equipment and the cost of expenses for the work, labor and materials necessary
for the collection and disposal of such garbage and rubbish by the City within
the funds available and duly appropriated by Council each year for such
purposes.
(Ord. 84-22. Passed 5-7-84.)
   951.09  HOURS OF COLLECTION AND TRANSPORTATION.
   No person owning or driving a vehicle hauling solid waste shall cause the
collection, transportation or transfer of such waste other than between the
hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m.  No collection, transportation or transfer
shall occur on Saturday after 4:00 p.m. or on Sunday.  Application for
exceptions to this provision may be made to the Service Director, on a form
provided by the Director.  Such exceptions shall be granted only where the
applicant is able to demonstrate circumstances of great practical difficulty in
the collection and transportation of solid waste in areas where there is heavy
daytime vehicular and pedestrian traffic and a concentration of commercial
activity. 
(Ord. 2007-44.  Passed 6-4-07.)
   951.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree and shall be fined not
more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or imprisoned not more than
thirty days, or both, if an individual, and shall be fined not more than two
thousand dollars ($2,000), if an organization, subject to the provisions of
Sections
606.08 and
606.09 of the General Offenses Code, for each offense.  A separate offense
shall be deemed committed each day during or on which a violation or
noncompliance occurs or continues.
