   955.01  CURFEW; INTOXICATING LIQUORS.
   (a)   No person shall enter or remain in any Municipal park after dark or
during darkness, except for authorized use of park facilities.  Authorized use
of park facilities applies to tennis courts, swimming pools, pavilions or
permitted use of park areas by groups or organizations when approved and
supervised by the Director of Safety.  Park area use permits shall be granted
by the Director.  Pavilion permits may be granted upon written application and
payment of the fees required, if any, in Chapter
953.
(Ord. 71-36.  Passed 7-6-71.)
   (b)   No person shall have in his or her possession any intoxicating
beverage, including malt beverages, while in a Municipal park.
   (c)   Subsection (a) hereof shall not be effective for prohibiting persons
to enter upon Municipal park grounds unless the time limits herein provided are
conspicuously posted upon the park premises.
(Ord. 70-48.  Passed 7-6-70.)
   955.02  APPLICATION OF CHAPTER.
   Any park authorized by Council after review by the Board of Zoning Appeals
is subject to the provisions of this chapter, except as otherwise provided in
the various authorization therefor and the public uses thereof.
   955.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree and shall be fined not
more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or imprisoned not more than
thirty days, or both, if an individual, and shall be fined not more than two
thousand dollars ($2,000), if an organization, subject to the provisions of
Sections
606.08 and
606.09 of the General Offenses Code, for each offense.  A separate offense
shall be deemed committed each day during or on which a violation or
noncompliance occurs or continues.
                                                                               
                   
CHAPTER 957
Municipal Swimming Pools
   EDITOR'S NOTE:  Because of the frequency of change, provisions relating to
swimming pool fees, personnel and incidents of their employment are not
codified.  Copies of the latest relevant legislation may be obtained, at cost,
from the Clerk of Council.
957.01   Supervision.
957.02   Admission fees; season passes; and special programs.
957.03   Pool regulations.
957.04   Petty cash.
957.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
   Parks and recreation - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 755
   Recreation Commission - see ADM. Ch.
183
   Pavilion in Lyndhurst City Park and Municipal Center Community  Room - see 
S. & P.S. Ch.
953
   Community Center - see S. & P.S. Ch.
954
   Municipal parks - see S. & P.S. Ch.
955
   Baseball fields - see S. & P.S. Ch.
959
   957.01  SUPERVISION.
   The Mayor shall supervise the management and operation of the Municipal
swimming pools, in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, and shall
appoint, promote, transfer, reduce or remove all personnel and employees
necessary for such management and operation.  The Mayor may delegate such
management and operation to the South Euclid-Lyndhurst Recreation Board.
(Ord. 4816.  Passed 6-20-55.)
   957.02  ADMISSION FEES; SEASON PASSES; AND SPECIAL PROGRAMS.
      (a)    Single full access season swim passes to both Lyndhurst Pool and
Brainard Spray Park for residents of the City of Lyndhurst for each season
commencing with the swimming season 2020 shall be sixty-five dollars ($65.00)
each with a maximum cost of one hundred eighty dollars ($180.00) per "Family"
living in the same household.  No additional charge will be made for passes
purchased after pool opening.  Passes shall be issued in the name of a specific
person and be non transferable.
      Season passes shall not be sold to any child under the age of four (4)
unless such child will be four (4) by the end of the third learn to swim
session. All children under the age of four (4) will be admitted free but must
be accompanied by an adult who has a season pass or pays admission or by a
related or non-related young adult fourteen (14) years to seventeen (17) years
of age, with a note or request signed by the parent or guardian. In the
interest of safety, children under the age of eleven (11) must be accompanied
by an adult or young adult at all times. Each child must use either the baby
pool or the large pool but must be accompanied as provided herein.
      "Family", as used in this section, means the members of a household
living as a single housekeeping unit in a dwelling unit who are related to the
nominal head of the household or to the spouse of the nominal head of the
household, and includes:
      (1)   Husband or wife of the nominal head of the household.         
      (2)   Unmarried children (23 years or under) of the nominal head of the
household or of the spouse of the nominal head of the household provided,
however, that such unmarried children have no children residing with them.     
   
   Upon presenting proper identification, non-residents may purchase an
individual pass for one hundred dollars ($100.00) with a family cost of three
hundred sixty-five dollars ($365.00) per family living in the same household. 
This provision regarding non-resident admissions may be modified or eliminated
permanently or temporarily by the Mayor, upon the advice of the Pool Director.
   (b)    Single admission pool fee shall be six dollars ($6.00) per person:
Guests shall sign their names into a registration book provided for guests. 
Each non-resident paying a single admission must be accompanied by a Lyndhurst
resident.
   Single admission Brainard Spray Park fee for Lyndhurst residents shall be
three dollars ($3.00) per person.  Guests shall sign their name into a
registration book provided for guests.  Single admission fees for non-residents
shall be six dollars ($6.00) per person.
   Any provision regarding non-resident admissions may be modified or
eliminated permanently or temporarily by the Mayor, upon the advice of the Pool
Director.
   The regular season shall begin in June, as determined by the City, and
continue through Labor Day.
   (c)   Regular season pass holders who are residents of the City of Lyndhurst
may participate in the Learn To Swim program by purchasing a Learn To Swim pass
for  twenty dollars ($20.00) per individual Learn To Swim course based on two
and one-half (2-1/2) week sessions.  The fee for the Learn-to-Swim Pass will be
waived for any season pass holder who is considered as disabled pursuant to the
guidelines of the Federal Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. Swim team
fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) per child for the 2019 season and sixty
dollars ($60.00) per child for the 2020 season paid to the City.
   Pool employees required to pay for lifeguard training shall be reimbursed up
to two hundred dollars ($200.00) (which includes the Red Cross Fees) per
person.
   Adult Baby Water Adjustment training for children, ages six months thru
three years, is authorized at the rate of twenty dollars ($20.00) for each two
and one half week session.  A season pass is required of the parent who must
accompany the child.  No pass or admission fee is required of the child.
   (d)   Private parties hosted by a Lyndhurst resident at the Lyndhurst Pool
or Brainard Spray Park will be authorized during the hours of 8:30 p.m. to l0:
30 p.m. on Friday or Saturday and 6:30 p.m. to 8:30 p.m. on Sundays unless
otherwise authorized by the Pool Director.  A charge of one hundred fifty
dollars ($150.00) for Brainard Spray Park and two hundred sixty dollars
($260.00) for Lyndhurst pool for up to one hundred fifty (150) people is hereby
established. Parties for over one hundred fifty (150) people may be allowed
upon approval of the Pool Director and Mayor; additional fees may apply.  If
the Lyndhurst Pool or Brainard Spray Park is closed due to rain or cold weather
on the scheduled pool party date, another date may be selected or a refund
given at the discretion of the Mayor.  Additional swimming times for pool
personnel and private parties shall be permitted during such times after
regular hours as permitted by the Mayor and Pool Director.
   A deposit of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be required for each private party
to reserve availability of the pool. If the private party is cancelled without
selecting another date, the deposit will be forfeited. If another date is
selected, and said date is acceptable to the City, the deposit will be
transferred to cover the second date.  After the private party, the deposit
will also be applied against the cost of repairing any damage caused by persons
attending said party.  In the event of damage, the fifty dollar ($50.00)
deposit will be applied to the payment of the cost of repairs, and any unused
portion will be refunded.  In addition, said deposit may be forfeited in
increments of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each fifteen (15) minutes, or
part thereof, that a party exceeds the established ending time for use of the
facilities. No more than three hundred (300) people shall be permitted at a
private party.
   All regulations currently in effect and as required by Ordinance for the use
of the pools are applicable to private parties except that food and non
alcoholic beverages may be brought upon the premises for such parties in
compliance with rules and regulations to be promulgated by the Lyndhurst Pool
Director. Such rules and regulations shall not be effective until approved by
motion of Council.  A person twenty one (2l) years of age or older shall be
present at the private party and responsible for the conduct of persons present
and any damages to property.
   (e)   A free swimming pass shall be issued to Lyndhurst residents sixty (60)
years of age or older.  Appropriate identification shall be required of the
residency of  such applicant, and the pass issued to such person shall not be
transferable.
   City employees, upon presentation of City employee identification, shall be
issued a pool pass free of charge.
   (f)   There shall be a charge of five dollars ($5.00) for replacement of a
lost pass.
   (g)   Refunds for any reason of any fees or charges imposed by this
Ordinance may be made at the discretion of the Mayor.
   
   (h)   A free single swimming pass and a free caregiver pass shall be issued
to an individual with a disability.  "Disabled" shall be defined in accordance
with the Federal Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (42 U.S.C. 12131 et
seq.).
   (i)   Section
955.01(b) of the Codified Ordinances regarding intoxicating beverages shall be
strictly enforced at the pool and spray park.
(Ord.  2020-22.  Passed 3-16-20.)
   957.03  POOL REGULATIONS.
   Swimming pool rules and regulations shall be established by the Mayor and
the Pool Director and shall be approved annually by Council.
(Ord. 82-37.  Passed 7-6-82.)
   957.04  PETTY CASH.
   The Director of Finance is hereby authorized and directed to disburse to the
Pool Managers the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) to be used by them as a petty
cash fund for the purpose of making change.  The Pool Managers may be required
to give an accounting of such funds at such reasonable times as the Director
may required.
(Ord. 57-73.  Passed 6-20-57.)
   957.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree and shall be fined not
more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or imprisoned not more than
thirty days, or both, if an individual, and shall be fined not more than two
thousand dollars ($2,000), if an organization, subject to the provisions of
Sections
606.08 and
 606.09 of the General Offenses Code, for each offense.  A separate offense
shall be deemed committed each day during or on which a violation or
noncompliance occurs or continues.   
                                                                               
                   
CHAPTER 959
Baseball Fields
959.01   Priorities; permits required.
959.02   Issuance of permits; contents.
959.03   Regulations governing issuance of permits.
959.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
   Parks and recreation - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 755
   Recreation Commission - see ADM. Ch.
183
   Pavilion in Lyndhurst City Park and Municipal Center Community Room - see
S.U. & P.S. Ch.
953
   Municipal parks - see S.U. & P.S. Ch.
955
   Municipal swimming pools - see S.U. & P.S. Ch.

   959.01  PRIORITIES; PERMITS REQUIRED.
   Priority in the use of the baseball fields owned by the City shall hereafter
be established by permits which shall be issued by the Director of the South
Euclid-Lyndhurst Recreation Board. 
(Ord. 4798. Passed 4-18-55.)
   959.02  ISSUANCE OF PERMITS; CONTENTS.
   Permits issued pursuant to Section
959.01 shall be issued in triplicate. One copy shall be retained by the
Director of the South Euclid-Lyndhurst Recreation Board, one shall be delivered
to the City of Lyndhurst and one shall be issued to the applicant. Each permit
shall include the name of the organization requesting the permit, the date the
permit is issued, the field to be used, the time the field may be used under
the permit and the name of the person in charge. The permit shall also contain
the signature of the Director.
(Ord. 4798. Passed 4-18-55.)
   959.03  REGULATIONS GOVERNING ISSUANCE OF PERMITS.
   The following regulations shall govern the issuance of permits for baseball
fields owned by the City:
   (a)   School activities shall have first priority.
   (b)   Permits shall be issued only on written requests from a group desiring
a particular field or play area, such request to be signed by the adult in
charge of the group.
   (c)   Groups must be under the supervision of an adult while using the area.
   (d)   There shall be no fencing of diamonds on City property if it
interferes with the use of other diamonds.
   (e)   All cars shall be kept off of playground areas and parked in
designated parking lots. The parking lot around the City Hall shall not be
considered as an authorized parking lot for baseball purposes.
   (f)   Organizations to which permits are issued shall be responsible for and
pay for any damage while using the area.
   (g)   Permits will be canceled unless the above regulations are adhered to.
      (Ord. 4798. Passed 4-18-55.)
   959.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree and shall be fined not
more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or imprisoned not more than
thirty days, or both, if an individual, and shall be fined not more than two
thousand dollars ($2,000), if an organization, subject to the provisions of
Sections
606.08 and
606.09 of the General Offenses Code, for each offense.  A separate offense
shall be deemed committed each day during or on which a violation or
noncompliance occurs or continues.
                                                                               
                     
CHAPTER 960
Skateboard Park Rules and Regulations
960.01   Hours of operation.
960.02   Skateboard Park rules and regulations.
960.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Toy vehicles on roadways - see TRAF.
412.04
   960.01  HOURS OF OPERATION.
   The Skateboard Park will generally be open for use from April 15 through
September 30 of each year. The hours of operation shall generally be from April
15 through June 15, 3:30 p.m. to 6:30 p.m. weekdays and 10:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m.
(or until dusk if earlier) weekends; from June 16 through August 15 from 10:00
a.m. to 8:00 p.m. weekdays and weekends; from August 16 through September 30,
3:30 p.m. to 6:30 p.m. weekdays and 10:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. (or dusk if
earlier) weekends.  All days and times of operation are subject to change
without notice at the discretion of the City.
(Ord. 2004-24.  Passed 4-19-04.)
   960.02  SKATEBOARD PARK RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The following rules and regulations shall govern use of the Skateboard Park
in the City:
   (a)   This is a high-risk activity and may result in accident or injury,
therefore, use of this facility is at your own risk.  Users accept such
liability and all risk when using this facility;
   (b)   Only one (1) person at a time allowed on equipment;
   (c)   Fair weather use only.  Area closed if wet, icy or snowy at any time
at the discretion of the City;
   (d)   Maintain all surfaces free of litter;
   (e)   No boom boxes or offensive language permitted;
   (f)   No food, drink or smoking permitted;  no glass containers of any kind
permitted;
   (g)   Required safety equipment (not provided by the City) which must be
worn at all times: tennis or rubber-soled shoes (no bare feet), helmet, elbow
and kneepads;
   (h)   Recommended safety equipment (not provided by the City): shoulder and
hip pads and wrist supports;
   (i)   Bicycles, scooters, and other vehicles are to remain outside the
fenced area.
   (j)   Know your ability, skate safely.
   (k)   All users are responsible for providing their own skateboard, skates,
or equipment and for insuring that they are maintained in good working
condition;
   (l)   The Municipality reserves the right to prohibit use of the facility
for individuals who are rowdy, abuse the facility or do not obey the rules and
regulations;
   (m)   Hours of permitted use of the Skateboard Park shall be posted at the
Park but are subject to change, without notice, at the sole discretion of the
City;
   (n)   No make-shift items or modifications to existing equipment are
permitted;
   (o)   In an emergency 911 should be contacted immediately and without delay;
   (p)   Skateboard Park shall not be used when it is closed.
   These rules and regulations are subject to change, including the addition of
new rules and regulations, at any time at the sole discretion of the City.  All
users must comply with all rules and regulations in effect at any given time
including any new or additional rules and regulations that may be adopted by
the City.  The Mayor and/or the Service Director is hereby authorized and
directed to cause the aforesaid rules and regulations to be posted at the
entrance to the Skateboard Park and shall further be responsible for opening
and closing the Skateboard Park according to the hours of operation specified
in this chapter, in general, which days and hours of operation may be changed,
without notice, at the discretion of the Mayor and/or Service Director.  At all
times that the Skateboard Park is not in operation, the Park shall be closed
and locked. 
(Ord. 2004-24.  Passed 4-19-04.)
   960.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree and should be fined not
more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or imprisoned not more than
thirty (30) days, or both, if an individual, and shall be fined not more than
two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) if an organization, subject to the provisions
of Section
606.08 and
606.09 of the General Offenses Code for each offense.  A separate offense shall
be deemed committed each day during or on which a violation or noncompliance
occurs or continues.
(Ord. 2004-24.  Passed 4-19-04.)
                                                                               
                     
CHAPTER 961
City Jail
961.01   Prisoner's meal allowance.
961.02   Use by other governmental agencies.
961.03   Medical care.
CROSS REFERENCES
   Jails - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 341
   Municipal correctional institutions - see Ohio R.C. 753.02 et seq.
   General Code penalty - see ADM.
101.99
   Municipal Court - see ADM. Ch.
197
   Traffic Code penalties - see TRAF. Ch.
408
   General Offenses Code penalties and sentencing - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
698
   961.01  PRISONER'S MEAL ALLOWANCE.
   The Chief of Police, or any member of the Police Department who may be
performing the duties of jailer, is hereby authorized and directed to expend a
sum not to exceed twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per day for each prisoner held
in the City Jail during such day, or a lesser amount for a part of such day as
determined necessary by the Chief of Police or his or her nominee to provide
nourishment for such prisoner.
(Ord. 2017-01.  Passed 1-3-17.)
   961.02  USE BY OTHER GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES.
   (a)   There is hereby established a rate of eighty-five dollars ($85.00) per
day for the use of the City Jail facilities for the housing of prisoners by
other governmental entities.
   (b)   The City Jail shall be made available to other governmental entities
on an emergency or temporary basis only and shall not be used by such other
entities on a contract or long-term basis.
   (c)   The Chief of Police or any administrative personnel of the Police
Department designated by him or her shall keep an accurate record of the use
made of the City Jail facilities by any other governmental entity and shall
advise the Director of Finance of the amount due therefor.
   (d)   The Director of Finance shall, upon receipt of notice of the use of
the City Jail and the amount to be charged, issue an invoice to the
governmental entity using the facilities.  The funds received therefrom shall
be deposited into the General Fund.
(Ord. 89-52.  Passed 4-17-89.)
   961.03  MEDICAL CARE.
   As regards medical care that a health care provider not employed by, or
under contract with, the City provides to a person who is imprisoned in an
institution under the control of, or who is in the custody of a law enforcement
officer of the City, both of the following apply:
   (a)   The City is not liable for medical care that is not medically
necessary;
   (b)   The City’s liability to pay or reimburse for medical care that is
medically necessary is limited to an amount equivalent to the amount Medicaid
would pay for the care provided if Medicaid covers the same kind of necessary
medical care.
   Medical care is medically necessary only if it is nonelective and a person
authorized under Chapter 4731 of the Ohio Revised Code to practice medicine and
surgery or osteopathic medicine and surgery determines that it cannot be
postponed until after a person is released from imprisonment or custody without
endangering the person’s life or health.
(Ord. 2009-4.  Passed 2-2-09.)

PART ELEVEN - PLANNING AND ZONING CODE
TITLE ONE - Planning
      Chap.

      Chap.

CHAPTER 1110
City Planning Commission
1110.01   Intent.
1110.02   Membership.
1110.03   Officers.

1110.05   Powers and duties.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Established - see CHTR.
Art. V, §6
      Membership, term and vacancy - see CHTR.

   1110.01  INTENT.
   The functions and purposes of the City Planning Commission are to consider
the plan, design, location, removal, relocation and alteration of any building
or structure within the city; the location, relocation, widening, extension and
vacation of streets, highways, playgrounds and other public places; the
approval of plats for the subdivision of land; the zoning of the City for any
lawful purpose or purposes; and the review and approval of conditional uses,
similar uses and development plans.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1110.02  MEMBERSHIP.
     The membership of the City Planning Commission shall be as provided in
Article V, Section 6, of the City Charter, i.e. the Mayor, one member of the
Council to be appointed by the Council, and three citizens of the City not
holding other Municipal office, appointed by the Mayor.  The Council
appointment shall be made at the organizational meeting of Council in January. 
If the Council appointee is unable to be present at a meeting, the Vice-Mayor
may appoint a replacement from Council for that meeting only, and the
replacement may vote on any matter on which the absent member is authorized to
vote.  Appointments of the citizen members shall be made for a period of six
years commencing with the expiration of existing terms.  A vacancy occurring
during the term of any member of the City Planning Commission shall be filled
for the unexpired term in the manner authorized for the original appointment.
(Ord. 2016-07.  Passed 4-4-16.)
   1110.03  OFFICERS.
   (a)   The officers of the City Planning Commission shall consist of a
Chairperson, who shall be the Mayor, and a Vice-Chairperson, who shall be the
Council representative.
   (b)   The Chairperson shall preside at all meetings of the Commission and
shall sign all documents, papers, minutes, reports and records pertaining to
the affairs and business of the Commission.  The Secretary shall attest to all
documents, papers, minutes, reports and records required herein to be signed by
the Chairperson. In the absence of the Chairperson, the Vice-Chairperson shall
perform the duties of the Chairperson.
   (c)   The Secretary of the Commission shall keep an official record, in the
form of minutes, of all the proceedings of the Commission and shall have charge
of the filing and preservation of all records, papers and other data belonging
to the Commission or its officers and, in addition, shall do and perform all
such other duties as may from time to time be required by the Commission.
   (d)   The Director of Law shall be the counsel of the Commission and as such
shall be the legal advisor and attorney for the Commission and attend to such
other correlated matters as may from time to time be delegated to him or her by
the Commission. 
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1110.04  MEETINGS.
   (a)       The regular meetings of the Commission shall be held at the City
Hall on the fourth Thursday of each month at 7:00 p.m., except that when such
day falls on a holiday, the meeting shall be rescheduled.  Special meetings
shall be held upon the call of the Chairperson, or in the absence of the
Chairperson, the Vice-Chairperson.
 
   (b)   A majority of the Commission shall constitute a quorum for the
transaction of business at any regular or special meeting of the Commission. 
Except as otherwise provided, Robert's Rules of Order shall be followed in the
conduct of the meetings of the Commission.
   (c)   Notices of the date, time and agenda of special meetings shall be
communicated to the Clerk of Council verbally or in writing, as such Clerk may
require, at least seventy-two hours in advance of such meeting, to permit such
Clerk to comply with the requirements of Ohio R.C. 121.22.  In the event of an
emergency requiring a meeting on less notice than is provided in Ohio R.C.
121.22(F), the person or persons calling such special meeting shall give notice
to the Clerk or the Clerk's office so that immediate notice may be given to the
news media which have  requested such notice.
   (d)   Persons desiring notices and agenda of meetings of the Commission, as
provided in Ohio R.C. 121.22, may deposit:
          (1)   Self-addressed, stamped envelopes with the Clerk of Council for
one year; or
            (2)       Two dollars ($2.00) if notice of only one meeting is
desired; or
            (3)       Twenty-four dollars ($24.00) for notices and agendas of
each meeting of the Commission for each calendar year.       
   (e)   If a regular meeting is not required because of the lack of public
business, a notice shall be posted to such effect, at least five days prior to
such meeting, on or in the vicinity of the bulletin board in the main lobby at
the Municipal Center.  Notice that a meeting is not required shall be given by
the Clerk of Council to all news media that have requested notices or to the
persons who have made the deposits referred to above. 
(Ord.  2019-54.  Passed 9-16-19.)
   1110.05  POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The City Planning Commission shall have the following authority:
   (a)    Pursuant to
Article V, Section 7, of the City Charter, the Planning Commission shall review
and make recommendations to the Council to approve, disapprove, or approve with
conditions, the following matters:
      (1)   The planning, design, location, removal, relocation and major
alteration of buildings or structures located in the City which require site
plan review;
      (2)   The location, relocation, widening, extension and vacation of
streets, highways, playgrounds and other public spaces;
      (3)    Plats for the subdivision of land; and
      (4)    The zoning or rezoning of the City for any lawful purpose or
purposes.
   (b)   In addition to the powers conferred by the City Charter, the Planning
Commission shall have the following powers and duties:
      (1)   To review and approve, disapprove, or approve with conditions, an
application for a conditional use for a particular zoning lot;
      (2)   To determine that a proposed use that is not explicitly listed or
provided for in the Zoning Code is substantially similar to a principal or
conditionally permitted use that is listed or provided for in this Zoning Code;
      (3)   To review proposed development plans in accordance with Chapters
1162,
1164 and
1166 of the Zoning Code;
      (4)   To review ordinances or proposed ordinances, regulations or plans
on its own volition or at the request of Council, including ordinances or
regulations to amend the Zoning Code and Zoning Map, and plans or studies with
respect to the use and/or development of land within the City;
      (5)   To adopt rules and bylaws for the holding of regular and special
meetings for the transaction and disposition of its business and the exercise
of its powers;
      (6)   To review the proposed change of a nonconforming use to another
nonconforming use of the same degree of nonconformity, as determined by the
most restricted district in which the existing nonconforming use is permitted. 
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)

   1112.01  ADOPTION; PERIODIC REVIEW.
   (a)   A document, consisting of text, maps and charts, entitled "City of
Lyndhurst Master Plan" and dated 1996, is hereby adopted as the Master Plan of
the City of Lyndhurst.  Copies of the Master Plan, as amended from time to time
by Council, may be obtained, at cost, from the Clerk of Council.  (Ord. 96-39. 
Passed 9-16-96.)
   (b)   In order to assure that the Master Plan shall at all times be current
with the needs of the City, and shall represent the then current best thinking
and planning of the Council and the Planning Commission and the boards,
commissions and departments of the City, in light of changing conditions, the
Planning Commission shall continue to periodically review the Master Plan and
recommend to Council any extensions, changes or additions to the Plan which the
Commission considers necessary. 
   (c)   All matters affecting the physical development of the City shall
continue to be submitted to the Planning Commission in compliance with City
laws, and where provided for in this Planning and Zoning Code, for a report
and/or recommendation to Council as to conformity with the Master Plan.  Such
report and/or recommendation shall be made to Council as provided for in this
Planning and Zoning Code.
(Ord. 98-50.  Passed 5-18-98.)

   1130.01  TITLE.
   This Title One of Part Eleven of these Codified Ordinances, and all
ordinances amending, explaining or supplementing the same, shall be known and
may be cited as the "City of Lyndhurst, Ohio, Subdivision Regulations" and
shall be referred to throughout this Title One as "these Subdivisions
Regulations" or just "these Regulations." 
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1130.02  AUTHORITY.
   These Regulations are adopted pursuant to the authority delegated to the
City of Lyndhurst, Ohio, under the Ohio Revised Code, including, but not
limited to, the statutes contained in Chapters 711 and 713, and the Lyndhurst
City Charter, including, but not limited to,
Article 5, Section 7.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1130.03  PURPOSE AND INTENT.
   The general purpose of these Regulations shall be to guide and regulate the
planning, subdividing and development of land in order to promote and protect
the public health, safety and general welfare.  It is intended that the
provisions of these Regulations shall be applied to achieve the following
objectives:
   (a)   The orderly development of land to obtain harmonious and stable
neighborhoods and the prevention of dead land or landlocked parcels which may
become neglected areas;
   (b)   The safe and convenient circulation of vehicles and pedestrians;
   (c)   The design of new subdivisions that will preserve natural features and
open spaces for recreation and other public purposes;
   (d)   The accurate surveying of land and the preparation and recording of
plats;
   (e)   The assurance that subdivision improvements are properly installed and
completed in compliance with the regulations contained in Chapters
1134 and
1136;
   (f)   The coordination of land development in accordance with the City of
Lyndhurst's Zoning Code, Zoning Map and other applicable City ordinances.
      (Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)   
   1130.04  INTERPRETATION.
   (a)   In their interpretation and application, the provisions of these
Regulations shall be held to be the minimum requirements for the promotion of
the public health, safety and general welfare.
   (b)   Except as specifically provided herein, it is not intended by these
Regulations to repeal, abrogate or annul any existing provisions of any law or
ordinance or any rule or regulation previously adopted or issued pursuant to
law, provided, however, that where these Regulations impose greater
restrictions than are imposed or required by other ordinances, rules,
regulations, permits, private easements, covenants or agreements, then the
provisions of these Regulations shall govern and to such extent only such other
ordinance or regulation is modified and amended.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1130.05  SCHEDULE OF FEES, CHARGES, EXPENSES AND GUARANTEES.
   Council shall establish a schedule of fees, charges, expenses and guarantees
and a collection procedure for the same.
   A schedule of such fees, charges, expenses and guarantees shall be made
available by the City and may be altered or amended only by Council.  Until all
such applicable fees, charges, expenses and guarantees have been paid in full,
no plat shall be entitled to be recorded with the Cuyahoga County Recorder.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1130.06  EFFECTIVE DATE.
   These Regulations shall become effective from and after the date of approval
and adoption as provided by law.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1130.07  REPEALER.
   Any Subdivision Regulations, or portions thereof, previously adopted by the
City, are hereby repealed.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1130.08  AMENDMENTS.
   These Regulations may be amended from time to time in the same manner and to
the same extent as originally adopted in accordance with the applicable
provisions of the laws of the City of Lyndhurst.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1130.09  SEPARABILITY.
   If, for any reason, any clause, sentence, paragraph, section or other part
of these Regulations should be determined by a court of competent jurisdiction
to be invalid, such judgment shall not affect the validity of these Regulations
as a whole, or any part thereof other than the part so held to be invalid.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1130.10  DEFINITIONS.
   Words and terms used in these Regulations shall be defined as set forth in
Chapter
1150 of this Planning and Zoning Code.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)

   Lots outside municipal boundaries - see Ohio R.C. 711.24 et seq.
   Revision of plats - see Ohio R.C. 711.28 et seq.

   Street dedication and acceptance - see Ohio R.C. 723.03
   Subdivision proposals in flood hazard areas - see B. & H. 1331.15(d)
   1132.01  RECORDING OF PLAT.
   No plat of any subdivision shall be recorded with the Cuyahoga County
Recorder or have any validity until it has been approved by the City as
provided in these Regulations.  In the event any unapproved plat is recorded,
it shall be considered invalid and the Commission may institute proceedings to
have the plat stricken from the records of the Cuyahoga County Recorder.  (Ord.
96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1132.02  REVISION OF PLAT AFTER APPROVAL.
   No changes, deletions, modifications or revisions shall be made in any plat
of a subdivision after approval has been given by the Commission and Council,
and endorsed in writing on the plat, unless said plat is first resubmitted to
the Commission.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1132.03  SALE OR LEASE OF LAND WITHIN SUBDIVISIONS.
   No subdivider, owner or agent of the owner shall transfer, sell or lease any
land within a subdivision before such land has been approved and recorded in
the manner prescribed in these Regulations.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1132.04  DIVISION OF PARCELS OF LAND; APPROVAL OF  PLANNING COMMISSION
REQUIRED.
   No subdivider, owner or agent of the owner shall divide any parcel existing
on or after August 1, 1960, without approval of the City Planning Commission
and confirmation of such approval by Council.  Approval shall be refused if a
lot or parcel resulting from such division is less than the width and area
required for new developments at the time of the passage of Ordinance 4122, or
the greater width and areas required for lots under amendments to such
Ordinance 4122 for subdivisions accepted by Council subsequent to the effective
date of such amendments, requiring larger lots.  Approval shall be similarly
refused if a resulting lot would be too irregular for construction or
objectionable in that it adversely affects the use or value of adjoining
developed real estate or interferes with the appropriate development of
surrounding undeveloped real estate as set forth in these Regulations.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1132.05  EXCEPTIONS. 
   Whenever the City Planning Commission finds, because of unusual topography
or other physical conditions concerning the land, that practical difficulty or
extraordinary and unnecessary hardship may result from strict compliance with
these Regulations, it may recommend to Council that any applicable provision of
these Regulations be varied so as to relieve such hardship, provided that such
variance may be granted without detriment to the public interest and without
impairing the intent and purpose of these Regulations, the Lyndhurst Zoning
Code, or other applicable provisions of the laws of the City of Lyndhurst.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1132.06  APPEALS.
   Any owner or subdivider who believes that he or she has been aggrieved by
any action of the City Planning Commission refusing to permit a subdivision,
may, within twenty days of such refusal, appeal the adverse decision to Council
by submitting a written request to the Clerk of Council to have the case added
to the agenda of the next regularly scheduled Council meeting.  (Ord. 96-61. 
Passed 4-21-97.)
   1132.99  PENALTY.
   The owner or owners of any building or premises where a violation of any
provision of these Subdivision Regulations is placed or exists, any architect,
builder or contractor who assists in the commission of any such violation and
all persons who violate any of the provisions of these Subdivision Regulations,
or fail to comply herewith, shall, for each violation or noncompliance, be
guilty of a misdemeanor of the  first degree and shall be fined not more than
one thousand dollars ($1,000) or imprisoned not more than six months, or both,
for each offense.  A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during
or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or continues. 
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)

   1134.01  INTENT.
   The provisions of this chapter are established to achieve effective,
efficient and uniform administration of these Regulations.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1134.02  PRE-APPLICATION MEETING OPTIONAL.
   The subdivider of the land proposed to be subdivided may meet with the City
prior to submitting a preliminary plan.  The purpose of such meeting is to
familiarize the subdivider with the requirements and standards contained in
these Regulations, the City's Zoning Code and other applicable City ordinances.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1134.03  PRELIMINARY PLAN CONTENTS.
   The subdivider of the land proposed to be subdivided shall submit nine
copies of the preliminary plan of the proposed subdivision to the Building
Commissioner.  The preliminary plan shall be drawn to a scale of one inch
equals 100 feet and contain the following information which is subject to the
review and approval of the Planning Commission:
   (a)   The proposed name of the subdivision. This name shall not duplicate or
closely approximate the name of any other subdivision in the City, insofar as
is practical.
   (b)   The names, addresses and telephone numbers of the subdivider, the
owner and the person who prepared the preliminary plan;
   (c)   A vicinity map showing the proposed subdivision and its location
within the City, in relation to surrounding subdivisions, streets and nearby
recreation and community facilities;
   (d)   The date of the survey, the scale of the proposed preliminary plan and
a north arrow;
   (e)   The boundary outline of the land to be subdivided;
   (f)   The locations, widths and names of all boundary streets or streets
terminating at such boundaries;
   (g)   The proposed arrangement of streets and sublots with dimensions;
   (h)   The location of all existing watercourses, culverts, storm and
sanitary sewers, watermains and retention and detention systems;
   (i)   The location of all wooded areas, flood plains, wetlands and other
natural features within and/or adjacent to the proposed subdivision;
   (j)   A topographical map with contour intervals of not more than two feet,
with one- foot contour intervals shown where required to accurately portray the
existing topography;
   (k)   The layout, acreage and names of streets, lots and any non-residential
uses, such as commercial or recreational uses, within the proposed subdivision;
   (l)   The location of all proposed utility, water and sewer lines, and of
all detention and retention basins, in the proposed subdivision, and the
location of their nearest existing connections;
   (m)   The existing zoning classifications and lot requirements for the
proposed subdivision, including minimum lot size, width and depth and the yard
and building setback requirements in the zoning district;
   (n)   Any existing or proposed covenants running with the land, deed
restrictions, rights-of-way or easements; and
   (o)   Such other reasonable information as the Commission and the City
Engineer may require. 
      (Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1134.04  PRELIMINARY PLAN PROCEDURES. (SEE EXHIBIT 1  FOLLOWING THE TEXT OF
THIS CHAPTER).
   (a)   The subdivider shall submit nine blue or black line prints of the
preliminary plan to the Building Commissioner.
   (b)   The Building Commissioner will then forward the prints of the
preliminary plan, together with his or her comments and recommendations, to the
City Planning Commission, the City Engineer and the Secretary to Council.
   (c)   The Commission shall set a date for a public meeting at which time the
preliminary plan shall be considered and shall notify the subdivider of the
date, time and place of such meeting so the subdivider may attend.  The public
hearing shall be held within ninety days after the preliminary plan has been
forwarded to the Planning Commission.
   (d)   At said public meeting, the Commission shall, by record vote, approve
or disapprove the preliminary plan as submitted or as modified to meet its
suggestions.
      (1)   Approval.
         A.   If the vote of the Commission is to approve the preliminary plan
as submitted or as modified to meet its suggestions, it shall send the
preliminary plan to Council with a written report of its action.
         B.   Council shall, by record vote, approve or disapprove the
preliminary plan by majority vote.
         C.   If Council approves the preliminary plan, the subdivider may
proceed with the proposed improvement plans, profiles and final plat, which
shall include all modifications as suggested by the Commission and the City
Engineer.  The Secretary of the Commission shall retain one print of the
preliminary plan showing all changes and modifications as proposed by the
Commission and the City Engineer.  Said print shall be used to check the
proposed improvement plans, the profiles, and the final plat when it is
submitted.
      (2)   Disapproval. 
         A.   If the vote of the Commission is to disapprove the preliminary
plan, its action is final unless the subdivider elects to appeal the adverse
report to Council within twenty days after the decision of the Commission.
         B.   If the subdivider elects to appeal the Commission's vote of
disapproval to Council, Council can only approve the preliminary plan by a
minimum three-fourths vote.
   (e)   All actions by both the Commission and Council shall be made a matter
of the minutes of their meetings.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1134.05  PRELIMINARY PLAN APPROVAL PERIOD.
   The approval of a preliminary plan shall be valid for a maximum period of
one year and shall guarantee that the terms under which the approval was
granted will not be affected by changes to these Regulations.  To extend an
approval at the end of one year, the subdivider shall resubmit the complete
preliminary plan to the Building Commissioner, the City Engineer, the Planning
Commission and Council for a full review.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1134.06  PROPOSED IMPROVEMENT PLAN AND PROFILE REQUIREMENTS.
   The subdivider shall prepare proposed improvement plans and profiles of the
proposed subdivision. 
   (a)   Proposed Improvement Plans.  The proposed improvement plans shall be
plotted with a horizontal scale of not less than one inch equals 30 feet and a
vertical scale of one inch equals five feet. 
         The proposed improvement plans shall include:
      (1)   The proposed name of the subdivision;
      (2)   The names, addresses and telephone numbers of the subdivider, the
owner (if different from the subdivider), the professional engineer and
registered surveyor who prepared the improvement plans, and appropriate
registration numbers and seals.
      (3)   A vicinity map showing the proposed subdivision and its location
within the City;
      (4)   The date and scale of the proposed improvement plans, and a north
arrow;
      (5)   The boundary outline of the land to be subdivided;
      (6)   The proposed arrangement of streets and sublots with dimensions;
      (7)   The grading plan for all proposed sublots and common areas in the
proposed subdivision;
      (8)   The layout and construction notes of all proposed culverts, storm
and sanitary sewers, water mains and retention and detention systems;
      (9)   All other existing and proposed features and improvements pertinent
to the platting of the subdivision; and
      (10)   Such other reasonable information as the City Engineer may
require.
   (b)   Proposed Profiles.
      (1)   The proposed profiles, which may be prepared on standard cross-
section paper, shall have a minimum horizontal scale of one inch equals fifty
feet and a vertical scale of one inch equals five feet. 
      (2)   The proposed profiles shall show the existing elevations on the
centerline at intervals of a minimum of fifty feet and at intermediate points
where there is a sharp break in grade. 
      (3)   A proposed centerline Profile shall be shown, with vertical curves
at each change of grade in excess of 0.3 of one percent. 
   (c)   Improvement Plans.  The subdivider shall provide improvement plans for
review by the City Engineer and the Building Commissioner as required.  The
improvement plans shall include all appropriate information and data and shall
be submitted in the manner and form required by said reviewing authority. (Ord.
96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1134.07  PROPOSED IMPROVEMENT PLAN AND PROFILE PROCEDURES. (SEE EXHIBIT 2
FOLLOWING THE  TEXT OF THIS CHAPTER).
   (a)   The subdivider shall submit three blue or black line prints of the
proposed improvement plans and profiles to the City Engineer who shall check
the proposed improvement plans and profiles against all requirements herein
listed in Chapters
1134 and
1136.
   (b)   The city engineer will then forward the prints of the proposed
improvement plans and profiles, together with his or her comments and
recommendations, to the Building Commissioner for his or her review and
comments.
   (c)   A written report of the reviews shall be provided to the subdivider
and the Planning Commission.
   (d)   The subdivider may submit the proposed improvement plans and profiles
at the same time that he or she submits the final plat to the Building
Commissioner and the City Engineer. 
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1134.08  FINAL PLAT REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   The final plat shall be made by a registered professional surveyor who
shall affix his or her signature and seal to the usual certificate stating the
scale of the plat, the correctness of the survey and calculations and that
permanent monuments will be set at points so indicated.
   (b)   The final plat shall be made on a permanent tracing or disk.  A
duplicate document shall be furnished to the City Engineer.
   (c)   The final plat shall be made to the scale of one inch equals fifty
feet.
   (d)   The title of the final plat shall show:
      (1)   The name of the subdivision;
      (2)   The name(s) of the owner(s) and subdivider(s);
      (3)   That the subdivision is located in the City;
      (4)   The date signed by the surveyor;
      (5)   The proper dedication clauses to be signed by the owner and
notarized;
      (6)   The proper utility clauses.
   (e)   The final plat shall:
      (1)   Contain all information included on the preliminary plans,
including all changes and modifications as proposed by the Planning Commission
and/or the City Engineer;
      (2)   Be complete and consistent in itself as to all measurements; and
      (3)   Show all survey data, both as to monuments and courses, used to
define the outlines of the land subdivided.
   (f)   The final plat shall also contain:
      (1)   Acceptance clauses to be signed by the City Engineer, the Secretary
of the Commission and the Clerk of Council;
      (2)   A dedication clause to be signed by the owner containing reference
to these Regulations;
      (3)   The ordinance accepting the plat for record-keeping purposes only;
and
      (4)   An acceptance of dedication of streets to be signed by the Clerk of
Council.  After Council has accepted the dedication of streets as City
highways, as provided for in Section
1134.16.
         (Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1134.09  FINAL PLAT PROCEDURES. (SEE EXHIBIT 3 FOLLOWING THE TEXT OF THIS
CHAPTER).
   (a)   The subdivider shall submit the original tracing of the final plat and
nine blue or black line prints to the City Engineer.  If the City Engineer
finds that all requirements of Section
1134.08 have been complied with, the City Engineer shall sign and forward the
same to the Planning Commission.
   (b)   If the Commission finds that all requirements of Section
1134.08 have been complied with and that all conditions imposed by it in its
preliminary approval have been met, the Commission shall approve such plat and
send it to Council.
   (c)   The City shall bill the subdivider for all costs and expenses incurred
by the City Engineer for the review of the preliminary plan, proposed
improvement plans, profiles and the final plat.
   (d)   If Council finds that all the requirements of Section
1134.08 have been complied with, that all conditions imposed by the Commission
in its preliminary approval have been met and that all costs and expenses owed
to the City thus far have been paid, Council shall, by resolution, approve the
final plat for record-keeping purposes only, and the subdivider shall be
entitled to rely on the fact that the Council, upon compliance with Sections
1134.11,
1134.12,
1134.13,
1134.14 and
1134.15 and payment of all fees, charges, expenses and guarantees to the City
incurred relating to such subdivision, will approve the final plat for record. 
The acceptance of dedication of streets clause, as provided for in Section
1134.08(f)(1), shall not be signed by the Clerk of Council until the City
Engineer and the Roads and Utilities Committee of Council have certified that
the subdivider has complied with the conditions of Sections
1134.11,
1134.12,
 1134.13,
1134.14 and
1134.15 and Council has, by resolution, approved the final plat for acceptance
of dedication of streets, as provided for in Section
 1134.16.
   (e)   All actions by both the Commission and Council shall be made a matter
of the minutes of their meetings.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1134.10  FINAL PLAT APPROVAL PERIOD.
   The approval of the final plat shall be valid for a maximum period of one
year and shall guarantee that the terms under which the approval was granted
will not be affected by changes to these Regulations.  To extend an approval at
the end of one year the subdivider shall resubmit the complete improvement
plans, profiles and final plat to the City Engineer, the Planning Commission
and Council for a full review.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1134.11  IMPROVEMENTS REQUIRED.
   (a)   No road, street, highway, lane, boulevard or other way shall be
accepted for dedication within the City unless it has been approved to the full
satisfaction of Council and the City Engineer, in accordance with the minimum
requirements set forth in Chapter
1136.
   (b)   No person shall use any public or private road, street, highway, lane,
boulevard or other way or part thereof for access to more than one dwelling
house, and no additional building permits shall be issued therefor, unless it
has first been improved to the full satisfaction of Council and the City
Engineer.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1134.12  FILING OF IMPROVEMENT BOND.
   (a)   After Council approves the final plat for record-keeping purposes
only, but before the commencement of any work in such subdivision, the
subdivider shall file with the Clerk of Council an improvement bond with
corporate surety in the amount of the final construction costs of all
improvements necessary to complete the subdivision in a satisfactory and timely
manner in accordance with these Regulations and other applicable regulations of
the City. 
   (b)   Bonds for subdivisions shall be in such form as are approved by the
Director of Law. 
   (c)   The Clerk of Council shall not affix his or her signature to the
acceptance for record-keeping purposes only provision of a plat as provided for
in Section
1134.08(f)(1) until the bond or bonds contemplated herein have been filed in
his or her office and approved by the Director of Law.
   (d)   Upon failure of completion of all improvements within twelve months
from the time of final plat approval as specified in Section
1134.10, or any extension granted by the Planning Commission or Council for
good cause shown, the City may, at its option and upon ten days written notice
to the subdivider, complete all or any portion of the improvements and the
subdivider shall be liable to the City for the costs of such improvements, plus
an additional twenty-five percent of such costs to cover City overhead.
   (e)   Should the City exercise its option to complete all or any portion of
the improvements, the improvement bond amount shall be declared forfeited and
the costs of completion, plus overhead, shall be charged against such amount.
   (f)   Upon the furnishing of a maintenance bond by the subdivider as
provided for in Section
1134.15, the balance of the improvement bond fund shall be returned.  Final
payments will not be made until the subdivider provides a maintenance bond.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1134.13  INSPECTION OF COMPLETED IMPROVEMENTS.
   Following the completion of the permanent paving, an inspection of all
improvements installed by the subdivider, as listed in Chapter
1136, shall be made by the Roads and Utilities Committee of Council and the
City Engineer.  Any defects disclosed by this inspection shall be corrected by
the subdivider.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1134.14  FILING OF ABSTRACT, CERTIFICATE OF TITLE, GUARANTEE OF TITLE OR
TITLE INSURANCE.
   As soon as the improvements installed by the subdivider have been approved
by the Roads and Utilities Committee of Council and the City Engineer, the
subdivider shall file with the Director of Law an abstract, certificate of
title or title insurance in the amount of at least twenty-five thousand dollars
($25,000), meeting with the approval of the Director of Law and showing the
title to the street or streets in the subdivision to be good in the City for
street purposes and to be free and clear from all encumbrances whatsoever.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1134.15  FILING OF MAINTENANCE BOND.
   After the improvements are completed and approved by the Roads and Utilities
Committee of Council and the City Engineer, the subdivider shall provide the
City with a three-year maintenance bond for at least fifty percent of the final
construction costs for all improvements installed.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1134.16  ACCEPTANCE OF DEDICATION OF STREETS.
   Once the Roads and Utilities Committee and the City Engineer approve and
certify that the subdivider has complied with the conditions of Chapter
1136 and Sections
1134.14 and
1134.15, and payment of all fees, charges, expenses and guarantees to the City
has been made as required by Section
1134.20, Council will then approve the plat for dedication of such street
areas, accept the streets as City highways and release all of the improvement
bonds required by Section
1134.12. The Clerk of Council will then sign the acceptance of dedication of
streets clause on the final plat.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1134.17  RECORDING OF FINAL PLAT.
   The final plat in final executed form, together with the fee required by the
County Recorder, shall be given to the Building Commissioner and City Engineer
so that the final plat may be filed with the Cuyahoga County Recorder.
   Divisions of parcels provided for in Section
1132.04 are also subject to the requirements of the preceding paragraph, to the
extent that if such division is allowed by Council, it will not be effective
until a tracing of the plat is provided, executed by the subdivider and given
to the Building Commissioner and the City Engineer in final executed form,
together with the fee required by the County Recorder and payment of all fees,
charges, expenses and guarantees owed to the City, so that such a plat may be
filed with the Cuyahoga County Recorder. 
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1134.18  MINOR SUBDIVISIONS.
   (a)   A minor subdivision, which involves the division of a parcel of land
along an existing public street that is fully improved and which does not
involve the opening, widening or extension of any road or street and does not
involve more than five proposed lots, shall be exempt from the requirements of
final plat approval and Sections
1134.06 to
1134.16 of these Regulations.
   (b)   Such a minor subdivision shall be filed and recorded in the offices of
the County Auditor and County Recorder by an authorized representative of the
City within thirty days after preliminary plan approval by the Planning
Commission and Council, provided that all required fees, charges, expenses and
guarantees as required by Section
1134.20 have been paid to the City.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1134.19  LOCATION OF FINAL PLAT FILE.
   The City Engineer shall be the custodian of all final plats for all the
platted lands in the City, subject to rules and regulations promulgated by the
Planning Commission. Such plats shall be maintained on file, properly indexed
and available for inspection by the public.  Copies of such plats shall also be
maintained at the City. 
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1134.20  FEES, CHARGES, EXPENSES AND GUARANTEES.
   The subdivider of the proposed subdivision shall be responsible for all
fees, charges, expenses and guarantees owed to the City for costs incurred
relating to such proposed subdivision.  Such fees, charges, expenses and
guarantees shall include engineering fees for the City Engineer, inspection
fees, filing and recording fees, performance and improvement bonds and
abstracts, certificates of title, guarantees of title or title insurance.
   All such fees, charges, expenses and guarantees shall be paid to the City in
full prior to the recording of any plat with the Cuyahoga County Recorder's
Office.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)

   1136.01  APPLICATION OF CHAPTER.
   The provisions of this chapter shall control the manner in which streets,
lots and other elements of a subdivision are arranged on the land.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1136.02  PURPOSE.
   The standards set forth in this chapter are established to achieve the
objectives of these Regulations and to create attractive and functional
development that will be an asset to the community. 
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1136.03  RESPONSIBILITIES OF THE SUBDIVIDER.
   Unless otherwise specified, the subdivider, through his or her engineer,
shall prepare and furnish to the City all plans, specifications, cost estimates
and any other documents necessary for the construction and installation of all
required improvements.  Further, the subdivider shall provide and pay for all
improvements necessary to serve his or her proposed subdivision, as determined
by these Regulations and the City Engineer.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1136.04  INITIATION OF IMPROVEMENTS.
   No improvement shall be started unless the complete plans, cross-sections,
details and specifications, prepared, signed and sealed by a registered
professional engineer in accordance with Chapter
1134, have been approved by the City Engineer, the Planning Commission and
Council and unless an improvement bond, as provided for in Section
1134.12, has been filed with the Clerk of Council.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1136.05  MINIMUM REQUIREMENTS GENERALLY.
   The minimum requirements for improving streets, lots and other elements of a
subdivision shall be in accordance with the following sections.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1136.06  STREETS.
   The minimum requirements for improving any public or private road, street,
highway, lane, boulevard or other way or part thereof, for the purposes
contemplated in these Regulations, shall be as follows:
   (a)   Right-of-way.
      (1)   The minimum right-of-way of any proposed street shall be fifty
feet. Council, upon the recommendation of the City Engineer and the Planning
Commission, may require street rights-of-way wider than fifty feet wherever, in
its judgment, provision for public travel makes the wider right-of-way
desirable or wherever any general plan of street development adopted by the
Commission and Council requires the establishment of streets of greater right-
of-way.
      (2)   The location and right-of-way of proposed streets shall be such as
to fit in with any plan of street development adopted by the Commission or
other public authority.  Due regard shall be given to existing streets or
streets capable of being established in surrounding property, so that streets
may be laid out through adjacent or neighboring subdivisions with reasonable
continuity of location and right-of-way.
   (b)   Pavement Width.
      (1)   The minimum width of pavement shall be twenty-six feet back of curb
to back of curb, constructed of seven-inch reinforced concrete, as specified in
the most recent edition of State of Ohio Department of Transportation
Construction and Material Specifications and constructed on a thoroughly
consolidated subgrade, conforming to the camber and crown of the finished
pavement.
      (2)   The City Engineer, the Commission and Council may, when it is
deemed necessary, require a pavement of a width of more than twenty-six feet,
back of curb to back of curb, to be constructed, and the improvement shall then
conform to such requirements.
   (c)   Direct Continuation of Streets.
      (1)   In order that proposed streets may be as nearly coterminous as
possible with existing streets in adjoining subdivisions, due provision shall
be made for the direct continuation of all existing streets which extend to the
boundaries of a proposed subdivision.  In cases where adjacent subdivisions are
separated by existing thoroughfares, due provision shall be made for
continuing, in a practical manner, such of the existing streets through the
proposed subdivision as may be necessary for public requirements, subject to
the approval of the Commission and Council.
      (2)   Where the land for a proposed subdivision adjoins unalloted
property capable of being subdivided, then the streets in such proposed
subdivision need only be carried to the boundaries thereof.
   (d)   Dead-end Streets.  Only where conditions make it impossible to extend
streets to the boundary of the subdivision will so-called "dead-end" streets be
approved, subject to the recommendation of the Commission and the approval of
Council.  All such dead-end streets shall terminate at a turning circle having
a minimum pavement radius of sixty feet.  In all other instances, streets shall
be carried to the boundaries of the subdivision.
   (e)   Cul-de-sacs.  A cul-de-sac shall have a minimum pavement radius of
sixty feet at its turn-around and shall not exceed 1,500 feet in length.
      (Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1136.07  INTERSECTIONS.
   At the intersections of the side lines of streets, existing or proposed,
turnouts having a minimum radius of twenty-five feet must be provided.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1136.08  STREET GRADES.
   Street grades shall be installed in accordance with the City Engineer's
standards.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1136.09  STREET NAMES.
   The streets shown on the plat shall be named so that there will be no
duplication of any existing street name within Cuyahoga County insofar as is
practical.  Street names must be approved by Council. 
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.) 
   1136.10  STREET NAME SIGNS.
   The subdivider shall provide for the purchase, delivery and installation of
all required street name signs.  Such signs shall be designed and installed in
accordance with City specifications. 
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1136.11  BLOCK LENGTH.
   Where practical, intersecting streets shall be provided so that no block
shall be longer than 2,400 feet. 
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1136.12  CURBS AND GUTTERS.
   The pavement shall include concrete curbs.  If cast-in-place concrete, the
curbs shall be six inches wide by eighteen inches deep.  If integral concrete
curbs are used, the details must be approved by the City Engineer and the
Planning Commission.  Curb drains of four-inch vitrified sewer pipe, hub and
spigot pattern or approved equal shall be constructed at the back of the curb
to a depth of twenty-four inches below the top of the curb and backfilled with
number 67 washed limestone or approved equal.  All curbs shall be constructed
in conformity with the most recent edition of State of Ohio Department of
Transportation Construction and Material Specifications.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1136.13  DRIVEWAY APRONS.
   Driveway aprons and the sidewalk continuations thereof shall be constructed
to a depth of six inches of concrete with temperature mesh and with
reinforcement as structurally required. 
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1136.14  SIDEWALKS.
   Concrete sidewalks having a width of five feet and a depth of four inches
shall be constructed of non-reinforced concrete and shall be located on each
side of the road in the subdivision, including intersections and corner lots. 
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1136.15  TREE LAWNS.
   The tree lawns shall be graded to a slope of three-eighths of an inch per
foot rise from the top of the curb to the front of the sidewalk and shall be
graded four inches below the finished grade.  There shall be a minimum of four
inches of good topsoil spread, rolled, surfaced, seeded and fertilized.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1136.16  STREET TREES.
   The owner shall plant trees within the tree lawn in accordance with the
specifications of the City's Service Department.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1136.17  TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES AND TRAFFIC SIGNS.
   All traffic control devices and traffic signs, deemed necessary by the
Director of Safety to regulate traffic in accordance with the Traffic Code,
shall be installed.  Such installations shall be at the expense of the
subdivider and shall conform to the standards adopted by the City.  (Ord. 96-
61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1136.18  HYDRANTS.
   All hydrants shall conform to the City of Cleveland's Water Division's
uniform standards.  (Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1136.19  WATER MAINS.
   All water mains and related items shall conform to the City of Cleveland's
Water Division's uniform standards. 
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1136.20  SEWERS.
   All storm and sanitary sewers and related items shall conform to the uniform
rules, regulations and standards for the design and construction of sewerage
improvements adopted by the committee on Uniform Standards for Sewerage
Improvements for Cuyahoga County, Ohio.  (Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1136.21  SURVEY MONUMENTS.
   Survey monuments shall be installed in accordance with the City Engineer's
standards.  (Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1136.22  UTILITIES.
   All utility features, such as electric, gas, telephone and cable television,
which can be underground shall be underground.  All utility features shall be
installed by the subdivider in accordance with the respective utility company's
standards and as approved by the City Engineer.    (Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-
97.)
   1136.23  CITY STREET LIGHTS.
   City street lights shall be installed by the subdivider in accordance with
the utility company's standards and as approved by the City Engineer, the
Planning Commission and Council.  All City lighting shall be underground fed.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1136.24  SUBLOTS.
   Sublots must meet the requirements of the City's Zoning Code as to frontage
and area.  (Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1136.25  RESERVE STRIPS.
   No plat or map of a proposed street or subdivision showing reserve strips
controlling access to public ways, or showing strips of land which will not
prove taxable for special improvements, will be approved, provided, however,
that such reserve strips may be shown where the control and disposal of land
comprising such strips are definitely placed with the City under conditions
meeting the approval of the City Engineer and the Director of Law.
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1136.26  NATURAL FEATURES.
   The subdivider shall, whenever possible, preserve existing views, wooded
areas, watercourses, trees and other natural features of the existing
topography and integrate them into the design of the subdivision. 
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1136.27  IMPOSITION OF EASEMENTS.
   The Planning Commission shall regulate the imposition of easements, with the
exception of easements for overhead power transmission lines or gas lines or
easements obtainable by condemnation proceedings, on property in the City as
follows:
   (a)   No subdivider, owner, or agent of the owner of land within the City
shall convey or be the grantee of easements on lands within the City without
the approval of the Commission.  The Commission shall inquire into and be
satisfied that such easement will not substantially change the use of land
except as permitted by these Regulations and the City of Lyndhurst's Zoning
Code.  The Commission shall further require that proof that hazards to the
public safety will not be increased, particularly, but without prejudice to the
generality hereof, pedestrian and vehicular traffic in adjoining roadways.  To
attain the objectives of these Regulations and the City of Lyndhurst's Zoning
Code, the Commission may request the imposition of conditions in approving
easements.
   (b)   If the Commission determines that full consideration of the
application for an easement will be facilitated by notices to adjoining
abutting owners to both the dominant and subservient estates affected by the
easement, then it shall require notice in such form as it determines to such
adjoining abutting owners, to be served by the Building Commissioner. 
      (Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1136.28  MAXIMUM NUMBER OF STRUCTURES ON UNSUBDIVIDED LAND.
   (a)   Maximum Dwellings on Unsubdivided Land.  Only one single-family or
multi- family dwelling, whichever is a permitted use, shall be constructed on a
parcel of land in residential areas which have not been subdivided prior to the
time a permit for construction is sought. 
   (b)   Maximum Buildings on Unsubdivided Land.  In nonresidential use
districts, only one building may be constructed on a parcel if no plat is
approved or on file as provided in Section
 1134.17.  However, a land owner may present a plat showing a parcel or parcels
that will be improved with a building, accessways to the land, easements and
other usual developments with a reservation of the balance of the land as Block
"A" for future development. 
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
   1136.29  OTHER CONSTRUCTION AND DESIGN REQUIREMENTS.
   Any construction and design which is not covered by this chapter shall be
approved by the City Engineer and accepted by the Planning Commission before
being submitted for approval of Council. 
(Ord. 96-61.  Passed 4-21-97.)
